description:
Awesome spot, this place is just a couple blocks away from where I work. They don't open for lunch and only for dinner.  They do NOT serve pho here so don't bother to ask them for it haha, unless you want to troll.  The food here is awesome, the 7 course beef is amazing! you make all the rolls yourself and it gives you a really good experience.  Although all the meat and the rolls kind of tasted the same after a while, its still delicious! 

I recommend complimenting the food with a nice beer! They have this "33" beer from Vietnam and its pretty good! its a beer you don't see often at much bars and stuff.  I always walk by here pretty often and it always seems pretty packed regardless of the day.  We were here on a Friday and the whole place was packed already.  They have plenty of locations and I did read about them, their first restaurant is in Saigon! 

Only beware that this place is in the Tenderloin, so keep your wallets and purses and valuables handy at all time if you plan on doing street parking and watch where you step because there is always a lot of needles on the floor..... something I have to watch out for everyday, lol.
author: Ben Z.

description:
I have been coming here for what seems like a decade which is actually pretty close to being true. I love 7 Course Beef and this is one of the best in the Bay Area to enjoy this Vietnamese speciality. They're located on Geary Street in the Lower Nob area and parking can be easy or quite challenging depending on when you come.

My dishes I love to order the most are the Bo Nuong La Lot(leaf wrapped beef), the Bo Nuong Sa(grilled beef with lemongrass and onions), and the Bo Nhung Dam(raw tenderloin beef you cook at your table). All are authentic and really hit the spot if you enjoy this cuisine. 

There can be a wait during the busy weekend dinner times as you would expect. They do take reservations so you might want to consider doing so in advance. Service is solid and I always leave this restaurant with a smile on my face.
author: Angela L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night at 6:30. There was no wait, in fact half of the tables were empty. We came to try their famous beef in 7 ways and we also ordered the sugar cane shrimp. The beef in 7 ways was a lot of food. We had 4 people and we ordered 3 portions which came out to be the right amount with everyone being stuffed by the end of the meal. 

The beef in 7 ways overall was great and a fun way to try a lot of dishes. Dipping the rice paper in water and making your own spring roll was really fun. My favorite was the Hawaiian leaf wrapped beef sausage- so flavorful! My least favorite was the pate and the congee at the end (too much ginger for my likening). Next time I would order ala carte and try more of their other dishes. The sugar cane shrimp was really good but kinda pricey for the 3 pieces that we got.
author: Jenny J.

description: I've been really into vietnamese spring rolls lately, especially the places where you get to roll them yourself. Anh Hong is known for rolling your own spring rolls as well as their seven courses of beef. I decided to get the grilled chicken with vermicelli instead of the seven course beef since I like chicken more. I love how much meat they give you, as well as the vegetables. The workers here are super friendly, constantly checked up on us while giving us recommendations on what is good there(basically everything was fire there). I left super full, but I felt good since I basically ate salad for dinner. I would definitely come back here.
author: Lisa W.

description:
WOAH HEY HELLO!!!! I am a HUGE fan of this restaurant. First things first... 

+ Location: it's located right in the TL, so be careful if you decide to walk to this location. But I've parked here plenty of times before and it's totally fine. 
+ Food: WOW. Make your own spring rolls is my favorite! (It's basically anything off of the SPECIALS or GRILL section.) Specials is cool bc they grill the meat for you and you just have to make the spring rolls yourself. Under the Grill section, you actually get to grill the meat on top of it! I recommend doing a mix of ordering from both Specials & Grill for a blended experience (and in case you're HUNGERS) and want to eat fast. The whole experience is SO MUCH FUN and it's such a great date / group spot. The meat was yummy (I ordered lemon grass & beef in Hawaiian leaf) and was thoroughly impressed with both. I opted out of the 7 Course Meal special bc that felt like too much food. 

My favorites are Hawaiian leaf, grilled beef with lemongrass, beef + shrimp, beef wrapped in shrimp with noodles, and beef carpaccio. 

+ Wine: HOLY you can get a WHOLE bottle for as cheap as $22 (we ordered the $25 cab and I was very impressed LOL)

All together the whole meal (grill + special + one bottle of wine) came out to $72 and I was STUFFED. This has easily become one of my new favorite places to eat at (and on top of that game in on a Thurs night 7:30pm and there was no line / plenty of seating)!

I'll be back! AND ROLLING SPRING ROLLS ALL DAY.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Met with a BIIIGGGG group of people (~25) for dinner in a Friday night at 6 PM. 

The restaurant was ready for us when we came! Very friendly, accomodating, efficient, food came out of the kitchen fast. Took our orders quickly (everyone had the 7-course beef). Generous pours of the wine (thank you)! 

Fun dining experience, great place for dinner parties (large and small), and more intimate family dinners. 

Would love to come again!
author: Peds P.

description:
Anh hong is a really great place to have a filling dinner. At just $25 per a person, you can get yourself a 7 course beef dinner. Location isn't so great so be prepared to walk through the dirty streets in the TL just to get to Anh Hong.

If it is available, I highly recommend getting the water prawns with banh hoi. These water prawns are absolutely enormous! The sauce is sweet and savory and just soaks into the banh hoi (rice noodle squares). If you behead the prawns and let the roe and juices soak up in the banh hoi, the flavors just blow everything else out of the water. The owner was kind and gave us an extra water prawn on the house!

The best part of the 7 course beef would be the three different meat sausages that it comes with. Being able to soak the rice papers and use it to wrap it with the sausages and veggies you like is great because I get to make the wrap the way I want it. The beef fondue is delicious too! 

Service is great and very quick. We got all our items really fast which is amazing seeing how busy they always are. This is always a go to spot.
author: Timothy C.

description:
I was so excited to try their 7 beef courses cause good Vietnamese food is non-existent in NYC. Despite being in the Tenderloin, the restaurant doesn't look so sketchy. It's quite spacious and clean. 

The star is absolutely the Beef Fondue (Bo Nhung Giam). I guess everyone orders that here. You dip the eye round beef slices into a small hotpot containing this weird pink sauce, then wrap it with lettuce, cilantro, basil using the rice paper wrap. It's lightly sour and sweet so I feel like I can eat ten rolls. I love the Raw Beef Salad (Bo Tai Chanh) as well. You should try it if you don't mind eating blue rare, thinly sliced beef. Other dishes like Bo La Lot were okay. 

Good place if you want something not too heavy.
author: Hannah V.

description:
You have to try 7 courses of beef sometime if your foodie career. It's a must! And it definitely won't disappoint. You might balk at the price point ($25 pp), but it's so worth it. I recommend coming here with a group so you can each get one order plus some other food to share.

Of the 7 courses, my favorites were the meatball courses (there are 3 of them) and the congee, which is so delicious. I also recommend the deconstructed spring rolls - they'll bring the rice noodles, veggies, whichever protein you choose, and the rice paper with water. So fun and delicious!
author: Sherry L.

description: Unassuming simple restaurant that is BURSTING with flavor (and patrons). Definitely a great place to bring friends and family. I recommend getting extra of the rice noodle dish and extra rice paper wrappers, and just wrap everything and add a square of the rice noodles to everything. Mmmmmm sooo good.
author: Esther Y.

description:
Since Pagolac restaurant was closed, I had no choice tonight but to come here for the traditional Vietnamese 7 courses of beef, aka the beef fondue.  It costs 25 dollars per person but there is not much beef on the plate for how much you pay for it. I was surprised to see a plain beef rice soup bowl which cost 10 dollars and 3.50 dollars for an extra small plate of pickles.  

I had the worst dining experience and I won't return back again.   It's probably been 20 years since I had been to this restaurant location.   There is another Anh Hong in San Jose, where the food and service are both much better.  The location is in the tenderloin and parking is extremely difficult.  There are only a few small tables so waiting for a table of 2 or 4 will be super long. 

There is one woman server, who does not speak Vietnamese, but Chinese.  I just could not believe that the owner hires the most incompetent waitress!   The waitress is rude, loud mouth, could not get the order right.  She screamed at the customers as they were no body.   This woman must be fired!   Haha.  With my die hard compassion, I still had to leave her and the cook good tip- I hope the restaurant 's owner  will realize this and change so the restaurant will succeed in the Bay Area. 

The quality of the beef was not good as the beef was not tender and was very dry.  The vegetables are not fresh either.  Totally disappointing. 

Terrible terrible terrible!   
I won't dine at a place where customer service is horrible.  Diners be aware!
author: Ivory B.

description:
This place was so memorable that I remembered when my childhood friend took me here more than a decade ago. The part I remembered the most was obviously making my own spring rolls! It was magical to see the spring roll skin turn soft by dipping it into water. Since I was a kid back when I first tried it, I had no idea where it was. I recently tracked it down through google and yelp and came here to relive my childhood memory.

This place smelled like gas when I first walked in because there is one dish with a portable gas stove. However, once the 7 course beef came out, I was impressed all over again. I would recommend doing a la carte because 7 courses is way too much! The best dish out of the 7 courses was the grilled beef sausages, so you should definitely order that. Making my own spring rolls was very fun and made me appreciate all the ingredients that go into Vietnamese cuisine. I appreciate how it is not only tasty but also healthy!!
author: Andrea T.

description:
Beeeeeeefffffffy beefcake of 7 course beef. Be prepared to eat a helluvalot of meat! Super tasty, and yes, come on down 'cause the price is right! -1 for service as there is only 1 (sometimes 1.5?) waiters trying to do their best, but just isn't enough (missing utensils, glasses, etc)- order everything up front!

Pro tip: if you want the water prawns, call ahead of time and reserve them! They were already sold out by 7pm!
author: Evan B.

description:
I had an extremely terrible experience here...

I am Vietnamese so I'm no stranger to 7 courses of beef, but this was the worst experience that I've had by far! 

My family and I arrived as a party of 5 at around 7pm on a Saturday. The restaurant was half full so we were seated and had our order taken immediately after we entered. The sauces and beef salad came out first, but the salad looked like a mess that was hastily put together.

We were unimpressed, but finished it all because we were starving. It took another 10 minutes for the fondue to come out. They had forgotten our plate of meat, so we patiently waited for the meat as restaurant started filling up. We reminded our waiters a couple of times, but thought it was strange to have to wait so long for an uncooked plate of meat!

It took us around 20 mins to finish the beef fondue. We waited a total of 40 mins for our next course and flagged waiters down every 10 minutes, but it never arrived. What was worse, was that none of the waiters bothered to stop by our table and just said "it's coming" every time we asked. My mom was pissed having to wait 40 minutes and decided to pay for what we ate and left to a different restaurant.

I'm sure the food would've been fine, IF IT HAD ARRIVED. This was by far the worst customer service I've ever received at a Bo 7 Mon place and I won't be coming back.
author: Vu P.

description: This is my go to place for Vietnamese bbq. I like coming here with my family it's such a treat for us. Make sure to call and make a reservation because they tend to get busy!
author: Ly L.

description: This place is a mandatory visit if you are from out of town! No need to explain. Because you need to enjoy the unique flavors. If you're into seafood get the lemongrass mixed grill and the water prawns!! MUST TRY.
author: Andrew J.

description:
Get the Bo 7 Mon!!! 

Absolutely love the raw beef salad and the little sausage platter that comes with it. What a glorious dinner to share between 2, 3, or n.
author: Laura B.

description: Oh and to a point another reviewer brought up, they now ask up front if you have any food allergies related to peanuts.
author: Robert P.

description:
EVENT: We needed some food... like Vietnamese style stuff! Cravings are realz... you know when you're Vietnamese... and you're missing your mom's cooking... her authentic Vietnamese food..... YES! This is the pace to go if you're in SF!!!! If ya'll like wraps and all!

SERVICE: kinda slow service... but I can wait... only one lady who runs around everywhere... she's sooooo nice! I love her! I would recommended to come early because it does get very busy and one lady server running to show. 

FOOD:
(1) 7 Course Beef - comes with tons of beef... like 7 courses! Make lots of wraps!! YUM
(2) Beef fondue - dipped into a pot of vinegar dipping... a little raw is good
(3) Vietnamese Raw Beef Salad - OMG! My favorite! A must get... tons of flavor... and if you like it raw... and RAW beef - yes! 
(4) Beef sausage - 

BEER:
Yeah! If you're feeling azn like me... Tsing Tao! Kirin... a small selection... but good enough for Vietnamese food.

**MUST GET: Raw Beef Salad = 100% delish! 

**OVERALL: Good for groups! Good for a Vietnamese party! 100% delish!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
One of my favorite places for dinner in the city.  I have taken many visitors here and they all love it!  For my sister who lives in Seattle, there is nothing like a place like this offered in Seattle.

I love the whole wrapping your own rolls, they provide you tons of fresh veggies and herbs and the pickled veggies is my favorite part.  Even though it is a Vietnamese place, they do not serve pho!  

Definitely order the egg rolls with the rice noodles wrapped around it, for some odd reason with the noodles wrap around it and gives it better flavor the texture of the whole thing is so good.  A must order.  The grilled pork and chicken is awesome.  We like the prawn wrapped beef and the pork in the hawaiian leaf.  Most of the grilled meat though you cannot go wrong. 

This place is known for his 7 beef course dinner, but my bf said he only likes a couple of them so we always order ala carte.
author: Lauren S.

description:
What's in the 7 courses of beef? 
- raw beef salad 
- mini beef hot pot (watch that fire, the heat is real). 
- beef pâté (get the tilde above the e)
- beef sausage, version 1 (wrap with lettuce or thin rice paper + all the veggie works)
- beef sausage, version 2 
- beef sausage, version 2 
- rice porridge with beef (teochew style) 

Get it. It lives up to the hype. There's a good amount of vegetables, so it's not overwhelmingly heavy.

You know it's legit when Vietnamese groups come here. 100% recommend.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Seven courses of beef... need I say more! 

This was an experience! We ate dinner with a large group, the serving staff were upfront with how much food we should order without having too much. I think we ended up with 4 between 7 of us.

Tip: if you have a food allergy speak up. We weren't asked but one of the dishes had peanut in it and hubby almost ate it before I pointed it out to him.
author: Sarah S.

description:
There is no better eating experience than eating with your hands.  I love ordering anything from here that you can wrap up into a summer roll.  It's like Korean bbq with the variety of meats and veggies but theoretically less messy (if you got those rice paper rolling skills!).  I've had the 7 course beef, and it's always waaay more food than I can eat.  They let you take everything home (and even give you extra greens if you ask) and you're set with another whole meal. 

Service was great the last time I went, got very useful recommendations and no one tried to push us into over-ordering.  

Tips and Tricks
-Eat with your hands!  Lick sauce off your fingers, it's part of the experience
-You can order ala carte if you think the 7 course beef is too much.  Lots of options to grill at the table or precooked meats to wrap
-Order extra noodle squares!
-Don't be afraid of that extra smelly fish sauce, it tastes amazing
author: Jessica L.

description:
ordered a la carte for DIY springrolls. the shrimp paste with sugarcane comes in an order of 3 pieces for $18 and is waaaay overpriced for the cost of shrimp paste, but the dish is delish. we also got steamed beef pates (AMAZING), grilled pork, and grilled chicken.

the lady (possibly owner or manager) came by and taught us how to construct our own spring rolls even though we didn't ask for a tutorial. it was kind of cute, but we're asian... and we've done it many many many many times before. i could make a spring roll with my eyes closed while doing a handstand. we ended up smiling and nodding for 3 minutes while she went over every single ingredient on the vegetable and herb plate as if we've never seen them before.

ive had better, but this was not bad.
author: Judy L.

description:
Living In The City Made me miss this place.. where my Bus frequently stop here.. My roommate decided to try it as word of mouth from his work saying this place is GOOD!!

We tried the 7 Course meal .. I'd say.. I'd come back to this place to bring my out of town / Out of Country friends to dine in San Francisco (Proud to say a diverse community with lots of food choices )

Wish I know how to make Rice paper.. turned out to be messy if your not used to it. But it's the meat and the sauce that make my stay here Great .. One of the few Asian Restaurant I've visited where they come back and ask how we're doing.. Kudos !!!!

The neighborhood is in a soo soo place But once your in .. Your in a different World.. still safe though considering their Restaurant is on the main Street
author: Donovan L.

description:
My friends and I were having a girls day out, and we stopped by here for dinner. 

Parking wasn't bad. We parked a block up, but I know it's usually harder to find parking in this area because there's only street parking. 

The place looks okay on the inside. Regular Asian restaurant, but of course we are there for the food, not the decoration. Its not too big. It probably seats about 30-40 people.

The service is okay. The lady was really nice and happy when she came to take our order. We know we wanted to do the 7 course beef, but we weren't sure how many orders since we wanted to order a few more items a la carte. She recommended we did 2.

We also ordered:
7 course beef
Anh Hong egg rolls w/ vegetables and noodles
Chao tom w/ and banh hoi

Everything was really good. I love traditional Vietnamese food. Anything that has to do with rolling spring rolls and dipping it in the mam nem. Yummmmm!!

The only thing that could be improved it the service after you get your food. We didn't get water refills until after we were done eating. It was hard to wave someone down for water because they were all focused and busy (tunnel vision). Then paying took long too, so maybe bring cash in all denominations. That way you can give the exact amount and leave without having to wait forever too get change.
author: Lily T.

description:
I came here with a couple friends to celebrate someone's birthday and all of us were so impressed with the 7 courses of beef. Luckily we went with an Anh Hong veteran that had been there multiple times already, so he was able to show us how to eat the food! (Tbh if I went with people that hadn't been there before I wouldn't have known what to do LOL.) 

The 7 courses of beef is $25 per person, but you can always order less servings if you aren't big eaters. I was with a party of 7 people and we probably could have gotten 6 servings, but we went with 7 since it was some of our first times and we were huuungry! The first dish is a papaya salad, followed by the fondue (raw beef that you dip in hot soup). After a lil bit we got the third, fourth, fifth, and sixth dishes together: 3 types of sausages and beef meatballs. The last dish is the beef porridge. I loved wrapping all the different types of meats with the pickled veggies, lettuce, and cucumbers in the wraps they provided! It was pretty fun, and a good way to get veggies in when you're eating so much meat. My favorite course was definitely any of the sausages because they all had unique but delicious flavors. I was also super surprised I actually liked the porridge because usually I skip porridge whenever I see it.

All of us left the restaurant with full, bloated bellies but we all were so happy with our meal. I would love to come again. Anh Hong seems like a great place for family gatherings or celebrations because you can make reservations.
author: Tara A.

description:
$24.50 per person for 7 courses of beef.  Not bad! 

With 4 people, they even recommended getting the 7 courses for just 3 people and ordering another appetizer. 

Drinks are reasonable as well, and you can even bring your own bottle of wine for $8.95 corkage.  Not bad!

They are very generous with their portions.  Even though we ordered for 3, there was more than enough beef for 4.  Plus, they make sure you have plenty of rice paper, veggies, and sauce to wrap all 7 courses of beef. 

Great value and a gem in San Francisco with prices rising everywhere else.  Just hope it will stay that way.
author: Sarah K.

description:
7-course beef! I'd heard about this magical concept for years, but it wasn't until recently that I got to try it for myself.

THE OVERVIEW.
- The area this place is in is not great. I would come here earlier in the day, and maybe get dropped off instead of trying to find parking
~ Reservations may be required? It was empty when we arrived at 5:30ish, but quickly filled up with primarily families (guessing the time was the factor on that)
+ Come in a group, because 7-courses is a lot of beef for any one person
~ Your entire group must agree to order the 7-course option
+ Cash and credit card accepted

It's a very low-frills place, but the food is delicious. You'll probably walk out liking beef a little less, but it's a tasty meal!
author: Claire S.

description:
I can't believe I never had 7 course beef until now. I'm already planning my next trip here because I'm currently craving it as I write this. Of the seven courses, my favorite hands-down was the 5th and last course which is the beef wrapped in Hawaiian Leaf and the special Beef Rice Soup. Prepare to get hands on as you wrap your own spring rolls. 

I was a complete newbie walking into this place but I quickly picked up the gist of it as I watched my experienced friends and the waiter explaining how to roll. I dipped my rice paper into the bowl of warm water and rotated it around quickly as I let the paper soak up all the water before placing it onto my plate. I ripped out a bunch of the various leafy vegetables and placed it on the edge of my rice paper before completing it with a beef sausage and then adding even some of the beef salad for the extra crunch. Wrapped it up like a burrito, dipped it into the sauces provided (a slightly chunky anchovy sauce with a sweet and tangy flavor). Count it as a success if you can get it from your plate to your mouth. Mission accomplished.

7 Course Beef of Deliciousness
1. Special beef salad (The appetizer that reminds me of a papaya salad. Gotta love that fish sauce)
2. Fondue with special vinegar sauce (Mini shabu shabu)
3. Steamed beef pate (Big tuna looking meatball. Comes with giant shrimp chips. I guess you don't have to roll this and just spoon the pate onto the shrimp chip and eat it like nachos)
4. Grilled beef sausage
5. Beef wrapped in Hawaiian leaf (Literally THE best sausage on the plate)
6. Grilled beef with lemon grass
7. Special beef rice soup (So flavorful and perfect end to the meal)
author: Diana C.

description: Awesome! The best spring roll experience ever! I recommend going and enjoying the amazing flavors they bring to the table! FIVE stars!
author: Karlos G.

description: Been coming here for over 25 years when it use to be $13 pp in 1992. Love the food.. can't get enough of it . Must try if you haven't. Food is Vietnamese French and they don't sell any pho soup. Just order their 7 course beef -min 2 order, sugar cane wrap shrimp paste , noodle plate- banh hoi and their grill giant shrimp.
author: Christy V.

description:
Seven Course Beef, a legendary experience.

Anh Hong is known for its seven course of beef. While there are other dishes here, like vermicelli or pho, it seemed like everyone in the restaurant knew that they wanted the seven course beef. And after trying the seven course beef, this would be the only thing I could ever get at Anh Hong.

Me and 3 other friends came in around 5:30, and was seated promptly. We were all eager to try the seven course beef, so we only ordered that and some drinks such as thai tea, yuja cha, and coconut milk.

Surprisingly, seven course beef isn't as meat heavy as one would expect. There is a large plate of carrots, cilantro, mint, radish, and lettuce. If you ever run out, you only need to ask the workers to receive more vegetables. The seven course beef also came with a lot of a lot of rice paper (which you dip into water to make it softer), and some fish sauce and anchovies sauce.

Moving onto the main attraction, the seven course beef.

The Seven course beef has:
Beef Salad,
beef fondue(beef hot pot),
3 types of beef sausages (with shrimp chips),
beef meatloaf,
and beef rice porridge(congee).

The beef salad was very good in my opinion. The beef salad has very strong mint taste. I thought it was going to be raw beef salad, but it was in fact a cooked beef salad. It was quite good, nothing mind blowing but it was a nice minty beef salad.
The beef fondue was just OK, but not as great as the salad. I personally thought the broth didn't have enough flavor, because when i cooked the beef in the fondue the fondue did not enhance the beef very much.
In my opinion, the main dish of the seven course beef is the giant platter of sausage and meatloaf, which has shrimp chips on top. This was definitely the best part of the seven course beef. Each sausage had a distinct taste, for example, one sausage had a thin slice of pork wrapped around it, another has a taro leaf wrapped around it, and the last one had a lemongrass taste. Each of these sausages were good by itself, but it really came alive when you wrapped a sausage with rice paper and put some vegetable with some fish/anchovy sauce on top.
The shrimp chips were fried well as well, so I enjoyed them very much.
The meatloaf was very fluffy, it almost tasted like meat flavored eggs. I personally didn't think the meatloaf was very good, but it added a different texture and taste.
The last dish was the rice porridge(congee) with beef. In my opinion, this had much to be desired. The congee was plain, and there was no beef taste. This congee might be a good cleansing dish, and that might have been the point. 

Overall, I would be very excited to recommend this to any group of two or more. This is a really fun experience. I think it is a little pricey and some of the dishes aren't very impressive, but the overall seven course beef experience is fun.
author: Anthony Y.

description:
After the rude and lack of service my family (table of 8) got tonight, we are never coming back. This was our fav place to go to for dinner and have been here at least 15 times. We loved this place cause their dishes tasted the closest to some of our favorite Vietnamese dishes. 

Our waiter was MIA the whole entire dinner except for the three times he was bringing our dishes out. And he'll quickly leave the moment he sets our dishes down. We never even got our water refilled. 

All of our orders except for the porridge are for wrapping. We only got three plates of veggies and pickled radishes to share between 8 people so of course we had to ask for more. And in the past, we've never had problem with that because they were always good at bringing out refills. I tried for a long time to get a waiters attention and got ignored the whole time. Had my hand up for while, I literally locked eyes twice with a waiter that was in front of me and both times he ignored me and walked away. Another time, we got one waiter's attention and he only came back with one plate of veggies but didn't refill the pickled radishes when the whole table was out. 

To top it off, they charged a mandatory 18% tip even though we received absolutely no service and were ignored the entire time.
author: Heidi V.

description:
My fam and I have came to Anh Hong when my sis and I were kids, thought it was really delicious. Had good memories here. Decided to go last night and well... here's my feedback of the experience:

Disclaimer: I generally don't like to give negative reviews but Anh, I was utterly disappointed my experience. 
(*-1) Especially concerning that as I was eating, I freaking pulled a steel wire string (from those steel scouring pads) out of my mouth! Why is this piece of metal in the meal??? When I showed the piece of scrap that was in my food to a lady that worked there, she apologized. 

(*-1) Then as the waiter was trying to put a plate down, we had to maneuver things around the round table but before the plate was given enough room. The waiter starts slowly putting down the plate, allowing it to push aside the surrounding plates. That's normal in family style Asian restaurants. What was NOT OK was that he did it without care and ended up pushing over a sauce plate, which spilled all over my grandpas lap!! Hardly apologetic, he didn't even get napkins or water for us to help clean up the spill without us having to request it!?! I'm glad it wasn't anything worse i.e. Boiling hot or would heavily stain that spilled..

The beef salad within one of the 7 courses, which felt more like a pork salad since the meat was pale, dry and tough. 

Otherwise, food tasted flavorful and good. It's just the incidents that occurred outweighed the delicious factor.
Had I already set shitty expectations of service/food safety, I probably would've recommended/come here willingly. However, now... I don't know :(
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Ever since my beloved Pagolac closed, I've been distraught over where I could get similar home-style Vietnamese food, a family-run place that proudly serves a seven flavors of beef. Pagolac was the restaurant I recommended when I was on "Check, Please! Bay Area" a few years ago when I managed to convince a young purse designer it was the bomb, while the Sonoma matron was not so much a fan. Well, Pagolac shuttered its door rather quietly in the last couple of years, and while Little Saigon offers several like-minded options, none really delivered the goods. I'm afraid I have to add Anh Hong to the ho-hum list.

I happen to catch the place when it wasn't very busy on a Tuesday evening, so I secured a table next to the window with ease. Forgoing my usual starter of Fresh Imperial Rolls (Goi Cuon), I started boldly with the $5.50 Special Seafood Soup (Soup Do Bien Dac Biet), which was a relatively clear broth served in a clear bowl with some squid slices mixed in to justify its seafood label (photo: http://bit.ly/1UHRAKr). There actually wasn't that much flavor to it, and in hindsight, I think I should have ordered something with explicit ingredients listed like same-priced Asparagus Soup with Crab Meat so that I know what I was getting.

For my entree, I ordered predictably and went with the $13.50 Combination Korean BBQ Rib and Grilled Sesame Chicken Dinner Plate (Com Dac Biet). It was definitely a generous amount of food but rather blandly presented with the riblets piled on the flattened chicken with little distinction in flavor. On the same plate was a Fried Egg Roll, a Fried Wonton, a scoop of white rice (as opposed to the fried rice mentioned in the menu), and a side salad with their house dressing (photo: http://bit.ly/1VoPcsE). It honestly reminded me of a school cafeteria meal where you were afraid to go up for seconds, so you decided to pile it high on your tray. Couple this with the indifferent service and I appear to be continuing my search for a Pagolac replacement.

FOOD - 3 stars...even if the food is good enough, it tastes a bit generic for Vietnamese food
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...pretty spacious
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...they appear to favor the big parties
TOTAL - 3 stars...Pagolac wannabe doesn't quite satisfy
author: Ed U.

description:
Bookmarked this place due to all the good reviews I read and it did not disappoint. I, like every one else and their mom in that place got their specialty of the bo 7 mon, which translates into 7 course beef, bc I mean, why wouldn't you if that's what they're restaurant is named after?! The beef dipped in vinegar was delish! Their sauce was on point! Only wish it was a little thicker to take more onto the rolls. Their beef salad, the sausages and steamed pate, and rice porridge were all tasty. The meal was definitely satisfying and enjoyed! 

One tip of advice for the restaurant - maybe not serve the diep ca (fish mint) to westerners? Or leave it on the side or be explained to them? Bc I'm Vietnamese so I know what is it and I, myself don't like the smell and can easily push it to the side. But others might not know, and be put off by the aroma and think it's the food or bad herbs or something.. better to either explain or leave off IMO.
author: Nhu P.

description:
7 course beef! Great service and awesome food. The portions are hearty and you will leave glistening with meat sweats and a full belly. They take reservations but when I came on a random weekday it was not full at all.

Not on the 7 course beef menu we ordered the grilled pork and carpaccio! Get those if you would like to lengthen your meal to 9 courses :)
author: Angela D.

description: My wife and her girlfriend brought us to this place.  I noticed that the ownership has changed and now Chinese operated.  The food was par and the service ok. I am Vietnamese and have tried many spots.  This location may have the Anh Hong name but not the quality or taste I was hoping to enjoy.  My opinion is this place is for rookie trying to wet their feet.  best to find another location outside SF if you prefer an advance taste of Vietnam.
author: Rich L.

description:
Came here for the 7 courses of beef. I never had it anywhere else. I thought they were going to serve me 7 different slices of beef for me to try. It is essentially seven difference styles of beef in different formations. This is  the place for the non-shrimp spring roll lovers! You can finally make the spring roll of your dreams without the shrimp. Also, you will probably not require another entree or appetizer. 

The door say "NO PHO." They do not serve pho unless you order it as a side dish, and even then, it's just a small portion.
author: Jess W.

description:
A lot of the complaints are about service...but I thought the service was better than most Vietnamese restaurants. Additionally you should never come to a Vietnamese or Chinese restaurant and expect good service or ambience...you come for the food. 

As for the food i did not think it was great. It was edible and there's a lot of it but I was not impressed. I liked the beef egg custard and one of the sausage selection but that's 2 out of 7 that I truly enjoyed...a 29% success rate. The worst was the final dish, the beef congee, it was super watery. I'm not even sure if there was any rice or beef in it. However for $25/person it's a good value.
author: Mai C.

description:
Found this place from doing some research online as I was craving the 7 course beef and Hawaiian leaf wrap meat. I believe this is the only place that serves this type of courses in the bay. It's not bad but being a so cal natives I've had better. The meatball stuffed with peanuts steamed was lacking flavor. The pineapple sauce was lacking flavor as well. Just my opinion in comparison to the places I've tried in so cal. But there are many options up here north for this type of dish so is the place to come if you want a 7 beef course meal.

The price was reasonable a 7 course meal costed $23.50 a person the portion were smaller but it'll fill you up.
author: Keniff K.

description: Please build your own spring rolls here. It was fun making the spring rolls and the choices of meats/seafood was absolutely delish!
author: Jenny C.

description: It taste decent, service not that attentive, pretty pricey. No music, you can hear what next table are talking about.
author: Qing L.

description:
7 courses of beef is legit. Great place for group dinners. Highly impressed with the service, the staff was cracking jokes but in a very unassuming way. They carefully rearranged dishes on our table to make room for more beef. After the salad and shabu, the next plate will contain courses 3-6, all delectable grilled beef variations.
Leave some room for the hot porridge palette cleanser at the end!
author: Gonzalo S.

description: Omg, My rice soup had cockroach  I ate almost half of it without paying any attention. After I put my phone down and sing off Facebook to focus on my meal. But nahhh I don't know did I eat cockroach too or not
author: TrAng H.

description:
This place always hits the spot. I always get the 7 course beef here. 

1st course - the beef papaya salad is good. It's not as vinegary as a thai payapa salad. 

2nd course - slices of beef cooked in broth. This is my least favorite course because the meat is very lean. 

3rd - 6th - these courses come out all together. There are 3 different types of beef rolls and 1 beef patty. Lovveeee all the beef rolls. They're my favorite part of the course. One roll is warpped with some sort of green vegeatble. Another kind of has the texture of a sausage. The last roll taste like it was wrapped with slices of lean beef. 

7th - beef porridge. Love the hot porridge at the end. It's the perfect way to finish off the meal.

Although I'm eating lots of beef, I still few very healthy after the meal becuase of all the vegertables I used in my wrap. Sometimes I don't even use the rice paper, I wrap the meat in lettuce.
author: Michelle T.

description: Probably the worst experience I've had in San Francisco so far! I'm a big foodie and eat out a lot. I love Vietnamese food and have dined out in many places in SF. I completely understand that even in the best restaurants things can go wrong but the service in this place was shocking and the food, quite frankly, awful! My husband was half way through his main course when I asked where my meal was as it seemed like it had been forgotten. I was advised that it was coming but received no apology or even acknowledgement for the delay. I was looking forward to my chow mein but when it eventually did arrive it tasted bland and the meat seemed off. I was very hungry so I had a few attempts but just couldn't force myself to eat it. There was no one around to give my feedback to and after it was clear my husband wasn't enjoying his either, I decided to just ask for the bill. The lady who seemed in charge passed by, I asked for the bill, she didn't acknowledge that I'd barely touched my meal, or even give me a chance to mention anything  as she walked away. When she brought the bill over i informed her that I didn't enjoy the meal and that it tasted strange. She said it was because it's a Vietnamese Chow mein and that it was supposed to be crunchy... I couldn't believe her response. How ridiculous!  I told her that I didn't mind the crunchiness but rather the off taste, and that in fact it was so bad I couldn't eat it. She just said ok and walked away. I'm still shocked as I have never experienced such poor service. Maybe I was unlucky but I thought I'd share my experience to warn anybody who doesn't want their meal to be ruined by horrendous service and awful food.
author: Dorota C.

description: Stars undertermined for this new location! Excited for Anh Hong opening soon across from Cam Houng!! Can't wait!!
author: Only1 C.

description: This place is legit Vietnamese food. If you've been to Vietnam, you will love the familiar sights, smells, and tastes. Very diverse menu and none of the Americanized dishes from your typical Vietnamese place. Highly recommend the house egg rolls and the ba la lot (double stack them in rice paper, herbs, etc). But you really can't go wrong here. Great for big groups. Crowded, fun, and amazing food. Also loved the Vietnamese coffee...the iced and hot.
author: dan s.

description:
#11 and #16 on top of the seven course beef = winning (for a party of 4)

LOVED my experience here! The food was delicious - it was nice to venture out of the pho zone - and our server was quite the character. He briskly suggested we venture out of the typical seven course beef and try the beef carpaccio and the shrimp paste wraps, which were huge hits. So glad he didn't let us order four servings of the beef special as that would have been way too much food. My group had a lot of fun making our own rolls and would highly recommend this  to anyone visiting SF!
author: Maggie H.

description:
The door to Anh Hong says in red letters:  NO PHO

If I didn't know better, I would be devastated.  But as the restaurant signage proudly says: Seven Course Beef - and that is exactly what we came for.  The restaurant is no frill, typical Vietnamese/Asian setting.  The service is quick and to the point.  Not much wait on a week night.  Although the food did take a little longer on a busier night.

We ordered the Rare Steak with Lemon appetizer and it was my favorite dish of the night (lemon juice + fish sauce).  The rare steak is buttery and ultra thin sliced.  They garnish the dish with bean sprouts and fried onions.  I like the different textures you taste in this dish.  The seven course beef starts with the typical beef salad, followed by beef in vinegar broth (also another winner of the night).  It goes on with beef rolls and ends with beef porridge.  I don't want to ruin the fun for you if you have never had the seven course beef, but it's a feast you can dig.  To make ourselves incredibly stuffed, we also got the squid and prawn (fresh!) dish cooked on a skillet.

The only tip I have to offer is you can order just a 1-person serving portion for the Seven Course Beef and add additional dishes on top.
author: Carrie L.

description:
Delicious, large, hole-in-the wall that is famous for its bò 7 món.

There's no reason to order anything else. Do it.
author: Sean B.

description:
Do you like beef? 
Are you hungry?

If your answer is "yes" to both questions then you are in the right place. The 7 course beef is why you're here versus any other Vietnamese restaurant in the surrounding area. No regrets if your mission is to eat as much beef as you can. Delicious, tasty and great service. The meal even comes with enough greens so you can pretend you had a very well-balanced meal.
author: Tiffany L.

description: The Vietnamese cuisine here is stellar. It is a very cozy and family owned restaurant that serves excellent food. Very delicious great for families to get together and have a good time. They even renovated some of the place and I appreciate the effort.
author: Abigail S.

description: LONG LINE like 1 hour when we went. The food is great here and so much easier to get here vs driving all the way to Berkeley. They have tables for large groups too as there was a huge dinner party the night we went. I would do the 7 courses of beef but I wasn't THAT hungry. We got a hotpot (great and would recommend again with the crispy rice and seafood). Beef wraps and chicken wrap and also appetizers. We the papaya beef salad appetizer and also spring roles. This was great. I can't wait to go back.
author: Lily P.

description: Consistency is key , been here for the longest time  the first time and today seem like nothing has changed.  Love  this place.
author: christian l.

description:
12.05.15

Belated birthday celebration with a group, and I had a random hankering for seven courses of beef. We haven't been to Anh Hong in years, but great to know that it's been such a staple and still as delicious as the last visit.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anh-hong-restaurant-san-francisco?select=gjVVRrfn8mHLRJ-zN-AkoA

Like.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Great spot for Bo 7 Mon (7 courses of beef) in SF! You get a lot of tasty food for your money, and if you're unfamiliar with the menu don't be shy about asking about dishes that other tables around you may be ordering - last time we came, a table (owner's family I believe) had a large plate of beautiful, huge spot prawns that weren't on the menu. We asked about it and out came some super sweet, delicious prawns!

Like any legit Asian restaurant, service gets spotty when this place gets busy but the staff tries to stay on top of things, so just keep your hand raised if you need something.

Random note: the waiter (older guy who never seems to smile) never fails to entertain me! He looks grumpy but usually banters (more like quick 1-to-few liners) good-naturedly with me or my father-in-law in Cantonese.
author: Steve L.

description:
Regardless of service here, the food was pretty filling.

"7 course beef"

We started eating daikon salad first.

Surprisingly, we had rice spring roll wraps to eat with it. It came with lots of meats and at the end, they gave us porridge! Service is okay, but regardless they came through. 

Will come back!
author: Ritney N.

description:
Sketchy neighborhood, but that's just the Tenderloin for you!

We ordered the seven course beef meal for $20.99 each for a party of three. For a meal in SF, this wasn't too expensive. Well, not for the amount of food you get! This is a DO-IT-YOURSELF option, so be warned! I definitely had fun making my rolls with my friends! 

Unlimited veggies? Check. Water cups refilled? Check. Typical bad service for an Asian restaurant? Check. But hey, at least one of our servers was super funny! I thoroughly enjoyed it - lol.

Dish #1: Interesting. The salad was good and flavorful.
Dish #2: Beef in Fondue.
Dish #3-6: I don't remember the names, but I particularly liked one of them. I wasn't a fan of the fish cake, which was very bland. I was fairly disappointed since I typically love fish cake.
Dish #7: Forgettable. Not flavorful. Tasteless. Flavored porridge was poorly done.

The veggies were hit and miss. Some of them were old. Some were fresh, but they were definitely not consistent. It was hit and miss. The fish sauce was good. I didn't like the shrimp paste too much though. 

I usually make shrimp rolls at home and preparing all the ingredients can be a tremendous hassle --- not to mention how much time it takes. If the opportunity comes again and if I'm lazy, I wouldn't mind shelling out the few extra bucks to come here again.
author: Chinsin S.

description: I use to love this place so much! But tonight was a real disappointment. I notice the guys that usually work there no longer works there ... and now they have a woman and another new guy, both have lousy memory. I have to ask them multiple times for things ... refilling water, getting more veggies, getting more rice paper, etc. And it took almost 30 minutes to get our porridge, the last part of the 7 course beef. And we specially said we don't want green onions in it to the waitress and she told the manager and the manager did not hear or something and it came with green onions. I am use to going to places with not the most supreme service so I thought, fine, I won't deduct stars for those things. BUT the dishes was also a disappointment tonight. The salad was kind of bitter than usual. The beef carpaccio looked messy and didn't even taste that fresh. The beef with the hot pot also wasn't up to standards either. They were clearly also rushing people out as quickly as they could since there was a line. I miss the old staff. But I am starting to wonder if they changed people in the kitchen as well.
author: Gerry P.

description:
This place is seriously the best place to get your vietnamese 7 courses of beef. I have literally been eating at this establishment since I was 1. Thats 27 years of deliciousness and Im still amazed that a lot of people (my friends included) have never had 7 courses of beef, let alone Anh Hong. I have to constantly bring countless people here and explain to them that there is more to Vietnamese cuisine than Pho, rice plates, and bahn mi. No biggie, more opportunities for me to get my fix.

Must gets here that are not on the 7 courses of beef: 
Eggrolls, beef carpaccio, sugar cane shrimp

Best courses in the 7 courses? 
The sausages , ones with the leaf and ones without. Unfortunately i dont know the legit english names, and if i tried to spell it out in vietnamese id probably fail. I can say it, and it gets the job done.

Also dont be afraid to try the drinks. Salted plum soda, preserved lemon soda sounds weird but its good and refreshing... especially after all the fish sauce.

The waiters are friendly and accomodating. It does get busy here so dont expect 5 star fancy pants lemme refill your sparkling water service. Parking is also a nightmare, but this place is worth it.
author: Carmen L.

description: Unfortunately food was mediocre and a cockroach was climbing up the wall.   We won't be back.
author: N S.

description: It's not the first time I've been here but this time is so terrible. I came in and wrote name down then waited for 15 minutes but nobody came to check even have free tables. I had to ask for the table. . So none of word can describe the service. No one cares about us. We ate for the 2nd course of beef and they said they hadn't had enough meat to do the next one, so we had to wait 30 minutes while eating ( can't believe how the big restaurant with 4 stars on Yelp can do that).
author: Vi H.

description:
OVERALL  -  4/5
--------------

FOOD  -  4.5/5
1) 7 Course Beef  -  4.5/5
Note:  with the 7 course beef you get to wrap the various beef in rice paper with different vegetables then dip it, so good!

SERVICE  -  4/5

CLEANLINESS  -  3/5

LOCATION  -  3.5/5

EXPERIENCE  -5/5

---------------------
Wait time:  5-8 minutes (dinner, holiday)
author: John V.

description:
The seven course beef is a should try! Not only it's good, but also the portion is very decent for one person!
First time, I ordered to go. The guy was really nice giving me recommendations for what I should get in order to get the largest portion of meat without having to pay extra.
The second time here, we ate there and the lady was extremely nice. She was super friendly and attentive. However, there's this other guy who was slightly rude and he totally ignored us and rushed away when he clearly saw me waving my whole body at him. Other than that, everything else was such a blessing.
We also tried BBQ pork with rice cake and it was literally wrapped in 3 words "to die for". 
We left with a bit of a slight damage for my bank account but more importantly, happy tummies.
author: Vi B.

description:
7 course beef and an order of their eggrolls and you're good to go!

This place is located in SF so parking is all street and sometimes it can be difficult to find parking depending on what time you come on what day. The worst that ever happened to me was having to circle the block once around so.. cool. 

The size of this restaurant is pretty decent size and they have a bunch of small tables with about maybe 3-4 big tables. The service here is also very nice. I made a reservation for Sunday night around 6:30pm and when we got there it was exactly 6:30pm. The boss was sitting at a table eating and he quickly finished to let us sit down. 

You don't really have to speak Vietnamese to be here. Some of the workers speak Cantonese and a little of English, too. I guess it's just a matter of who you get. 

Overall, YUM. The 7 course beef is enough to get you hella full and their eggrolls are the best ones I've had so far. Nothing can beat them. Nope. If you tell me there's somewhere else that can top this, I will not believe you. That is how awesome this place is.
author: Venus L.

description:
I'm from Silicon Valley and part Vietnamese, and there is one other place that we like to go to for Bo 7 mon. If I had to compare it, I would say that Anh Hong beats it by far! At 6 pm on Friday, the restaurant wasn't crowded, and we were seated RIGHT away. By 8 PM, the restaurant was packed! 

The food was really good. They are NOT stingy on the vegetables for the rolls like most restaurants are!  They REFILL the HOT WATER without asking. The beef rolls were REALLY easy to eat and packed with flavor! THIS was the thing that hooked me BECAUSE in other places I've eaten, the beef rolls would be too tough. 

If you've never had a 7 meat meal course, the restaurant staff are very happy to share their culture with you and TEACH you how to make one. I thought that was a bonus. We had a party of 3 (3 females, none overweight) and I think 2 orders of the 7 meat meal course would've been enough for all of us because we had leftovers!

I also want to add that their cha gio (egg rolls) are delish and are nicely wrapped. Their rare beef appetizer was really good and tasted so healthy! I had no stomach ache!

There are bathrooms here but for customers and they can split the check onto two credit cards. We took Uber here since parking in the tenderloin area (or any part of SF) is a mess!
author: Justina L.

description:
7 course beef dishes for the win! 

What consists of this feastful 7 dishes - cold beef salad, rare beef steak with hot boiling soup, 3 types of grilled sausages (my favorite was the simple beef with no wrapping of leaf or scallion stuffing), a scoop of this tasty meatball that was served with the sausages, vegetable plate that includes pickled carrots, daikon, mint, basil, beansprouts and lettuce and last, but not least, the hot beef porridge as dessert.  

That porridge should have been served as a soup, in my opinion, at the beginning to warm the soul up!  I recommend watching a YouTube video on how to roll up a spring roll, before ordering up the 7 course because it requires that skill to combine and eat the courses properly!  They provide fish sauce, anchovy sauce and hot sauce for the dishes - my favorite dipping sauce was the anchovy sauce.  

This grand meal can surely feed 3 people!

The service was lacking, otherwise, this place would have earned its 5 stars.  I had to repeat myself 2 times each for being ready to order and requesting for my cups of tea.  It was busy after 7:30pm on a Sunday night, but that doesn't excuse ignoring me 2 times each!  That made it 4 times of avoiding me.

I like how the 38 Geary bus drops you off literally right in front of this restaurant.  It was so convenient - like valet drop off more or less, but for public transportation.  

Don't expect grand decor.  Their other dishes are mediocre - you can find elsewhere.  As a heads up for a Vietnamese restaurant, they do not have Pho here!

The 7 course meal was fitful for a buffet!  For $20.95 per person, it was definitely worth the variety, delicious concept and tastiness.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
We got the 7 course beef. Service is friendly albeit some of the servers don't speak English so we had language issues sometimes.

The course is really just four courses, because four of the "courses" come out on the same platter.

The extras (lettuce, daikon, carrots, etc.) were fresh and plentiful.

First course needed more lemon and salt--the sugary-ness was just a tad too much.

Second course was fine, though we cooked the meat for a bit too long and ducked it up.

The third course is where it gets really real. This is where Anh Hong shines. Everything was delicious and plentiful. This is where they take out a giant plate of four different kinds of beef sausage/meatball things and you just get to go crazy.

We also ordered a side of bun (noodles) to put in the wraps, which I highly recommend.

The fourth course was the worst. The rice porridge was the most forgettable course, half assed so they could call it 7. Pro-tip is to ask them if you can skip the last course and instead get more meat in the third course.

Dessert was average. I got the 3 layer dessert thing. They served it in the beginning, for some odd reason, and I had to tell them that I wanted it at the end.
author: Yan F.

description: This place is excellent.  I had their specialty, the seven courses of beef.  Each plate was delicious. The slices of beef were tender; the beef rolls were so moist and perfectly seasoned; beef wrapped in grape leaf was nicely grilled. The fish sauce was also perfect. There was so much food for one order.  At 17.95 a person, the meal was a real bargain.  Definitely recommended for large groups, vietnamese food lovers, and all true foodies.
author: Jewels V.

description: Must get the 7 course meal! I know nothing about Vietnamese food other than the traditional white girl order of pho and imperial rolls. This place does not have pho but they do have the 7 course meal for 25$ which comes with a whole bunch of stuff I'm not really sure what it is but my Vietnamese friend recommended it and I could eat there every day. You leave stuffed but all the ingredients are so light and fresh you don't feel like an a**hole after eating it all.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Our group had an authentic Vietnamese feast here, and it was amazing.  Every mouthful of food had a crazy explosion of flavor.  Also, the portions are generous, bowls of fresh, raw veggies accompany your dishes.  And, although I did not make my own spring rolls, it looks like other people enjoyed making theirs.           

Their flavor profile rivaled that of a high-end, $$$$ restaurant.  The best Vietnamese dining experience I ever had.
author: Dana C.

description: Absolutely horrible. I don't like to leave bad reviews but this place service was bad and food quality, I don't know how you can call it beef? 7 course of beef is hardly beef prices at $23, you get 4 types of weird funky hard over cooked and strange concoction of sausages. You get a weak salad tastes blah. And some soupy thing w beef in it but it looks fake. Close to he rare thin slices you get in pho but it's redder and no marble. That's it folks. And some porridge at the end looked like crap. Rip off when you actually get crap
author: Jennie D.

description:
Great food, great service, I love Vietnamese food and spring rolls are one of my faves but my husband is not a fan, now when I crave Vietnamese we can come here! He thoroughly enjoyed everything we tried!!!

His favorites were the beef carpaccio, the beef sausages, the eggrolls and the congee, he loved the congee!
author: Mijin J.

description:
Come here with the family for father's day. It was pretty busy by the time we came to the restaurant and this place is small so it can pack fast. This place is known for 7 beef course. It costs $21.95 per person for the 7 beef course. Its quite pricy but the food can get you full. This 7 beef course consists of beef salad, beef fondue, steamed beef pate, grilled beef sausage, beef wrapped in Hawaiian(lot) leaf, grilled beef with lemon grass, and ended with beef rice porridge soup. They also give you rice paper and vegetables so you can make spring roll from all meats they give you. Also they provide sauces as well so your created spring roll can have some flavors. 

Service was slow even after couple of big group of family left the restaurant. Took them a while for them to bring out the food especially the grilled beef/pate and wrapped beef...that took the longest that we had to wait about 10 - 15 minutes to come out. It wasn't fun waiting for our food when we were hungry...food here are average. Its a good place to come with family or group of your friends
author: Julie N.

description: The lady who took the order is really nice and taught us how to prepare the wrap of 7 courses of meat. Food is delicious and price is reasonable. Always cannot finish the whole dinner at once.
author: Sanguan L.

description: Love this BBM place! Me and my family come here very often the food is great. Owner and staff are super friendly and always getting us what we need. Yummy!
author: Michele T.

description: If you looked at the pictures below you can see how great the food looks but it tastes just as good. The raw beef salad was excellent best I've ever had any where and the wrapping of rolls makes dining casual and fun. One of the best Vietnamese restaurants in the city.
author: N A.

description:
Of all the places I've tried, this is probably my favorite 7 course beef course:

Course 1: beef salad
Course 2: raw beef to be cooked in a hot pot and wrapped in your own rice paper
Course 3-5: different types of grilled beef to be wrapped in rice paper
Course 6: beef meatball
Course 7: beef porridge to finish off

One order can feed 2-3 people. We also like to order the beef carpaccio 

Great for groups and family.
author: Joanne K.

description: Wonderful service! Man the 7 course meat so yummy, pace yourself for the sausages!!! All stellar I can't even describe how good the meat was...that soup!!!! It'll blow your mind. Thank you.
author: Attic F.

description: I've been going here since I was about three or four and now I am 20 years old. This place is authentic and very good. I usually come here for birthdays, celebrations, and take out of towners here. Located near the TL , the restauraunt has a nice interior and a 1000000+ year old fish tank. The fish tank is ancient and has a lot of history to it. Make sure you wear clothes that you don't want to stink up because trust me you will smell. Its not a bad smelll sort of like bbq when u are bbqing or fire x wood when you have a bonfire. An A1 quality place and always always always get some porridge at the end and top it off with some neopolitan ice cream. This place has so many memories from our family gatherings and meals. A fond memory I have is of my cousins and I collecting our sugar canes from the shrimp and seeing who has more. This place is a family owned restaurant and has a homey like feel. The family works hard to have a good operation.  A must try!!!!
author: Brian C.

description: I've been a regular to this restaurant for nearly 25 years.  Despite the less than desirable location, the food keeps me coming back always.  Truly some of the best Vietnamese food on the planet.  This would be my last meal if knew I were going to die!!!  Carnivore heaven.
author: Mary F.

description:
When someone tells you they're going to bring you to get a "7 course beef meal", you would never imagine it to be at a Vietnamese restaurant. Was I disappointed? Absolutely not! 

But first things first, our meal was 100% entertaining. The owner (?), the man with the awesome sideburns, was hilarious. He bickered with a friend throughout our meal. To be fair, our friend did not know the basics of rolling a spring roll. Mr. Sideburns even provided us a table side demo to the art of spring rolling; basically unheard of at any Asian restaurant. In the end, we were absolutely thankful for his participation to a very interesting and entertaining meal! 

Now, back to the food. As a group of 12, we ordered 10 sets of the 7 course beef set and there was still too much food leftover!

1. Cold beef salad. 
I liked it! It was very refreshing and had the perfect tang.

2. Beef Shabu. 
Interesting, probably my least favorite. The fire for the shabu was too mild and the broth was a bit too adventurous for me. 

3. Plate of 3 different beef rolls and 1 type of meatball. 
Seriously, the best part of the meal. The three different types of grilled beef rolls were divine! Everyone's taste buds were dancing for the beef rolls wrapped in Hawaiian leaf and the grilled beef sausage. The rolls with the onions were the least desirable, they were too mediocre and had no oomph to keep us yearning for more.

Note: Please eat the meatball with the shrimp chips! My friend made a mistake and ate it with a beef roll. Mr. Sideburns was not impressed, haha. 

4. Beef Porridge
A surprisingly light porridge! A great way to end a protein filled meal.

Overall, a great meal with friends! You get to bond and laugh at all the ugly and pretty rolls that eventually end up in your stomach. I definitely recommend Anh Hong for those who are feeling adventurous! 

P.S. Street parking is extremely difficult on a Saturday night.
author: Winnie I.

description:
This was my first time trying the Seven Courses of Beef (dun dun dun!). The first thing I noticed was how busy this place was, which is typically a good indicator that the food is good. During our meal, the manager was attentive and answered any questions we had about the food. And, of course, the food was delicious. So what is the Seven Courses of Beef, you ask? 

1. Beef salad
2. Thinly sliced raw beef that you add to hot broth to cook
3. Grilled beef wrapped in a Hawaiian leaf
4. Grilled beef rolls with onions and lemongrass 
5. Grilled beef sausage
6. Steamed beef meatballs
7. Rice porridge with beef and peanuts and ginger

With the meat, you are given uncooked rice wraps, a bowl of hot water to soften the rice wraps, and a plate with pickled vegetables and bean sprouts. With it, you get to make your own spring rolls, so make sure to wash your hands!

I am so glad I got to try this. Thanks again for the recommendation, fellow friend!
author: Nina Z.

description:
It was my first time here and totally impressive with taste and service. 
The owner was so nice. She even demonstrated how to wrap and dip and everything which was honestly i'm really appreciated :)  
They would give you big basket of vegetable and rice paper(am i right?) with any main dishes.
author: Panchaya S.

description: Yummy authentic Vietnamese food. Seven course beef is a must try. No pho here. They ran out of few dishes we ordered which sucks otherwise I would have given this place a four stars. I heard there are other locations too as well in berkleys etc. Waiters here speaks viet. Be sure to bring someone who knows what to eat and to order when you go.
author: Weiming L.

description: Being Vietnamese and loving the 7 course beef cuisine, it was just amazing to find this restaurant and it is so delicious here!!!! It's always crowded with other Asians whenever I'm there, which is a tell tale sign that its authenticity is well worth the trip. I order it To go sometimes and it's only 15 minutes wait. Absolutely delicious!!!!
author: CHristine J.

description:
I would give them another half star if I could. This is one of my favorite places in SF to take friends when I honestly do not have the energy to wash all those greens and slice all those vegetables myself. It's pretty close to what a slightly special, family-style meal would be like in South Viet Nam. If you come on the early side, you won't have to wait. Just be aware you'll be sharing the dining room with grandmas and grandkids celebrating somebody's birthday or the other.

On good days, the servers are like your youngest uncles who good-naturedly bear with you and your silly special requests. But they can also be more like your older, grumpy, great-uncles who, nonetheless, bring you extra herbs and refill your pickle plates endlessly. For Southerners like me who live in a neighborhood where people assume that VN folks eat only pho and banh mi, this place is a godsend.

Seven courses of beef has always been too much for me, so if I'm feeling like having red meat, I usually just order 3 dishes a la carte. My favorites: the beef rolled with la lot leaves, the beef that you dip into vinegar broth at the table, and the rice and beef soup (which is best at the end of the meal, as a finisher). Often, though, I just stick to seafood, such as the shrimp on sugar cane followed by the assorted seafood grill plate.

I love, love, love how much fresh greens they give you. It's piled up high just like my own family does. They also offer the traditional anchovy-pineapple sauce that goes so well with beef. 

There was one day when they didn't have the full complement of the usual herbs, just cilantro and mint. I asked about it (fearing that they'd switched over to the minimalist plate that most other VN restaurants in the US offer). The owner came by and apologized, saying they usually do have the fish mint and the sawtooth herb, the red perilla and the rau ram...just not that day. Whew! Worries averted.

Secret: Order a beer and tip some of it into the vinegar broth for the dipped beef. Mmmm.
author: Thy T.

description:
Been coming to this place for many years. The food is decent but the service seems to be somewhat below standard. Never knew why and always wondered why the owner of the establishment doesn't train their servers to have better customer service skill....UNTIL recently found out why all the servers that work there provided shitty service. It's not that they don't know how to service the customers, it's the fact that they're not happy with their job because the owner pocketed all the tips that customers leave for the service provided by the servers....Shame on you Mr., this people work hard for you and they have family to care for. Have a heart and take care of your employees. 

3 stars for the food
0 star for ownership
author: Danny N.

description: First time going to a make your own spring rolls place in SF! I'm just too in love with the one in Sac lol. Anyways my bf took me here on a Wednesday night. The restaurant wasn't busy and we got seated right away. The inside of the restaurant isn't as clean tbh. The fish tank looked dirty lol. My bf told me he saw cockroach before...luckily I didn't see one bc I would have left lol. We ordered the carpaccio, shrimp salad and the spring rolls with sugar cane wrapped with shrimp cake. They were all very tasty but honestly it could be better. Maybe I had too high of an expectations bc the spring roll place in Sac is hella good. The waiter was cool and came by to pick up dishes. The food was good but I think I'd prefer the pork inside my spring rolls lol tbh. The shrimp cake was good but I think it tastes better by itself. It's just my opinion. Our bill was about $60 or so for the 4 dishes. It was filling. This place is in tenderloin so be careful with your surroundings and your car. Lock all doors and hide nice things lol. I'll be back again sometime.
author: Monica W.

description:
I HAD to write a review for this place.

We came here expecting pho and were pleasantly disappointed. The Owner there, Sharmain (hope I get that right) provided THE BEST service you could ever ask for. When asked to explain her favorites she went above and beyond explaining the menu and what she recommended for us to order. We ordered the 7 course beef menu which was SO MUCH FOOD and the bbq chicken (smokey goodness). Everything was delicious. Fresh, sweet, savory, soulful, homey.. a true dance on the palette. She even came back over EVERY COURSE to explain what the dish was and how to prepare it. It felt like I was in a cooking class. She changed out our plates multiple times to provide us clean surfaces to wrap our rolls, and attentively came over to replenish our drinking water and hot water (used to prepare the rice paper). The whole experience could have easily been way more in price for how great the restaurant felt. I've been to Michelin star restaurants that didn't feel as wholesome of an experience. 

I will come back here many times with my friends and family. Thanks for such a wonderful experience and for keeping my keys safe for me. :p
author: Louis P.

description:
Beef seven ways is no joke, so you and your stomach should prepare for some serious business when coming here.

My friends and I arrived on a Sunday night for an early dinner, so we had no problem getting seated. By the time we left, the restaurant was packed and there were some people waiting to be seated. Between the 9 of us (7 of which were guys) we ordered 5 orders of the beef seven ways. At first the server told us that it would not be enough, but by the time we got through all 7 styles of beef, I felt like I was going to explode. I had never heard of beef seven ways before, and I am a total novice when it comes to wrapping spring rolls, but at the end of the meal I became a lean, mean, spring roll rolling machine. This is definitely worth a try if you're in the area, but come hungry!
author: Ada C.

description: Best place to get Bo 7 Mon in SF. I can't wait for the next time I visit home to get this! You can't fine Vietnamese food like in California in Hawaii! Definitely missing this place.
author: N A.

description: Bo 7 mon (beef 7 ways) is definitely a must get here. My bf and I came here because of the good reviews and it didn't disappoint. Very good service -- super quick and friendly. My favorite out of the 7 beef varieties were #4-7. Their beef wrapped in Hawaiian lot leaf along with that INCREDIBLY YUMMY dipping sauce still has my mouth watering. I may just come back for that alone. Also, very simple, but I like their porridge/rice soup too. The flavor was good. Overall, not the nicest looking exterior, but hey, the inside was clean and I had a good experience.. So pretty much, I WILL BE BAAAACK :)
author: Jenn N.

description:
We've been coming here for over 25 years and the food has always been deliciously consistent.

Sugar cane shrimp is a must! Seriously.
author: Julie L.

description:
I love organizing dinners/happy hour/no reason for get togethers because I figure, if I don't then who will? 

Just mention Anh Hong on an invite to a group of yelpers, expect a lot of "I'm there!"

Then tell them, corkage is only $7 and Peter L's bringing booze! I guarantee, this is one dinner where everyone will be on time!

The 7 courses include a beef salad, beef carpaccio, grilled beef wrapped in lot leaf, grilled meatballs and beef in lemongrass, sausages and beef porridge.  We also ordered charbroiled shrimp served on sugar cane, very cute presentation!  

This is a very interactive dinner, both with your friends and your food.  If you're the type who can't keep still, no problem, because your hands will be busy: rolling, wrapping, drinking, grilling, boiling, drinking, assembling, drinking.  You're brain will be busy thinking, "wonder if I should skimp on the lettuce to have more pickled carrots? (Yes)  should I put more meat in here? (Yes) is this fish sauce better than that shrimp paste? (Nope) "   I need more wine please! (hell YES!)

Anh Hong is a casual place that's great for big groups where you can easily feel relaxed, have loud conversations with your friends and stuff your face with all the delicious beef you can handle. Holy C-O-W! (pun intended!) where else can you do that for only $20.95 per person?!?
author: Janice C.

description:
So, I came with Alice L a few weeks ago, and we didn't do the 7 course beef that everyone else did, because, well, we eat like waify little people. Instead, we ordered their:

* Shrimp Wrapped Sugar Canes - The flavors of this dish were fantastic, the shrimp balls pairing wonderfully with the cooked sugar canes. As a pro-tip, apparently each ball and the sugar cane it wraps is actually pre-cut down the middle already, so, don't do what we did and eat them one ball per wrap!

* Hawaiian Leaf Wrapped Beef - While the smell of this dish (from the leaves themselves, I think) were a tad on the offensive side, the flavors themselves were quite tasty: much in the same way that stinky tofu smells terrible, but is also delicious. Not quite as good as the shrimp and sugar canes, but also worth trying.

Both of these come with sides of two sauces (a plain fish sauce, and another fish sauce mixed with several others), large lettuce leaves, and a stack of rice paper wraps that you're supposed to wet in the bowl of water. Basically, all of the aforementioned make Anh Hong a DIY spring roll joint. And let me (us) tell you this: if you've never tried making spring rolls before, you'll develop a whole new appreciation for people who do, as you fail time and time again to make a proper one!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A large, spacious restaurant, mostly filled with larger tables. Accessibility shouldn't really be an issue.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I ate here for the first time on the weekend from a recommendation from my nail salon (they're Vietnamese of course so they definitely know the best Vietnamese places to eat). Let's just say they were right, but don't expect bells and whistles. You're down to eat here! Their specialty of the 7 course beef is fabulous, the fondue beef is fabulous and finishing with beef congee, they sure have the flavoring right! 
They replenish your greens, sprouts and herbs plates as required. The key ingredient to these meals are fish sauce and they make good fish sauce however it does smell the place up so if you're ok with that, then you'll love it. 
I loved it and will definitely come back!
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
An order of the 7-courses of beef serves two people is a good bet, as one order is just too much food for one person. Use that as a guide so you will not be stuffed, and then can also order side dishes and/or appetizers - imperial rolls and carpaccio are justifiably popular.

They carry wines and beers but corkage fee is only $7, for any bottle you bring in - even the harder stuffs. However, I normally have beers when eating this.

To me this venue feels more noodle-house than a nice sit-down restaurant but I'm there for the food (the one in San Jose - in the profile pic, lol - is nicer). And, like JasonG said, mention he (or Yelp) sent you but don't be all demanding, lol. Kent is a friendly host and the servers do their best since most visitors are group diners - the ideal way to enjoy it!
author: Peter L.

description: Loved this place.  Is family owned since the 1980's by a family from Saigon. We were novices with Vietnamese food and this Is very authentic.  The owner's daughter-in-law, who was managing at the time, and was so incredibly helpful with guiding us on what to order and how to eat it!  The food tasted incredible. What a treat it was for us!  Don't pass this place up!
author: Gina Morra S.

description:
We have been wanting to eat here forever but they are only open for dinner. I usually like to eat Vietnamese for lunch.. I guess because it's so light and healthy.
