So for dinner we opted for the 7 courses of beef (Bo 7 Mon). The place was packed with only Asians (I'm assuming they were Vietnamese), so that is a good sign.

For 2 people this was definitely a feast (about $22 per person). It may even have been too much. But no matter, we are professional eaters so we ate everything LOL. Even though we were stuffed, it still has that light feeling you associate with Vietnamese food. I know 7 types of beef sounds like overkill but it's really not.

It was so good! First dish is salad.. yum! Just hint of beef, with papaya I believe. Second was fondue. You dump slices of beef in the fondue and make your own "egg" roll. It's actually rice paper you dump in water and it turns soft. So much fun! Then you get one big plate with 4 different beef: meatball, 2 types of sausages (they are a little sweet), and beef roll. You can also make "egg rolls" with these. You have carrots, cucumber, lettuce, basil, etc to stuff it with also. Last course is soup.. rice and beef. Very good! Overall we really enjoyed the experience and also the food! This is perfect for groups of people. You may want to reserve on the weekends if so because they get very packed. Winner!

As for the neighborhood it's on Geary which is full of restaurants, bars, shops, etc. It's technically Lower Nob Hill but also borders Tenderloin. I live just a block and suburbanites may be a little scared but to the rest, it's quite fine.
author: Vol T.

description:
First time I had this place was when my dad's cousin who grew up in Vietnam took me there. He said it's hard to find this kind of Vietnamese food in bay area. I could say it's one of the best place I've ever had. 

You gotta order the 7 beef course meal. And the rare beef with lemon juice if you can eat raw meat. It's the best. If you go when there's not many customers, the staffs might be picky on how u eat the food, but trust me they know it best. They just want you to eat the way it should be eaten.
author: Nuntanat R.

description: Not your typical pho place, in fact they have none. If you come here for their rice plates or noodles, you will be disappointed. Their specialty is their seven course beef which is pretty good; you do get a decent amount of food. Their drinks are ok, so I would just stick with regular hot tea.
author: Eric T.

description:
Service: UTTERLY shit. My friends and I literally waited 30-45 mins to get seated when there were empty tables around the WHOLE time. The servers just didn't feel like cleaning. This cannot be emphasized more!

OK. Whatever, the food comes.
I order 7 course beef, my friends order the rice plate.

I get the salad first, great! Tasted superb! OK, feeling excited for what is about to come. The steam beef comes (2 slices) had literally no taste, looks like some poverty beef you buy from a discounted Ranch 99 (serious). Then comes the sausage links plate. This was awesome at the time, quite a bit of food as compared to 2 pieces of sad beef previous. I eat it, took another 25 mins to get 'Beef Rice Soup', or 'congee'. 

Like other goers have said, this is MILDLY better than the sausage plate (IMHO) 
So, for those of you reading still; salad, steamed, sausage, and soup/congee...there should be more coming right? Nah. Sausage plate counted as multiples. 

Overall, the food here was above average; however it was not enough to cover my disdain for the shitty service. So bad that I actually went out of my way to create a Yelp account just so I can neg it.

Rest assured, I will NOT be coming back anytime soon.
author: Robin T.

description:
I come here every few years because:
-sketchy neighborhood 
- I fall into a food coma after 
-natzi like waiter

Everything here is tasty and flavorful.  My favorite has to be the sugarcane shrimp wrap, beef, and the Vietnamese porridge.

Remember, starve yourself before you have dinner here. I made the mistake of going to Zazie for a late lunch and happy hour for appetizers and wine.  I wasn't able to enjoy the whole meal at Anh Hong. But again, starve yourself before eating here.
author: Angelica C.

description:
I've come here many times with my family and this last time was for Thanksgiving. Hey-- no one eats turkey at home and we just had steak the other day. So we had 3 sets of bo 7 mon amonst the 4 of us, adding 2 orders of banh hoi. And 3 sets are always enough for all of us.. It's a lot of food. But if you're a couple.. go with 2 sets.
I love wrapping up my own rolls; it's hands on and you can spend time with your family and talk while you're building your perfect roll (like making fun of your dad's burrito-like roll where everything falls out of the opposite end). And also you can put whatever you like in there!! Hate cucumbers?? No problem!
Anyway, I love coming here. And the people working here are all really nice and will probably answer any questions you have if you're not familiar. Just remember to wash your hands before and after!!
author: Athena L.

description:
I'm torn writing this review because their food was so dang good but it was one of the most frustrating customer service experiences ever.

I called in a reservation for 10 people and showed up with about half of my party (the other half were just a few minutes late trying to park). The restaurant was surprisingly empty when we showed up and we saw a table reserved for 10 which we assumed was for us. Instead, they showed us to a table with 8 seats. I was confused but he said that we would have to squeeze. Wtf, rude. Why would you make us squeeze when you have all these open tables available? I was adamant on requesting a bigger table since we had a lot of adults which would be uncomfortable to squeeze AND I made a reservation for 10 so why don't you just give me my table for 10?! After the third time asking, he finally agreed to put two tables together to accommodate.

When we got seated, my sister placed the order to probably the most emotionless man I've ever met who would not acknowledge any of our requests (we asked for water and soda chanh since 20 minutes in and they didn't bring it out on their own). I don't understand why their service was so slow when the restaurant was still pretty empty at this point. My family had a pretty late lunch that day so though we had 10 people (including 3 small children), we ordered about 5 portions of the 7 course beef, two appetizers and a rice plate to start and were planning to order more if it wasn't enough. The waiter kept making snide comments about how this was too little of food for such a big group and gave us the dirtiest look. Who are you to tell us how much to order? We are giving you business regardless! Which by the way, the bill ended up coming out to over $200.

When the 7 course beef came out, we really liked the Bo Nuong La Lot and egg roll appetizers so we decided to order more, which took foreverrrr to come out. And since they wouldn't acknowledge us, we couldn't tell if they even got our order. Just as we were about to give up and ask for the check, the waiter finally brought out the last dishes. 

The food here was hot, tasty and made to order which is the only reason why I'm even giving them 2 stars. They were way too rude from the get-go and I will not be coming back even though the food here was good. I know many say not to expect much customer service from Asian restaurants but this was beyond anything I've ever experienced and it is definitely not worth it to be treated this way!
author: V L.

description:
I've walked by this place a million times and peered in. It's usually full of families congregated around giant round tables laughing and chatting while small children scamper around.  The tables spilling over with vibrant mint and other herbs,  with noodles and colorful vegetables commanding attention in an otherwise spartan environment. It was always busy.  I had to find out what was so special about this place.

Tonight was the night.

We ordered a fondue pot which includes cooking your choice of meats or fish in an open flame hot pot filled with broth and assembling spring rolls from the piles of ingredients and rice paper brought to your table. Very hands on...very fun.  Unbelievably delicious.

The beef wrapped in leaves was melt in your mouth. Strongly seasoned and buttery.

While this place is a little on the spendy side by TL standards it's worth every penny... I am totally impressed.
author: Summer S.

description:
I had heard so many raving reviews about the infamous 7 courses of beef.  Maybe that why I left feeling full, but under-whelmed.  It was over-hyped up for me.

I enjoyed these courses:
1 Beef salad with pickled carrots and daikon with nuoc mam (fish sauce)
2 Slices of beef cooked in broth heated over a sterno burner
3 Slices of beef grilled with onions on a hot plate over sterno burners
4 Beef Congee (served after 5, 6, 7 below).

I didn't enjoy these courses as much, but it could be because I was hitting the FULL threshold:
5 Ground beef rolled in some sort of leaf
6 Beef rolled around some daikon, I think
7 Ground beef that looked like some chunky pink pate.

Basically, all the courses except the beef salad and beef congee involved me rolling the beef with some veggies in rice paper and dipping it with some anchovy sauce or nuoc mam.  Sadly for me, the veggie selection only had a sprinkling of cilantro, and was 95% basil leaves, 2% sliced cucumbers, and 2% julienned carrots and daikon.

Sure, everything was tasty, but when you put anything together with nuoc mam and hot sauce, it's bound to be tasty.  The boys ordered quite a bit of beer, so our grand total came out to be about $40/person.
author: Christina L.

description:
No Pho here, but that's not what I come here for!

I've been here many times as a kid, but never really appreciated the food until recent years. They supply the ingredients and we roll and wrap our own spring rolls. The meat selection is delicious and the condiments (veggies and herbs galore!) are always fresh. Their "Seven Courses of Beef" is highly recommended by staff...and by me. I think it's a good start if you've never been there before and want to taste a variety of their beef fillings. Not sure if you know how to roll your own wrap with rice paper? No worries, they'll show you.
author: Helen L.

description:
#1 service was horrible 
#2 the staff's lack of urgency is appalling 

Don't come here if you want good service and amazing food.  The wait is long and the food is aight
author: Matt L.

description:
I've been going to this place since I was in grade school. It's my mom's favorite and every time we go out to celebrate you can catch our family here. Make a reservation or you'll be stuck waiting. Going through 7 courses takes while so you want to make sure you get there on time. Watching people eat is so torturous :'( . Corkage fee is $10. Great for parties between 6-15 max, if you want to sit comfortably. 

My favorite courses would be 
course #2 the beef fondue
course #3,4,5 usually come out together, it is a variation of  sausages. Each different but so delicious in their own way! 

order the shrimp with sugarcane too! Yum.
author: Michelle G.

description: Go to place for 7 courses of beef. Not as good as down South, but hey what can you do. Decent for what it is. If you haven't done it yet, you must experience it at least once in your life.
author: Vivian D.

description:
My family and I use to always come here, and we would order the seven course beef. After all these years, it still tastes delicious! The meats are flavorful, and the serving sizes are just right. 

Everything seemed perfect, the food, the spacing, the lighting, but the service.. Their service has changed over the years. Besides the boss, the others seem very angry all the time. There was one in particular who made a nasty joke when I ordered soy milk. I do not know if it is because I cannot handle a joke, or what. I felt very uncomfortable afterwards, and everyone at the table became silent.
author: Melinda T.

description:
I love vietnamese food. 

It's got to be one of the healthiest cuisines in the world. 

What makes this place so unique is that you get to roll your own spring rolls.  

They bring out a bowl of hot water, rice paper, mint leaves, bean sprouts, cucumbers, and julienne radishes and carrots soaked in vinegar 

You can order your meat separately and even cook at your table. 

Must Try: 

Shrimp Wonton Soup (the broth is so clean, there is hardly a drop of oil in it) 

Fish Balls on Sugar Cane (after you eat the fish balls in your rolls you can chew gently on the sugar cane for flavor) 

Beef wrapped in Leaves
author: Sandy C.

description: Did I miss something? This meal was not good! I really wanted to try this Vietnamese restaurant, I know they had a location in San Jose. It's a unique experience where you cook and roll your own spring rolls. However for close to $80 w/o tip for 3 people it is not worth it! The restaurant itself is dirty. The guy that came to our table was coughing while he set stuff onto our table. Ew. We did the beef and shrimp grill, egg rolls, and BBQ chicken. The raw portion of beef and shrimp was small, not worth the $26 for 5/pieces each. For the price I'm paying I'm expecting some vermicelli noodles to come with the combo. The only highlight was that the greens were fresh. The server brought us BBQ pork, my boyfriend can't eat pork and we informed him we ordered chicken. He then argued with us saying we ordered pork and insisted it was very good. Nonetheless, they didn't take it back and we didn't eat it. Very frustrating, it looked like everyone was enjoying the food but we were not impressed. Not only did I leave did I realized I could have gotten more with the 7 beef combo which the server didn't inform us about anything on the menu or how things work since he didn't even speak English or Vietnamese (to us adleast). The pictures and reviews are deceiving, I would definitely pass on this place.
author: Van N.

description:
I wasn't blown away by the 7 course beef. Maybe because I'm comparing it to my boyfriend's mother's cooking and really, nothing beats her Vietnamese cooking and home made fish sauce!

The portions are big and they are pretty good with refilling your sauces and water when you ask. I came with a group of 6 of my girlfriends and we ordered for 4 people and it was plenty for us. Don't order the shrimp on sugarcane because it was so expensive and not worth it! You are also allowed to substitute one of the dishes for another dish. They were nice about it.
author: Janny S.

description: Strong love for this place for the great tasting authentic Viet 7 meat dishes their congee and generous greens served to make me feel less guilt with eatting so much meat
author: Juila L.

description: Must do the whole shabang! 7 course beef with the sugar cane shrimp! YAAAAAASSSSS! Meaty yet light and absolutely delicious! Reminder they do not serve pho! Lol wraps on wraps on wraps! A definite must try at least once!
author: Dolly R.

description:
2 words. HORRIBLE SERVICE!

Been here a couple of times back in the day when I was in grade school. Pretty much too young to even know how to order my own food. 

My most recent visit was in January for a friend's birthday dinner. She had just came back from traveling to Vietnam so she wanted to have 7 courses of beef. She had made reservations for over 15 people (forgot the exact amount) and they had made arrangements for that on a large rectangular table. However, some friends didn't show up so they had move them to a smaller round table.  My girlfriend and I arrived late. So when we got there, they were already munching. With that said, they still didn't want to give us the larger reserved table and just pushed together another smaller round table together. UGH. Let me emphasize that the restaurant is 3/4 EMPTY! Pessimistic, yes! Fine, we understand you want to reserve your tables for other guests. 

Alright, so everyone that was already there ordered already. I think they all shared the 7 course beef. My friend and I weren't that hungry so we wanted to share a rice place but the male server flat out told us NO because everyone has to order something. WHAT???? There was no apology or anything while he was saying it either. He stood there and waited for us to figure out our second order. 

Besides that, we never got refills or check backs. At the end of the day, I know it's a vietnamese restaurant so I shouldn't expect much service but for gosh sakes we're in Downtown SF not chinatown! I totally understand that you want to generate revenue and reserve seating for larger parties but service here is BS. Do not expect return customers if you are going to treat your customers like that. 

As for the food, it's really nothing spectacular. There are a million other places that you can enjoy 7 courses of beef so please try it elsewhere especially if you want to celebrate a special evening!
author: Yen Yen C.

description:
The last thing I wanted to hear to night at anh huong was some hipster wanna be white girl scream loudly inside saying " What the hell is that ? It looks gross, I ain't eating that..."...way to make all the Asians stare you down..like you're part of the Viet Cong..hipsters don't fit in here..esp if they aren't used to non american cuisines and only eat at crap diners..go back to mels and Denny's..


Having come here as a spur of the moment quality control, I had high expectations of this place.
Extremely high, should this place fail, it would been such an embarrassment.

What did I discover from this visit?
 
1)Chao Tom: For once the sugar cane came up without being too stiff and dry to the point it felt like chewing on bamboo. The shrimp wrap around it is perfect. (+1)

2) Cha Gio: They look like they were cooked evenly this time as the skin layer wasn't bubbling, but they were defrosted on this occasion and by the time they reached the table. You would not want to order it again. It was cooked thoroughly but as wit all frozen food. There was no real flavor to it. (-1)

3)Bo Thai Chinh: if you hate or resent beef. Keep your hands off this plate. If you are a carnivore, you will love the flavor infused into the beef as you taste it.
Rare beef is better than it sounds. Trust me. They wouldn't be able to charge you money for it if unless it was perfect.(+1)

4)Bo Nuong La Lot: tested the beef and not so thick on the leaves (+1)

5)Bo Nuong Mo Chai : Beef and Chips . Very tender for something charcoaled (+1)

6)Veggies :Clean and bug free! (+1)

7)Coke: Expiration date and Carbonation check -+Passed (+1)
author: Eric C.

description: Came here on a Sunday night with girlfriends. Got the seven courses of beef which was pretty damn good. Definitely a lot of beef lol. Everything was really good except the steamed beef plate. One of the beefs was stuffed with onions; it tasted more like a European dish rather than Asian. The other beef options were great. For 4 girls, we ordered 3 of the seven courses and then egg rolls and it was more than enough food.  Will def come back at some point.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Carnivore Cavegirl strikes again! 

The 7 Courses of beef here is famous for justifiable reason! They offer a variety of styles of delicious beef for you to enjoy. I love some courses like crazy and others I am happy to watch others enjoy while I wait for the ones I love to appear. Peter usually orders other dishes also - which creates this wonderfully distressing situation where you try to figure out how you can fit everything you want to eat into your belly! 

I squeal with delight when the rice noodles, rice paper, and sausages appear. I am wild for the Carpaccio. The beef salad doesn't really stand a chance when it hits the table because I really love that a lot! The rice soup that is kind of like jook makes me really really happy. I love to crunch and munch the pickled carrots and daikon in between courses. 

I don't like doing this menu unless I am with a large party because it is too much food and it takes a long time for each course to come to make it a good thing for two - so make this a group event when you go! 

They offer other great Vietnamese dishes but the 7 Courses is what makes my heart go wild, so that is always have when I am here with a table full of friends. 

The parking lot across the street is closed so try to score parking on Geary after 6 PM when parking restrictions are lifted on the one side of the street. 

Come hungry. . . you will be reveling in beef heaven! Wear stretchy pants or a dress so your belly can distend while you enjoy each course bite for bite. I love how my hair and clothes smell like beef and fish sauce when I leave. 

I know, i'm weird. It's ok. You can handle it. 

PS: Thank you Peter L for calling us to the table once again. This is truly one of my favorite things to do with our great group of friends!
author: Jennifer C P.

description: Their 7 course beef are the best anywhere. All the dishes are rich in flavors and spices. Addicted to their grilled prawns and sugarcane shrimp. I've been coming here for the last fifteen years and service is still great.
author: Hoang T.

description:
So I'm guessing they pay yelp to advertise for them? I'm 90% sure the waiter spit in my food.

Anyway, came in on a slow Tuesday cause the bf has been dying to try this place. To say I'm not impressed would be an understatement. The service is slow and the food is really not that great. I don't see what all the hype is about.

We did the 7 course beef - $21.99 per person. First time and the waiters didn't bother explaining it to us so we fended for ourselves.
*1st - a "beef" salad. I say it that way cause the meat really looked like pork. it was tough and dry and vinegary. PASS
*2nd - 6 slices of super thick beef that you're supposed to dip in a vinegar broth. they call this beef carpaccio apparently.
*3rd, 4th, 5th and 6th - I believe it all came on the same plate? not sure cause the waiters didn't acknowledge us. they would just walk by and put the food on our table without even making eye contact. There were 3 different types of beef sausages - one was plain grilled. one was the exact same sausage wrapped in a leaf and the last tasted like pork....again. and then there was a teacup sized beef cake looking thing? it tasted like children's tears..dried.

Maybe 30 mins pass? At this point, I had to flag down one of the waiters to ask if we could just cancel the rest of our order and I'd pay for whatever we ate. He said it would be the same price whether we finished the courses or not - and that they were going to bring our food out soon.

Out comes #7 - beef porridge. this is the reason why they have 1 star (also cause yelp won't let me leave 0 stars). the taste is good but too much ginger in my opinion. if you like that stuff then more power to you! 

seriouly,  I'm disappointed in you Anh Hong! I wanted to go Pagolac to break my 7 course beef virginity but they were closed...and so you were ungratefully blessed with my presence. never again, never again.
author: Lily K.

description: Seven course beef is sooo good! The server was very friendly and helpful. She taught me how to make the rolls and explained the different sauces and meat. My husband ordered the grilled chicken and it was so good too. The chicken was tender and flavorful. The servings are big. We couldn't finish it. Looking forward to coming back!
author: Kate L.

description: Good food, clean.  Great service. We did not have a wait to be seated.  Traditional Vietnamese food.  I would go back again
author: Patrick D.

description: 7 course meal... good food, large portions, friendly but impossibility slow service. We finished... waited. Asked for check and boxes. Waited. Asked again. Waited. Paid cash. Asked for boxes. Waited. Left. Annoyed.
author: Daniel W.

description: My family and I have been going here for over two decades. Most definite the best 7 course beef in town!
author: Michael P.

description:
Anh Hong has been a family favorite for many years. The 7 course meal is what we normally get, with some additional sides of shrimp over sugar canes and vermicelli. The Bo Nuong La Lot is so unique and delicious. I will never get tired of eating here. Every time I come here I leave a very full, satisfied girl. I would recommend this place to anyone who loves wrapping up their own little rolls. 
The only downfall to this place is probably parking, since it's in the Tenderloin.
author: Melissa C.

description:
My first time having Vietnamese food that is not Pho, spring rolls, and ban beo/xeo!

I've never experienced Vietnamese cuisine where you cook your own beef (like kbbq) and then wrap your own spring rolls. They give you sheets of rice paper and a bowl of hot water, along with the veggies (cucumbers, pickled veggies, bean sprouts, mint, lettuce) and sauce. I was a pro by the end of the meal, haha

- Shrimp cake wrapped in sugar cane: I cut these up and put it in my spring roll - delicious, flavorful shrimp cake

- Shrimp wonton soup: Broth was flavorful and the shrimp wontons tasted fresh (big piece of shrimp)

- Lemon grass beef: They give you a grill to cook these on with some onions. Be careful no to overcook the beef (laying the beef on top of the onions helped prevent beef sticking to the grill)

I'll have to try the 7 course beef that everyone is raving about next time when I have a bigger appetite!
author: Stacey K.

description:
Beef..it's what's for dinner!!  And it so was a few weeks ago!  Of course we had the much talked about 7 Courses of Beef.  Of course service could be a little better, but then again, you're coming to restaurants like this for the food strictly, not for the service. As many have said, much of the meal is filled with veggies too to balance out the beef...and your diet!  Bf was pouring on the dipping sauces (vs. dipping) onto his course #2, & one of the waiters came over & scolded him saying, NO NO, not that!  7 Courses of Beef Nazi?
*Course #1: The beef salad: It was light & refreshing & veggie filled.  I don't know what part of the cow it was, but the apperance reminded me of tripe.
*Course #2: Beef fondue: Think shabu like but you make your own spring roll with the veggies, beef & vermicelli wrapper.  Simple yet tasty!
*Course #3: Meatballs mixed with nuts, mushrooms & spices.  Reminded me of pate kind of.  Served with shrimp chips.  Not bad, though I never care for Vietnamese meatballs.  
*Courses #4-6: Three different kinds of grilled sausages that you also wrap up like a spring roll (though I did eat one by itself)!  One was wrapped up in Hawaiian lotus leaf, one with lemongrass and peanuts, and the other simply nekkid!  We liked the plain one the best, but they were all delicious and perfectly juicy.  
*Course #7: Last but not least, beef rice soup.  Perfect for the chilly weather!  It was so flavorful yet light.  

Favorite for sure would be the plain beef sausage, but the beef soup was so good too.  The whole meal was a different & delcious experience.  All that food for $22 per person is a deal.  We left stuffed and with some leftovers to take home.  Come here definetely when you're hungry & feeling carniverous!
author: Cat C.

description:
Went to Anh Hong for dinner last Friday because my mom was craving it. We used to eat there semi regularly with my grandma when I was a kid. However we haven't been back since my grandma got sick and passed away. So going back definitely brought back bittersweet memories. 

We ordered one of the Bo 7 Mon (seven course beef), the grilled shrimp wrapped with beef, the special imperial rolls and the sugarcane shrimp to share among my mom, my sister and me.  Perhaps it was because my grandma wasn't there or maybe the food really changed but it wasn't as great as I remembered it. The beef salad used to be more tasty and I also recall the meatball a little more moist.

However, Anh Hong is still my favorite place to get seven course beef.  They make a really delicious Bo La Lot (beef wrapped in Hawaiian Lot leaf).  The sugarcane shrimp is a must try as well.  The banh hoi (rice noodle cake) is also cooked perfectly with a slight bite to it...not mushy and falling apart like some places.

If you like Vietnamese food or Bo 7 Mon, then you definitely need to check out Anh Hong.
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Good:

-Good thing we  came around 7pm and there wasn't a wait on a Wednesday night. It got busier within the hour. 
-First 3 dishes came out fast when we ordered the 7 Beef Dish special. 

Meh:
Food is ok and nothing was spectacular.

Bad:
-Super slow service
-Last 4 Beef Special Dishes took FOREVER to come out
-Charged twice for an order of (cold) rice noodles that took 20 mins to come out
-Ice tea was $1.50 in an Asian restaurant?! Should've ordered water with lemon.
-Included the Tip for what they considered a large party... We had 5 adults and 2 kids

Won't be coming back to this place. The one in San Jose is much better.
author: Kat V.

description:
Porridge is awesome......

I know its the 7 course beef, but the porridge that comes with it is the best.........

A whole group came as the place was packed.........it was our first time there, and very memorable.........parking is a little hectic as the TL area is always full.....

Beef lovers only.....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
I absolutely love this place. It's a unique dinner experience where you hand roll your own spring rolls. From dipping the rice paper in hot water to soften it, to picking out your choice of fresh vegetables, to the meat you choose to put in there. My family and I usually come here for birthday dinners or whenever we deem is a good time to feast. 

We always, always, always get:
- Chao Tom Banh Hoi (charboiled shrimp wrapped around sugar canes)
- Tom Nuong Banh Hoi (grilled BBQ shrimp)
- Cha Gio Anh Hong (house special imperial rolls)
- Bo 7 Mon (7 courses of beef)

The Bo 7 Mon includes:
- Goi Bo (beef salad)
- Bo Tai Chanh (slices of rare beef cooked at your table)
- Bo Cha Dum (steamed beef meatball/pate w/ chips)
- Bo Mo Chai (grilled beef sausage)
- Bo La Lop (grilled minced beef rolled in lot leaf)
- Bo Nuong Xa (grilled beef w/ lemongrass)
- Chao Bo (beef rice porridge)

All these dishes are served with rice paper, lettuce, mint leaves, cilantro, cucumbers, bean sprouts, pickled carrots and daikon. If you start to run low on these, just let them know and they'll gladly refill.

There's two different dipping sauces: nuoc mam (fish sauce) and mam nem (fermented anchovy sauce). They have very different tastes so give them both a try. I grew up using nuoc mam and was introduced to mam nem when I first came here; it took a while but it eventually grew on me. From my experience, mam nem usually tastes better with beef.

It's delicious food and an awesome hands-on eating experience. But be warned! You and your clothes will smell like the food you just ate.
author: Sandy T.

description:
Not worth your time or money.

We went there for my friend's birthday. The birthday friend and I ordered 2 Bo 7 Mon ($24 each).  The others ordered BBQ beef rolls with fried rice & salad, and a rice noodle side dish.  The tall, older Vietnamese Chinese male waiter took our orders. He was rude and unfriendly throughout our meal. He alone would keep me away from Anh Hong.  But he was not the only reason keeping me away.
Here is my take on the Bo 7 Mon:
--Celery salad: average at 8/10
--Beef fondue: lean round slides of beef, good 9/10
--3 types of beef rolls: fatty, greasy, MSG overdose, the lowest beef quality, 5/10
--Beef pate: good 9/10
--Rice soup: average 8/10
The BBQ beef rolls with fried rice & salad: unremarkable, beef rolls have fillers in the middle (onions, sprouts, or both).

We do not recommend Anh Hong Restaurant due to 4 reasons:
--Bad neighborhood: urine-soaked and shit-filled streets, drug addicts and dealers, prostitutes, criminals, etc.
--Average food with 3 nasty types of beef rolls - fatty, oily, over-MSG'ed
--Rude waiter
--Lack of cleanliness: dirty floor, sticky chairs, no paper towels to dry your hands in the restrooms.
--Noisy
author: G D.

description:
I was hoping for something quite strongly flavoured and authentic from the other reviews. The 7 shades of beef did not appear to contain a hell of a lot of beef, other than the sausage/pate medley at the end. Salad and soup were vanishing populated, and only the slices of meat in the vinegar dish were actual visible beef worth celebrating.

You do kinda get what you pay for here and they are mighty generous with the condiments and side dishes.
author: Donald C.

description:
The food here was just okay and probably lower-than-average for Vietnamese restaurants in the city. I tried the grilled pork rice plate and my bf had the lemongrass chicken. The portions were large and the taste was there, but we felt that the quality of ingredients used were poor.

I grew up in San Jose and have been to many authentic mom-and-pop (and some of them, "gritty") Vietnamese restaurants. And a lot of them do not appear to be very clean or welcoming at first, but turn out to be great in the end (amazing food, and awesome/friendly service).

Unfortunately, our experience wasn't so great here. The service was also not the best and the restaurant felt unsanitary and unwelcoming. There was also very unpleasant smell at one part of the restaurant, maybe that was the real culprit for this review...
author: Monica T.

description:
Looking for a new Vietnamese dining experience other than your run of the mill pho and bahn mi? Anh Hong is the place to go.

My friends and I got the seven course beef and it was delicious. It is A LOT of food so it might not be necessary to get one per person. Between 2 girls and myself we only got two orders of that and there were leftovers. The salad that came first was ok to be honest. It was refreshing but nothing I'd rave about. The Beef fondue was neat and pretty tasty. Next came all of the beef rolls and pate. It's not particularly easy to make the rolls if you're not used to it but not too hard to get the hang of after 2-3 rolls. After all of the rolls, the rice porridge comes in to finish it off. Very tasty porridge and full of flavor. All in all, it was a fun and tasty experience.

However, if it's your first time here, come with someone who knows what to do because the waiters aren't the most helpful/friendly. Most people who go here already know what to do so they probably never have to really tell anyone what to do.
author: edward k.

description:
Met with two of my BFFs for dinner on a friday night for Chinese new year. We made reservations, sat us right away. We been here many times before. We had: raw beef salad, shrimp and beef sald, shrimp wrap in sugar cane, egg rolls w noodles, beef wrapped in lot leaves, beef sausage (was not good this time around) we asked for crab claws, waiter said, "no more" ooohhh no! I can hear my son across the table. Surprisingly the service was attentive during this visit. Usually its so slow, i sort of get the feeling once i get my orders, I'm fending for myself. 
This time the waiter was more talkative and engaging. We had our water and our side of veggies replenished. I will stop by there for dinner again when in the city, yes with my BFFs .
author: Vuoch. L.

description: Unfortunately this restaurant had the worst service of any in SF. The wait was obnoxiously long, the waiters were very distasteful and rude, and the food was not worth the time spent in waiting for it. I would definitely think twice before dining at this establishment.
author: Ubz D.

description: The restaurant was able to accommodate our large party of 7 adults and 4 kids for the 7 course beef dinner.  I was able to eat most of it and wow was it good.  If you don't mind getting your hands dirty and if you love the Vietnamese spring roll wrap you will love this place.  We ordered 4 or so of the 7 courses and added some sides like imperial rolls, grilled shrimp & squid (highly recommend - soooo damn good) and I can't remember what else.  Luckily my gf had already been so she knew the drill and did the ordering and showed us how it all worked.  We definitely had an abundance of food and had a lot of leftovers to divy up & take home.  Service is pretty attentive and the ambiance isn't bad, just not in the best of neighborhoods.
author: Meredith K.

description: DIY spring rolls of 7 course beef! Yum! First had beef carpaccio which was delicious!! Had a plate of papaya salad and then cooked beef for spring rolls. After that we had a large dish full of a variety of beef cooked in different ways. All delicious and filling. Finished almost everything among six girls for 20 each isn't too bad. Will be back again one day.
author: Amanda C.

description:
The most amazing Vietnamese food I have experienced in my life thus far! A very nice break from the typical pho establishments. 

7 COURSE BEEF, BEEF CARPACCIO, GRILLED BEEF, GRILLED SHRIMP, IMPERIAL ROLLS, SPRING ROLLS, SHRIMP WONTONS, SHRIMP WRAPPED SUGAR CANE, BEEF PORRIDGE. BEEF AND SHRIMP AND VEGETABLES AND RICE PAPER AND FISH SAUCE ALL OVER THE PLACE!

I really enjoyed wrapping my own spring rolls and how they came with all the fixings you could possibly want. Though I am a more hands-on person so I could see how that could be a hassle for those who don't like to put an effort into creating their meal. Topped off dinner with a fried banana and vanilla ice cream and stumbled out of the restaurant after a whole 2.5 hrs of dining. Definitely not diet-friendly though possibly low carb!
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Love the 7 course beef here! I've been coming here for about 5 years and it never disappoints. Don't expect the service to be amazing, but it's decent. Their raw beef salad is also delicious. Usually when we come with about 5 people, we will order 3-4 7 course beef set and it's super filling and we usually have some left overs, so I don't think each person needs to order a set. 

Definitely recommend this place!
author: Chelsea H.

description: Get the 7 courses of beef and the shrimp balls with sugar cane
author: Paul R.

description:
Overall, I say 3.5 but the food really wins me over so I rounded up to a 4.

+4 for awesome 7 course beef, -1.5 for service, +1 for the fact that you really cannot get this anywhere else in the city (except Pagolac - but Anh Hong does it bettah!)

Parking is OKAY here, always seem to find parking.. very easy to get here by bus (take the 38). Area is soooort of sketchy but I'd still come out of my way to come here to try it =)

Service is not the greatest. They're pretty slow and they don't really speak English that well (which is TOTALLY fine in my book) but they're kind of .. brusque? Not rude but just.. brusque..

ANYWAYS - the 7 course beef sounds pretty overwhelming but it's not like.. 7 courses of steak. Just read about it on their site! Haha too lazy to type. But yeaaaa.. my fav is the congee which comes last =]
YUMMMMM! I get cravings for this place about every few months.. Sorry it wasn't a very in-depth review on the food itself but I don't really know the dishes by name and don't want to make myself sound stupider. Haha.
author: Emily C.

description:
Always enjoy coming here.

Very interactive dinner where you can make your own spring rolls as you please. Don't forget to order the raw beef salad as a starter! Also, leave a little room for the beef porridge at the end. 

Warning: If you order only 2 orders of the 7 course beef, they will charge $3 for the extra side of veggies (cucumber, radish&carrots, and bean sprouts). No thanks..
author: Hana Y.

description: Ordered the shrimp with rice cakes and crispy noodle dishes to go. Both withstood a 15 minute ride home and both were tasty and delicious. I particularly enjoyed the crispy noodle dish. Though a bit overpriced, the flavors and chow mein-ish noodles brought the value up. I'd order it again.
author: stuart l.

description:
Man I love this spot!  Such contrasting flavors and really nice service. 

We always get the "do-it-yourself spring rolls". I'm not sure what they're called in Vietnamese. And, I apologize for that. But, they are super delicious. We get the shrimp and rice cakes. They come with a giant pile of quick pickled veggies and a mound of ultra fresh herbs and lettuce. You wrap em up and devour them like giant, healthy Vietnamese cigars.  They are dipped in a vinegary, fishy, sweet and spicy sauce. 

On this visit we tried they're clay pot. This is a traditional rice with chicken and shrimp dish. And, it's literally cooked in a clay pot. The fiery hot pot makes the rice all crispy on the bottom. Yum!

Service is really good. Albeit, a little slow at times. 

I'm hooked on all things Vietnamese. If you love Pho and Banh Mi, try this spot for another aspect of Vietnamese food!
author: Dusty B.

description:
I finally had my first experience with a traditional Vietnamese 7 Course Beef Menu.

Along with that, we ordered shrimp wrapped around sugar cane, egg rolls, chicken rice plate and other stuff I can't recall.

For the shrimp dish, they took shrimp and basically grounded them up and made them into square shaped shrimp "balls". The shrimp's sweetness was heightened by the addition of the sugar cane without being too sweet. I thought the egg rolls were standard, nothing special. As for the chicken, it was overcooked but was sure tasty!

For the meat courses, everything came out relatively quick and tasted good. Nothing bad stood out to me partly because I simply was so entralled with the newness of my dining experience I forgot to taste taste my food. 

I love the fact that they give you a copious amount of rice wapper along with veggies and fish sauce for you to wrap your own meals. It is an amazing hands on dining experience that I am so fortunate to have tried. The next time I go to another establishment that offers a beef course I shall have a better sense of what to look for.

An authentic Vietnamese family style meal that allows you to be interactive with your meal, can't beat that! 

3 star for food
+1 star for new experiences

Overall Thoughts

Anh Hong gives you the opportunity to experience more than just pho, a way to connect deeper with Vietnamese Culture. You might find yourself not messing Pho so much after all
author: Eddie W.

description:
The perfect place to have a low carb meal that's also delicious and nutritious and not at all boring, as long as you don't give in to the temptation of the rice noodles, or getting a rice dish, or using too many rice wrappers. 

Just remember: Rice = Public Enemy Number One. (I mean if you're trying to stay away from carbs....)

USEFUL: Do not hesitate to use up all your lettuce wrapper and herbs. They are cool with giving you more more more, even if they may sometimes have looming, dour looks on their faces.
author: Joshua L.

description:
Excellent!!  My dinner which was a Shrimp wonton soup and bbq chicken and beef ribs hit the spot.  I was the only non Vietnamese patron, which should tell you they have the respect of their comrades and cook to perfection.  I wish I lived here because I would come at least once a week!!!!

Only draw back was the bathroom.  They need to keep it spotless!
author: Kam E.

description:
I ordered the "7 Courses of Beef" and a side order of shrimp & pork spring rolls. 

Service:
Terrible. It was a bunch of grouchy looking men who never spoke to you and only dropped food off at your table. Trying to get any service (like more water) was nearly impossible. When the waiter took our order and I just wanted one person's service of the beef (for a table of two), he looked so irritated.

When he came to drop off the plate of herbs, he poured all the water (from washing the herbs) all over my dinning partner's napkin/plate/utensils. He didn't even acknowledge that he drenched our table with water.

Food:
The food came with no instructions. What are you supposed to do? Figure it out. When they drop the food off without talking to you, you have no idea what the dish is. There was a soupy bowl of beef that was dropped off. I thought it was soup, and took a giant spoonful of -- VINEGAR. Yes, I know it was listed on the menu, but how am I supposed to know that?

All the beef courses were bland and boring. I was suckered in by all these great Yelp reviews, but seriously, this food is not good. I would highly recommend picking something else on the menu.
author: H. L.

description:
This is my family's go-to place  for Bò 7 Món, we love it! During my most recent trip to Anh Hong Restaurant we ordered 3 portions of the Bò 7 Món, this was more than enough for the four of us! 

My favorite of the 7 dishes are Bò lá lot (beef wrapped in lolot leaf), Bò nuong mo chài (ground beef rolled in pork belly), and the Cháo Bò (beef rice porridge). Can't forget the Mam Nem Sauce (Anchovy Sauce)!! My faveee =)

The service is attentive and courteous. The waiters are very efficient and it was great that they never rushed our meal. 

I would be cautious what you decide to wear to eat Bò 7 Món because it can get very smelly, especially when the place is packed.
author: Elaine N.

description:
So last weekend 14 of us went to dinner for a pals birthday. Her BF was in charge and decided we woudl go to an old haunt of his. I'm a fan most asian food - so I wasnt a hard sell. Especially with the multi-course beef dinner. 

We arrived early and were immediately seated. It was a wet rainy night - yet the place was well lit and had the right balance of noise that you wanted to tuck in and enjoy. 

Once we are all seated the staff got us started. all but 4 of use went with the 7-course menu - those that didnt had both meat and meat-free dishes that looked great.

Everything about this place says casual, and relaxed yet with an attention to the food. Even being some of the only white faces in the room - we were made welcome and the staff made sure all of us knew what and how to eat each course.

This is most definately a "go again" spot!
author: Frank S.

description:
So happy that honey brought me here for our Friday night dinner.

We ordered beef, shrimp and chicken for our spring rolls. You get to roll your own spring rolls! ^___^ A tad different than La Vie, Anh Hong sets a bowl of hot water, rice paper, lettuce, mint leaves, bean sprouts, and vermicelli out for you to leave you to your own rolling. No doubt the beef, shrimp and chicken was delicious and fresh.

Ambiance is exactly like an Asian restaurant, haha. I mean that with utmost respect. Must come here and show your tummy you love it. Very filling!
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Do the beef 7 ways. Just do it. 

I love making hundreds of spring rolls when I'm here and they really do give you beef, made in 7 different ways. If you're a pig like my boyfriend and I, get one order of it for each person (it's $20 an order, so get two for $40, yay, math!). This place is awesome and I think about it a lot...
author: Kelly B.

description:
The beef course is excellent. I also love the sugarcane shrimp.
This place is the most authentic one of all.
author: Bentley K.

description: This place is awesome! It is one of my favorite Vietnamese places, and for me that's saying a lot! The Bo 7 (7 course beef) is phenomenal! also got to have the wrap & roll. Great when with a big group, but still works with only a couple. Everything here is really good. If you like Vietnamese food, there is no way your not going to love this place!
author: Peter K.

description: Probably the first time and last time I'll eat here. I didn't feel welcomed here at all. Waiters are rude that hate anybody that speaks English and Thai tea is made from sour condensed milk. Needs new waiters, service was by far the worst I had in SF
author: Tim A.

description: The 7 courses of beef is great, we went here multiple times and love it. Fast service and friendly staff. We will definitely come back!
author: Moniek D.

description:
First time eating a legit Vietnamese dinner so I don't have anything to compare it to. Came here with my boyfriend and his family and I felt like a noob because I didn't know how to eat .___. well in this case, monkey see, monkey do! lol

Rare Beef Salad - Yummmm this was soo flavorful and delicious that its gotten me graving for more. My stomach wasn't too used to so much raw beef and acid, so it made my stomach bloat pretty badly. But I'm definitely still coming back for this dish. haha

Beef wrapped in a Hawaiian Leaf - pretty good, like mini little sausages. Great wrapped in the spring rolls.

Egg Rolls - I love these! they taste amazing wrapped in the lettuce with the noodles!

Beef thats grilled on the table - Not a big fan of this mainly because of the dryness.

Beef Porridge - Although I was too full to eat it, I still took a taste of it and it was pretty damn good

Overall, great food. Im anticipating to go back for the rare beef salad.
author: Harriet W.

description:
O____o did I eat the same stuff as the other reviewers??? This place is a hole in the wall. Its actually right across the street from my boyfriends place but I never noticed it before until my friend wanted to go there for her birthday after hearing such great things about it... most of us got the 7 course beef and I wish I didnt. 

The only thing that was decent was the beef spring rolls and porridge at the end. Everything else tasted the same and was just not satisfying. I would NOT come back to get the 7 course beef. 

Since it is a hole in the wall place, of course it is not very clean... the staff was slow too but I guess I'll forgive them for that because we had a really big party and they did take the time to put tables together for us. 

*Note: watch out for some of the veggies. Some of our mints were wilted/going bad!
author: Elaine L.

description: MMMMM! Parking was a hassle but came here for a family dinner of ten people. 7 course beef. good god we were stuffed by the end of the night.  35$ per person that was a good deal if you ask me. I enjoyed the shrimp and tea leaf wrapped beef. ! I hope you know how to roll a spring roll!
author: d n.

description:
"AND...it keeps getting better!"  
....is something I rarely say about the Tenderloin, however after eating at An Hong one wet December evening...I knew this was true.
I stopped in my tracks when I saw "SEVEN COURSES OF BEEF FOR $20"
Really? Could this be true? 
Truth...it is.
This meat party includes: Beef Fondue in Vinegar sauce, chopped beef salad, make your own Vietnamese rice paper rolls with tons of fresh veggies, beef wrapped in vegetables, vegetables wrapped in beef and just beef-loaf. 
No way I can ever finish it...but it sure is fun to share! 
See also other overlooked menu items like prawns wrapped around sugar cane and crispy fried chow mien. 
Drink a Vietnamese coffee (you guessed it, it's mostly sweetened condensed milk) Get friendly with the owner and he might just give you a shot of whisky.  
$40 for two.
author: Sarah M.

description: This place has the best seven course beef.  Whenever I crave for it, I come here.  Service is a little slow but the food makes up for it.  For about $20.95, you can get the seven course beef.  It comes with beef salad, thin slices of beef you cook yourself, 3 types of beef roll, beef meatloaf, and a soup at the end.  This is a family restaurant and it's not fancy or anything.  Parking is tough to find in the area.  The neighborhood is not the greatest, but I've never had any problems.  I can't say much about the other items on the menu since I've never ordered anything else but the seven course beef.  There's two different dipping sauce, I like the stinking one best.  They give you lettuce, herbs, cucumbers, bean sprouts, and pickled veggies.  The spring roll wrap is also included.  I enjoy making my own spring roll.  Try the seven course beef here if you can't make it at home.
author: S L.

description:
First off i wanted to say that this place is so hard for me to rate. Why? because their 7 course beef is probably one of the best in the city, but their service is horrible. I think i have the right to say that since I have been coming here since maybe being in my mommy's belly. MY family use to live in the Tenderloin and I grew up eating at this restaurant and just like the name of this place, they are famous for 7 course beef. My 2 favorite dishes here, are there lemongrass beef that you have to grill yourself and there beef porridge. the lemongrass  beef isn't in the prefix 7 course so you would have to order this on your own. The beef porridge is pretty amazing, its not your regular porridge you get at a Chinese restaurant.

Service- Considering the amount of business they have generated over the pass 2 decades,I'm sure my review wouldn't matter much but feels like people should still know about it. I'm a a big meat and veggie lover and while this is call 7 course beef you still need the veggie to enhance the goodness of the spring roll. Anh Hong doesn't like to refill your veggie platter,  I mean they have to but they prefer that you don't and if the restaurant gets really busy, the owner ( a short and fairly large vietnamese man) would literally ask you to leave if he knows that your  done eating . He comes over and checks and see how far along you are with the food and when you are pretty much done he drops off your bill. And if you are still sitting around he would come over and ask that you leave, I wouldnt mine that he did, but he never say it in a nice way and that's what annoys me . 

I would give it 4 stars if it wasn't for the service and he's been like this for the past 20 something years.
author: Angela T.

description:
Come here with an empty stomach because their portions are huge and you get a lot from the 7 beef course.

Very flavorful.

I never went back because I would be happy with just a bowl of noodles but if u want to try it then you should at least one time.
author: Carol Y.

description:
I'm sure there are plenty of reviews of the 7-course beef at Anh Hong so I won't go into that.  I will say that my favorite dish was the beef porridge - so comforting, loved it!  The waiter must serve tons of these 7-course dishes daily but not being all that experienced with it, I wish he could've been a little bit more patient with us.  He just sort of brought them, grunted a lot and didn't take time to answer any questions.  

I didn't know that we could ladle the hot water/vinegar that we had cooked thin strips of beef and onions earlier to drink like a soup.  He mumbled, 'do you want this, do you want me to ladle this out for you' very impatiently and then took off with the soup before we could make up our minds.  Ok...that was not impressive.  I might give Anh Hong another chance as lots of friends talk so highly of this place, but I think I would go back to Pagolac first.
author: Maile N.

description:
I don't mind slow service but I won't put up with rude servers.

They were clearly short staffed. This did not justify the way our server treated us. We showed quite a bit of patience with him so that it would not ruin our meal. The nicer we tried to be, the ruder he became.

The food was decent and cheap. Two orders of the 7 courses of beef was enough for four.  We also got the lemongrass squid and shrimp to grill at the table. The squid was perfectly tender. We ended up with way too much food.

I couldn't find any vegetable dishes on the menu. It's all protein! Even the papaya salad had meat in it. 

Pagolac is better and they are nice to their patrons.
author: Jeanne C.

description: My first time here. Truly a hidden gem in San Jose. The meat was grilled to perfection. The house dipping sauce was so complexed yet absolutely perfect for the meal. Two thumbs way up!
author: Jeni N.

description:
I've never had 7 courses of beef before in one sitting, but let me tell you, Anh Hong definitely knows how to do it!

Just the thought of eating beef prepared 7 different ways is overwhelming, but the actual experience makes you wanting more! Especially when you come in a large group, trust me, you will be 'fighting' to get stuff on your plate...at first. But trust me, there will be enough food come 7th course. I think you are suppose to get 1 order for every person but I've done fine with 1 for every 2 people. 

Beef in sausage, beef in soup, make your own beef wraps...what more could you ask for?!

Writing this review makes me want to get some, and 7 courses worth, of beef that is...now!
author: Alysha K.

description:
Beef.
Too much.
Definitely wasn't feeling it.
So.
Not much eating for me going on.
If you're crazy about loads & loads of beef, you'll probably like it.
As for me..........nope.
author: Amy C.

description: Ok my friends love their seven course beef and this is the place we go. Service is mediocre but we just know that's how they run as long as we get our food. Food is good but the last two times i went i ended up on the toilet all night ugg! I was in denial it was this place but i think it was after last nights episode.
author: Karen T.

description:
we had a table of 12 and we all did the 7 course of beef special which is $20.95 per person.  The first dish was the beef salad, then came the hot pot beef made into spring rolls, then the beef congee, then the beef vermicelli cake, and then 3 different beef sausages that are made into more spring rolls.  I'd say it was good food overall, the beef cake was the best one, probably because they use lard in making it (told to me by my expert foodie friend).  I really like the sausages and spring rolls in general, so I'd say I am a fan of the 7 course beef.  

The service here was okay, at times they were attentive but sometimes they weren't even looking our way.  Make reservations here, it can get busy around dinner time.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Came here with some friends to try out there 7 course beef set the other night. It was surprisingly quiet for a Thur night (6:30pm). We got sat in a small corner table and immediately ordered as we were famished. 

First course: Daikon / Carrot Salad with beef. 
Second course: Beef rice paper roll.
Third course: BIG beef meatball w/ shrimp chips.
Forth course: Beef sausage 
Fifth course: Beef wrapped in tealeaf (?)
Sixth course: Beef meatloaf.
Seventh course: Beef porridge.

Everything was ok. Porridge being my favorite that night. Would of gave them 4 stars except our waiter disappeared when we wanted to get our check. After 15 minutes, we had to flag down the owner to pay. Next time I'm in the mood for beef prefix meal, I think I'll stick to Pagolac.
author: Harry Y.

description:
For our FABULOUS last meal of 2010, we went to Anh Hong. Having visited the restaurant's website prior, I had high expectations on the decor, ambiance and food only to be let down in the end.

We arrived prompt for our reservation at 7:30pm since it can be quite difficult to find parking on the "TL" We found parking within minutes so I guess we were lucky so we were 30 minutes early for our reservation. We arrived at the restaurant and it was GHETTO! We were overdressed but at least we looked impeccable. We approached one of the waiters regarding our reservation and he told us to wait a few since it was pretty packed and busy at the time. We waited for around 10 minutes and they had a make-shift table put together for us. 

We first started off with drinks, not sure what to get, the waiter recommended a Vietnamese beer, emphasizing that once we try this beer we won't forget it...the beer arrived and we took a sip...ehh? It tasted like all the other Asian beers I have tried, and no, I'll probably forget it. We ordered our food, the 7-course beef, Chaû Gioø Saøi Goøn - Saigon Rolls (Vietnamese Fried Eggrolls Wrapped in Rice Cake, served w/ Fish Sauce, Lettuce & Mint), and Chaïo Toâm Baùnh Hoûi - "Chaïo Toâm" (Charbroiled Shrimp Packed around a Sugar Cane Served over Rice Cake). 

The Saigon Rolls were hot and had a good filling in them, nothing too spectacular, forgettable. The Chaïo Toâm Baùnh Hoûi came next, not good. It taste like the crab claw you get at a Chinese restaurant. It was three measly sized pieces for around $14, TOTAL RIPOFF! 

We then started with the first two courses of the 7-course beef. It was ok, nothing that stood out. Then we had a long intermission waiting for our food. After about 15 minutes our 3-5 courses arrived in what we called, our "DONG" meat. Everything tasted the same with little variance between the dishes. There was a lot of wrapping of the DONG which got annoying after a while. If I'm paying $20 for this, I hate to get my hands messy, but I guess it is part of the whole experience of customizing what you want and like in your wraps. The last course, a Vietnamese version of congee came, it looked really good but again a disappointment.

Although I probably won't visit this location again, my stomach was pleased with my first 7-course beef experience and would definitely recommend it to others who have never tried.
author: Myron J.

description:
I highly recommend this restaurant, and do not let the "scary" reputation of the tenderloin neighborhood keep you away.
My friends and I ordered the seven course beef, and we were absolutely blown away by the amount of mount.  Please be aware that you will need to eat with your hands and prepare our own spring rolls, but I find this interaction part of the fun.  
I would disagree with previous yelpers on two accounts.  One, I found the service attentive and pleasant.  They let me sit around for an amount of time, drinking a beer and reading a magazine, while my friends slowly trickled in.  Also, my favorite dish was the rice soup at the very end.
In sum, I highly recommend Anh Hong Restaurant.
author: Andrew J.

description:
7 course beef is a must.. Other dishes are just as delicious. I wonder why they stop serving the slices of unripe banana with the plate of vegetables? Veggies includes fish tasting leaves that's from the tropics which happens to be my fav. There are others that I don't know by English names. 

It's fun to roll your selections of meat in the rice paper but first you'll have to dip it in water to soften the paper but will maintain it's elasticity for you to load up on as many different kinds of meat and fresh veggies. 

They also have thin rice vermicelli noodles dredge in green onion scallion sauce. There are 2 dipping sauce, both are stinky. One more so than the other. You'll need an acquired taste for the beige sauce, it can be rancid like durian if you never had it, but once that's overcome. The meal comes together. Pure goodness in your mouth.

Everything is so healthy, it's why I love this place. Anh Hong gets pretty busy so try to get there early.
author: Joanne L.

description: I have to say, the food here is good but I have tasted better in Southern California. The service is just horrible, the waiter took too long and when our food came he basically just threw it on the table. At the end, it took about 20 minutes until we received the check. We asked three different waiters and they seem preoccupied. Overall, the food is not bad but the service is horrible.
author: Vivi T.

description:
If you're going to Anh Hong, make sure to bring someone along with you so you can try to seven course beef extravaganza. In my mind, for some reason, I was thinking huge pieces of meat would be served to us, but instead, you'll get thinly sliced marinated beef, beef wrapped in eggroll-shaped form, etc. Still, it was enough for 2 people with another side dish.

It was our first time there so we stared at each other blankly as dishes came rolling out and we had no idea how we were "supposed" to assemble all of it. For those of you who may not know, rice-paper gets soggy pretty quickly in the bowl of hot water. Rotate the rice-paper in the water until you can get it in the pliable form most of us are familiar with. Then you can feel free to wrap any of the meats in the rice paper for a spring-roll type of dish. The dishes also come with the usual sides of mint, bean sprouts, lettuce, picked cucumber and carrots as well as condiments like fish sauce, hot sauce, and shrimp paste sauce (which we didn't end up using too much of). All in all, an interesting experience, just be willing to get your hands a bit messy while you're making your own food.
author: Angela S.

description:
If you like to make your own rice paper roll and you don't know what to get, the seven course beef is a good deal because it gives you a taste of everything. It has salad, beef + vinegar dip, all kinds of beef meat rolls, and lots of fresh herbs. If you know what you like or don't like, then definitely order off the ala carte menu instead.

We had a party of four and knowing that the portions of the 7 course beef is humongous, we only got two orders of the seven course plus an order (or two) of fried spring rolls to complete the meal. It was perfect and my friends had a great time.

Service? Yeah, it's kind of odd. Our first time was terrible. Sometimes they don't tell you what they are bringing to the table. So we had no idea what we were eating. The second time around, he asked if he needs to show us how to do it and I said YES! Since then, he took care of us so well, watching us and made sure that we knew what we were doing. He moved things around and made space for us--almost too motherly hah! So my advice is: tell them it's your first time and have him walk you through the process of making a roll. Maybe that would help.

Oh you have to try the fruity pungent dipping sauce. Amazing...
author: Kwoky L.

description: The seven courses of beef is definitely worth a try here and it's a unique dining experience!  Especially when you have no idea what to expect.  We had a pretty good experience with the service too.  One of the waitresses was helpful in explaining all the ingredients to us when it came to making the rice paper rolls yourself.  They even give you a bunch of different types of dips like lemon grass sauce and fish sauce (the legit kind...be gentle with it cause it's pretty pungent).  I really liked the beef rolls that came out especially the one wrapped in hawaiian leaf.  Anyway, after having seven courses of beef I'm pretty sure I got all my protein for the day in one meal and in delicious fashion.  Way to go Anh Hong!!
author: Justin L.

description: Came here for the 7 courses of beef, I've personally never heard of it before but I like making spring rolls so I'm all up for it. Parking isn't the easiest, parked about two blocks away which isn't bad for the area. Two of my friends told me that #1 and #7 of the 7 course of beef is some basic dishes that you can cook for $2. So instead, we ordered #2-5 a la carte and doubled up on beef sausages and pate. Turned out the meal ended up being cheaper than the full 7 courses and we got more bang for our buck. Everything was ridiculously good. This place gets a double thumbs up from me.
author: Ryan L.

description:
7 courses of beef = 7 course of amazingness! I came here awhile back and experienced course after course of delicious variations of beef. The place looks like a typical pho place with gigantic goldfish in a tank and typical decor but the food is SO SO SO GOOD! For $20.95 you will get to experience of beef like no other. 

Food:
Beef salad- nice appetizer that is refreshing and tasty
Spring rolls with fresh beef cooked in fondue pot- the first of many spring rolls
a plate of assorted beef with beef sausage wrapped in a tea leaf (the BEST), a different type of beef sausage, and a piece of beef wrapped to look like a sausage with a mount of beef cake that has various goodys inside
Last course of beef is a porridge to help wash down the beef.

Must try for beef lovers just becareful of the bums and people that walk around outside, they normally leave you alone if you leave them alone.
author: Elliot T.

description: What a fun experience! I knew I wanted to try the 7 courses of beef, but starting out felt a little unsure of how to proceed. Luckily the man who took our order very straight faced and matter of factly came over and offered guidance. We enjoyed 6 of the seven courses immensely and had fun wrapping our own spring rolls. One of the courses (it seemed to bee beef wrapped around onion, not sure of the name because we tend to dive straight in and eat) wasn't to our liking, but 6 out of 7 ain't bad. Bottom line- great food, fun experience, and we left feeling stuffed for 23.50 a person! Highly recommend
author: Bree V.

description:
Just as good at Little Saigon. 
My favorite is still Bo La Lot (leaf beef for you round eyes).
You can surpass the other 6 courses and order one whole plate of this!
author: Alex T.

description:
O' MacDonald had a farm.
Ee I Ee I O!
And on this farm he had 7 cows (and one GIANT gold fish).
Ee I Ee I O!

I'm glad I came here with a bunch of other yelpers!  I had no idea what to do with the food that was presented before me.  

After explained, I started to get the hang of rolling various beefy items in spring-roll wrappers and proceeded to stuff my face.

The decor is nothing too fancy, save the impressively large goldfish swimming in a tank.

The service is friendly and attentive.  They handled our large group very effectively.

The shining star was the food!  So many fresh veggies, and perfectly done beef courses.  Everything was an explosion of interesting flavors, and was pretty healthy!  Yey!

My favorites by far were the rare thin sliced beef in lemon juice, and the beef that you poach and put in the spring roll.  Though we ordered some calamari that you grill at the table that was also FANTASTIC.  Really, everything was amazing. 

7 courses of cow + eating with your hands.  What could be better?
author: Susan C.

description:
(See pics)

A couple of my friends and I came here for the 7 course beef. The 7 kinds deliciousness earn the 5 stars that I dream of even I just finished it.

The first course beef salad was refreshing and was a great starter to open up our appetites. Then the hot pot showed up so that we can have either the raw or boil the beef slices (carpaccio) and wrap with the rice paper.

At this point I did not know how to do it as I looked perplexed at my Chinese Vietnamese friend. He demo it quickly. The server/owner then came by, asked if we had any questions and proceeded to do a full demo.

He also pointed out our fully cooked beef would be too tough to eat. And as I proceeded to put loads of vegetables in my rolling process. He said I should put less to be able to roll my version of  gigantic "imperial" roll! I was almost afraid that he would judge me when I roll but he was very very nice. He loves his food to the point of protecting it by teaching us how to make it the right way. :)

The mint leaves and lettuce were very fresh, and I love the little hands on experience.

We proceeded to the other three kinds of beef sausages (onion with lemongrass, minced, and grilled beef), a giant steamed beef ball, and a few delicious chips, which we just kept on rolling and eating.

To calm our senses down the beef porridge with scallions, ginger and peanuts was light and it reminded my friend's grandma's dish.

In addition to the 2 beef course orders, we also had the BBQ chicken with rice cakes, which we also rolled them with rice paper. It was really delicious as I can taste the nice lemongrass in it.

Every dish was very delicious, fresh and tasty.

Service was phenomenal. The server/owner was like a teacher from the mountains, firm and delightful instructions while we tried to keep straight faces without laughing. At one point he said more food was coming as he was taking away the hot pot.

We had so much food left that I took a big box leftover home. They were so nice to also give extra containers for the fish sauce and hot sauce.

Highly recommended for anyone who loves beef, a handcraft experience that will make the food even more enjoyable.
author: T L.

description:
Went there for the Seven Courses of Beef. I was surprised by how big the restaurant was. It was pretty empty when we first went in but soon filled up. The place is mostly Asians, which always bodes well for the restaurant. 

The waiters were very helpful on how to make the wraps. The portions are pretty big and we ended up with leftovers. Definitely will come back with friends and share this experience with them. 

On a side note, I tried the 7 course of beef at Pagolac and thought this was better.
author: Alice W.

description: Came here just to hv something quick while I wait for my friends. We had four but I was the only one who wanted to eat something. My friends ordered dessert n drinks. But they told us everyone have to order. So we left.. Never had I been told to order certain stuff at a restaurant.
author: Wai Hei C.

description:
Bò 7 Món (7 Courses of Beef)!  Tasty, filling and I enjoyed every savory course.  My Vietnamese friend told me that the beef courses here are very authentic.  

1.  Beef salad
2.  Beef carpaccio to boil and roll in rice paper
3.  Beef meatballs
4.  Grilled beef sausages (these were excellent)
5.  Grilled minced beef wrapped in piper lot leaf
6.  Grilled beef wrapped around onions and lemongrass
7.  Beef porridge

The seven courses are also accompanied by rice paper, lettuce, herbs, cucumber, bean sprouts, carrots, daikon, chili and two kinds of fish sauce.

Those looking to hop on the once popular Atkins Diet might want to make their first meal here.  It will be a good one.
author: Erich D.

description: Worst service I've had. No greeting at all. Servers were just way to serious. Saw a menu item on yelp. Asked for it. They didn't have it and was rude about it. Felt so uncomfortable. Honestly felt as if the waiter was talking bad about us. Definitely will not be coming back ever again.
author: Dexter C.

description:
This is a 0 star review.

Why? Because both of us got sick after we ate there. Does not matter how "good" the food is, if is DIRTY, and it makes you SICK. You should not be eating there.

ALSO. Possibly the WORST customer service ever. No, seriously. See it for yourself.
author: Moto B.

description:
Count em.. 1, 2... 3, 4, 5, 6!!!! and just when you've got yourself a solid little plushy meat baby, SEVEN!!! COURSES!!!!...OF...BEEF!!!

Omgolly...

1= Beef salad- cooked beef, carrots, daikon, celery, onions, herbs, and peanuts tossed in peanut dressing

2= Rare beef carpaccio in hot pot

3= Beef pate- beefy meatballs with nuts, mushrooms, and vietnamese spices, served with shrimp chips

4= Beef sausage- moist and flavorful

5= Beef wrapped in lemongrass- was dry and chewy

6= Beef wrapped in leaf- MY FAV!! Nomnomnomnom

7= Beef "jook"/porridge- lots of green onions and ginger, runny= let's call this dessert

Comes with:
three different sauces: hot, shrimp, and fish
Green veggies: cilantro, mint, basil, lettuce
Misc: carrots, daikon, and bean sprouts
Rice paper
Bowl of warm water for dipping rice paper

Make it an interactive night: make a salad, make a taco, make a burrito, eat, repeat. BEEF, ITS WHATS FOR DINNER.

Note:
I've been to Pagoloc too, which wins for quality and ambiance. They can take foreverr and a minute for the whole service though, where they wait for you to finish a course before serving the next. Anh Hong serves MORE BEEF and busts it out fairly quickly.
author: Angela W.

description:
Most people have never tried 7 courses of beef, but it's one of my favorite parts of Vietnamese cuisine.

I would highly recommend the baby beef sausages wrapped in Hawaiian leaves (Bo La Lot) and the thinly sliced Beef Carpaccio (I've never had better anywhere else and didn't dare try this raw beef when I went to Vietnam). Everything is quite delicious. Although I'm not a fan of the oily meats that you grill by yourself, it's quite delicious when you put into the roll and will order it when there are many people at the table. Also a must get is the shrimp rolls wrapped in sugar canes (you can suck the juice out of the sugar canes afterwards as a sweet treat)!

This place is a must come if you like healthy veggies and tasty meats cooked in several different flavors. Veggies are unlimited.

Service can be pretty bad if you don't speak Vietnamese and especially if they are crowded on a busy Friday night. Make sure you make a reservation if you're planning to come during primetime.
author: Farrah N.

description:
I'm kicking myself while asking, "Why, Why, Why have I waited so long to try the 7 beef course?"  Omg, these Vietnamese wraps are ABSO-F*NLUTELY DELICIOUSO!!  My new food obsession!

So you take a wrap, soften it in some hot water, layer on some lettuce, veggies, the meat of your choice, cilantro, basil, mint, and then roll away.  Dip it into some sauce (my favorite was the fish & hot sauce mixed together) and get ready to give your taste buds a whole lotta lovin!

It's healthy, hella fresh, affordable, and in my case, totally addictive!

Word of caution:  these take a bit of work b/c you have to make every single roll, which I didn't mind at all.  My husband on the other hand...  Let's just say I had to make both of ours :)

I want to eat these everyday until I get sick of them!

How glad am I that Anh Hong has location in LA?  I just hope they are as good as the one in SF.
author: Seung Eun C.

description:
A friend celebrated his birthday here and a large group of us partook in a good number of dishes:

* raw beef salad (tasty and fresh!)
* egg rolls with vermicelli (yums)
* Bo Nuong La Lot -- which loosely translates to yummylicious baby beef sausages
* grill your own beef
* sugar cane wrapped in  shrimp  (thank God the guy next to me showed me how to eat this. You have to cut the shrimp off the sugar cane. Dip the rice paper in the steaming hot water until it is soft, place the rice paper on your mini plate, place the shrimp meat in the softened rice paper, then pile on the veggies and wrap. Gnaw on the sugar cane later for dessert!)
* Large prawn heads

I was about to pop and couldn't even try the prawn heads but everything was yummy, fresh and healthy, and satisfying and very different from my usual pho, bbq vermicelli, and fresh spring roll orders.
author: Patricia M.

description: Best Vietnamese restaurant in town. 7 course beef or Bo Nhung Dam is highly recommended.
author: Vy T.

description:
The most authentic Vietnamese food I've had since moving to SF from San Jose (land of Vietnamese food). My girlfriend and I wanted to try 7 course beef because together, we are like two vultures eating our way through life. Her mom and friends were visiting from Japan, so we were given the opportunity to check out Anh Hong. I haven't had the 7 course beef since I was 12 years old (gave up meat in college). So it was a new experience for me. 

We were seated family style and served Vietnamese beer and tea. I ordered in Vietnamese thinking that they wouldn't try to get us to over-order. I can't even remember what/how I ordered but the food came out swimmingly. 

Beef salad, Beef carpaccio, Grilled beef wrapped in lot leaf, Grilled beef stuffed with onions and lemongrass, Grilled beef sausages, Steamed beef meatball with shrimp chips and Beef porridge. As a side we ordered the sugar cane shrimp as well as spring rolls and vermicelli. 

Everything was excellent. $18 for 1 person. We ordered a little under 6 servings. Bring a large group with you when trying this place out. You'll walk out so full, you'll have food coma.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I made the mistake of coming here on my own for a quick meal. I had no idea what the menu was like, and now after reading Yelp reviews, I realize why the staff was so confused as to why I was eating in by myself.
