For those of you thinking this place might be good for some pho - just stop. This place does not have pho! Coming from a complete Vietnamese food n00b, I really don't know what type of Vietnamese food to call it. There were a variety of cook-for-yourself platters, and it seemed like almost everyone was getting the 7 course beef menu. It looked good -- too bad I wasn't that hungry and didn't know what I was doing.

I ended up getting the spring rolls and the combination platter with beef and chicken. It definitely wasn't the greatest meal I've ever had, but given that this wasn't really their specialty, I can't really fault them for it.

Next time, I'll come back with an empty stomach and some friends to chow on that 7 course beef menu to see if it lives up to all of it's Yelp hype!
author: Alison C.

description: I'm never one to write bad reviews, but this place is awful. The waiter wasn't friendly to start. I ordered the grilled beef platter. "Beef" looked and tasted like day old sausage, even the rice was bad. Too many good spots around here.
author: Blake S.

description: Very bad experience !!!!! No customer service at all ... From the beginning I sat down and I asked for tea...!!! But nothing comes up till I done dinner !!!! And food is so so ... Not so good !!!
author: Jackie L.

description: Whenever I am in San Francisco, I like to stop here when I can for their seven courses of beef.  Yes, it is exactly how it sounds.  Beef served seven different ways with rice paper, lettuce and various herbs.  There is a beef salad that is not heavy in the beef.  It is a nice light salad to start.  There is beef fondue, three different beef sausages, a beef meat ball and beef porridge.  I also order their shrimp wrapped around sugar cane, young coconut juice and egg rolls.  You can use the rice paper to roll your own spring rolls.  It is a lot of fun if you like to eat with your hands and great for groups.  Just keep in mind it is not in the best neighborhood and your typical Asian hole in the wall atmosphere.  If you can handle that, you'll like it.  I've brought many people here and everyone has liked it.
author: Sivilay H.

description: Wow, I was so impressed with the service that I felt compelled to write this review. Our party of four arrived at about 5pm on a Sunday. The place was pretty empty and we were seated at a nice table for six, lots of elbow room. I was craving bò 7 món, so we ordered 2 portions. Also ordered the bò nuong vi, beef cooked on a grill, and the shrimp wrapped around sugar cane. The food came out at a well measured pace. Totally hit my craving on the spot! When we needed more veggies or tea, our waiters responded quickly. It was great! We all wondered if we were really in a Vietnamese restaurant. BTW, by the time we left at 6:30, the place was packed and it was just a little harder to catch our server's attention. Nothing to complain about though. Will definitely come back.
author: Tam V.

description:
You only come here to eat 7 course beef, and if you come with a vegetarian then you're a dumbass who didn't do your homework.
Okay, now that i've gotten that out of the way....

They're larger than Pagolac with more tables. 
I enjoyed every course of the 7 course beef but I suck at rolling my own rolls. Yes, i'm a chinawoman that can make egg rolls, potstickers, won tons, and various dim sum from scratch but I suck with those rice paper rolls!
author: Susy C.

description: My wife and I enjoyed their 7 Courses of Beef. The food was plentiful and tasty. The waiter even demonstrated how to create a rice paper roll. Service was fast and friendly. I wish that I could find Vietnamese food this good close to home.
author: Carl W.

description: Ate here tonight. Ordered 7 course beef.  Server recommend we order more food because he thought we ordered 'light' but we had tons of left overs. Overall service was slow and incomplete. Food was 6 out of 10. Would not repeat.
author: Jeff I.

description:
Note: Review solely based on service, NOT food (since I didn't eat here).

Called in 1.5 weeks  in advance to make reservations for a party of ~15. The guy on the phone said that everything was ready to go (had my name, number, time, and party size down). I even asked if it was okay to bring in a cake, and he said sure. I thought how awesome!

Called in a week before the date of the dinner to cancel the reservations since we decided to eat elsewhere closer to where we will be. The guy couldn't even find my name on the reservations list. UH.... nice going. If we had actually come for our dinner, that means we wouldn't have our table at the time we reserved it for. I'm glad we decided to choose elsewhere to eat! Thanks, but no thanks. Bad service much?

2 stars solely for no cake fee.
author: Michelle L.

description: This was the first Anh Hong restaurant and I used to come here with my Vietnamese friends who taught me how to do 7 courses of beef right!  Since then I like to bring my other friends and colleagues for this awesome experience here.  The menu is slightly different than Berkeleys -- they do shabu shabu with the sliced beef here, where Berkeley does carpaccio.  Both are good.  The SF restaurant is more plain and not as nice as Berkeley, but the service is still pretty decent.  Food is consistently good and I always love their sugar cane shrimp with purple perilla.
author: Yoshiko D.

description:
Large and roomy inside. It felt very authentic since some of the waiters had a hard time understanding what we wanted.

Vietnamese ice coffee is delicious! We had three of us dining, and were allowed to share one order of the 7 course beef (which was a hell of a lot of food already). It was my first time trying this kind of meal and it was delicious.

Also got the fried rolls and they were delicious!

Would recommend to friends. You know it's legit when your salon manicurist vouches for it too!
author: Jeanne C.

description: Not in the best part of town to say the least, but this joint still serves up some of the best food in the city regardless of price.  I've taken friends and relatives to this place, and they all loved it.  In fact, some of them became regulars like us, despite the trouble it takes to get here and park.
author: Dave N.

description: They are famous for there 7 courses beef.  It comes with a bunch of fresh vegetable and rice paper to roll your meal.  This is the place for all the CARNIVORES.  It is simple DELIOUS!  I always order the vermicelli plate cause I need some carb to go with my meat.  Please remember not to make the roll to big or you won't be able to end the roll.
author: Jess T.

description: I always wanted to try the beef 7 courses from here but its only ok and a bit disapointed.  It was not that great and the first dish, beef salad doesnt look like they have beef in there, the beef looks like pork and taste like pork too. The server didnt introduce every dish that he put down on our table.
author: Teresa C.

description:
GO BIG OR GO HOME. That saying has never rung more true for me than at Anh Hong.  I stopped by Anh Hong to try their egg rolls and raw beef salad, and I ended up ordering the 7 courses of beef... BY MYSELF. In hindsight, it was pretty embarassing to sit there... alone... as course after course came and filled up my table.  However, at the time, I was too busy eating to care. 

The 7 course beef dinner at Anh Hong is served with rice paper (and a bowl hot water to rehydrate the wrapping yourself), lettuce, mixed herbs, cucumber, bean sprouts, pickled carrots and daikon.  Aside from the first and last courses (salad and porridge), all these condiments are used to wrap up each course of beef.  

1. Beef salad: slices of cooked beef, daikon, celery, onions, herbs and peanuts in a light vinaigrette. My least favorite course. The beef had a lackluster white appearance and was a bit tough.   

2. Beef carpaccio: raw slices of beef that you cook in a broth. This was pretty good. The broth was vinegar-based and gave the beef a interesting acidic component. 

3-6 were various kinds of sausages served on one plate (a grilled beef sausage wrapped in lot leaf, grilled beef rolls mixed with lemongrass and onions, grilled beef sausages, and steamed meat balls). I let out a few audible gasps during this course. These were FANTASTIC! Everything was perfectly seasoned, tender, and juicy. My favorite item was the grilled sausages in lot leaf. 

7. Beef rice porridge: This was just ok. Vietnamese rice porridge is not thick and gelatinous like Chinese congee. It was more like broken rice in a beef broth. It was a simple way to end a heavy, meaty meal. 

Overall: I was really happy with the indulgent 7-course beef dinner at Anh Hong. After having been to Pagolac, I definitely recommend Anh Hong over Pagolac. While Pagolac may have a better ambiance, Anh Hong's beef courses were more memorable.
author: Monelle A.

description:
BANG FOR YOUR BUCK!

7 course beef!!

Meat overload.

Do not come if you're on a diet.

Nom nom nom!
author: Dorothy L.

description:
I am a Vietnamese.  I am also a foodie so I recommend you listen to my review as I know what good Vietnamese is supposed to taste like. 

The only thing I see good at this particular location (this is a chain Vietnamese restaurant - the one in Milpitas so much better!) is the beef cooked 7 ways (the steamed beef is gross so don't bother, ask them to get you more of the other beef dishes). This particular dish is very good. It's so annoying as it is a 50:50 chance that they will even have it available. For this I want to give them 2 stars.  There is a common theme here: SUGAR, to overwhelm the taste buds so they don't have to use MSG... I'm a cook so I know the tricks.

All soups - They literally add sugar so it's "sweet". It's so overwhelming that I can't tell if the broth is really good or not. 

Banh Hoi - 4 stars but for the price, you get literally 8 thin slices of very sweet meat and 6 little patties of noodles with vegetables to wrap.

Rice Plates - Small portions served on HUGE fancy platters to appear like there is a lot of food but it's purely presentation. The meat marinade is loaded with sugar so if you like your meat "Korean BBQ" sweet, this place is it... 3 stars

Cleanliness - although the place is nice, they don't seem to sweep/mop/dust. If you look closely, it's so gross so imagine their kitchen. I wouldn't care so much if it was a hole in the wall, but they try to be this fancy-ish place.
author: Giang N.

description:
Ahhhhh, finally...I don't have to spend 2 hours chopping, dicing, and grilling in my kitchen to eat delicious banh trang (DIY spring roll wraps).  I didn't try the 7 courses of beef but it looks pretty bomb.  Maybe next time.

I stuck to the a la carte menu and ordered beef w/ lemongrass (grill it yourself at the table) and beef sausages wrapped in "la lot" leaves (pepper leaves).  I could eat spring roll wraps every day and die happy.

Major caveat though: do NOT bring vegetarians to this restaurant.  There are literally no vegetarian items on the menu.  You'll have to go to the Berkeley location.
author: Priscilla T.

description: you know exactly what youre gonna get!  always consistent! always good!  no PHO, but def a one of a kind experience and food that you cant get anywhere else!
author: howard c.

description:
I went to Anh Hong for the 7 courses of beef. Everything came family style and they even doubled up 2 courses on one plate, so that made it feel like a regular dinner where people are just ordering too many beef dishes. The courses included a simple beef salad, beef carpaccio that we cooked in a hot pot, beef rolls wrapped in a lot leaf, grilled beef rolls with onions and lemongrass (my fav of the courses), beef sausage (I liked that this came with shrimp chips), beef meatballs, and beef porridge (this was a tad salty).

Everything tasted decent and it was really filling, but nothing was memorable. It also bothered me that dishes 3-6 were so similar. For $20 it was worth trying and a fun experience but I'm not sure I'll go back anytime soon.
author: Alice J.

description:
Some of the dishes were not made very authentic:

*Beef carpaccio (bo tai chanh): Pieces of meet were all stuck together.  The top lacked the usual garnish (ie fried onions, etc) which usually makes this appetizer a real treat! 
*Shrimp wrapped in sugar cane: The piece of sugar cane was overly sized.  Usually its about half of the size!

Service was okay.  The entire seven course beef wasn't bad, although I have to say I've had better.
author: Tramy V.

description: Most people come for the seven-course beef, as did we. It's about $20/ person, but we only ordered 4 for the 6 of us (plus a toddler), which was plenty. My favorite course was the beef salad and the beef porridge. I thought it might be too much meat (and only meat), but there is actually a nice balance because they give you a lot of veggies on the side. Keep in mind that each type of beef sausage counts as a course; we were waiting for the last two courses without knowing that it already came!
author: Allison S.

description: I come here for the 7 course beef, beef carpaccio and fried Imperial rolls. Always a lovely time - eating with your hands and plenty of fish sauce.
author: Allison C.

description:
What a surprise: this innoculus looking corner restaurant with worn out business graphics, serves up some delicious food. 4 stars for the food and 3 for the slow refill of my water; but read on.

I have tried many kinds of Vietnamese food but for some reason, never the 7 Courses of Beef; yes, it is called by that moniker. It was tastey and a feast.

It's a huge amount of food; beef served barbequed 4 diff. ways with differing spices, 
an interesting ground beef spiced and steamed and a salad of shredded fruit with very thin slices of boiled beef and the soup. Four different kinds of leafy veggies. And a plate of very thinly sliced raw beef for dipping in the cauldron they will put on your table. Plenty of rice papers for dipping in hot water; here's how you do it: after you dip it for 15 seconds,(make sure it is thoroughly wet) place it on your plate and fill it with various pieces of veggies and or BBQ'd meat; then wrap it all snug and dip in one of the various sauces. I liked the pineapple sauce best, mixed with some red chili. The fish sauce was ok, but second place for me.
The last round is a delicious rice soup with bits of beef and ginger; very soothing for the stomach. You better be hungry, cuz it's feast: big enough for man, but made for a woman! =)

 I could go on and on; look it up on line. Better yet, drop in for The 7 Courses of Beef.

 Tip: if you are allergic to peanuts, be sure to specify no peanuts. 
Good fresh quality for everything, about $85 for three.

Customer service: fine, except for my water was only refilled once.
Can get noisy with families and kids happily noshing away.

Parking: tough, tip: drive up hill one block and turn right or left, usually there is parking. Free on Sundays, I think. Sketchy area after sundown.


Bathrooms: very clean.
author: Bert K.

description:
About 3.5 stars, but definitely not a 4 after my last experience here.

I've been coming here for years for their 7 course beef and sugar cane shrimp.  Food wise, it taste a lot better and more authentic than it's other 7 course beef competitor in the TL and I often love taking "first timers" here.  Only grip I have is that too bad they don't have their raw beef salad as one of their 7 courses, that would be awesome!  I keep coming back for their food, but as for their service, I can understand why some customers won't come back. 

I don't expect much service when I come to a restaurant like this, definitely nothing fancy so it is normally not a deal breaker for me to come here.  What I don't like is pushy waiters that try to make you order more, first time is ok, but when you keep on insisting, it just gets annoying!!  Their 7 course beef is huge for one person to finish so generally, one order is enough to feed 1 1/2 - 2 people.  I came with 3 others and started off the night w/ an order of eggrolls (which is somewhat costly - $10) and 2 orders of the 7-course beef with a bunch of side dishes (bun, banh hoi, etc).  Waiter gave us a nasty look and told us we needed to order more.  We were definitely  planning to but haven't decided on the others dishes yet, which started the whole pushiness.  He started to give us grief + attitude that we were taking so long to order the other dishes.  It just got very annoying and it didn't help that he was not smiling at all throughout the night.

He finally warmed up a little towards the end of the night and actually said "you're welcome" after the 15+ thank yous we said each time he brought stuff to us or picked up empty dishes from our table.

Not sure when the next time I'll be back here, but I highly doubt it'll be any time soon.  That's too bad too since I often crave 7 course beef.

P.S. - For some reason, I don't recall them charging for tea before, but they do now.  Not sure if it is per person or per pot, but they refilled our hot water once and 2 hot tea showed up on our bill.  Not a big deal, price was fairly minimal, but I just thought it was odd.
author: Janetto L.

description:
ORDERED: 7 Course Beef Menu

I dont get why its so special. I can eat a lot but the 7 course flavor seem repetitive. The thai ice tea was also too sweet. The service was subpar, if we are the only table left in the restaurant, I feel I should be able to get the check quicker than 10 mins.
author: Jess H.

description:
This was my first time having the 7 course beef - it looked like most people in the restaurant ordered it, and about 99% of those customers were Vietnamese so how could we not? In actuality I was a little disappointed - I didn't know what to expect, but the portions were small (albeit filling) and the cooked pork (courses 3-6) tasted and looked like something I've made before so nothing amazing. I expected at least one course to be the raw beef salad I've had at other Vietnamese restaurants, but was disappointed that none of them were.

I would be interested in trying other restaurants' versions of the 7 courses.
author: Leily P.

description:
I came here with 6 other friends for the 7 Courses of Beef after much hype. Luckily, it mostly lived up to my expectations!

Here's my review on each of the 7 courses: 

1. Goi Bo - Beef Salad (Sliced Beef, Carrot, Daikon, Celery,
Onions, Herbs and Peanuts Tossed in Lemon Dressing)

The beef salad was one of the best in the 7 (although the slices of meat didn't look exactly like beef) and had a great flavor.

2. Bo Tai Chanh - Beef Carpaccio (Slices of Rare Beef in Taùi Chanh Sauce) 

#2 was the most fun to eat - First, we got wraps which we dipped in bowls of warm water to soften. Next, we cooked the slices of beef in a boiling pot of water (similar to a fondue pot / hot pot). Then, we wrapped the beef, along with veggies, in the wraps. I also loved the dipping sauces. I wish we got more of this one!

3. Bo La Lop - Grilled Beef Lot Leaf (Grilled Minced Beef Wrapped in "Piper Lolot" Leaf)

4. Bo Nuong Xa - Grilled Beef Lemongrass (Grilled Beef Rolls with Onions and Lemongrass)

5. Bo Mô Chai - Beef sausage (Grilled Beef Sausages)

#3, 4, and 5 looked and tasted somewhat similar (I can't quite remember which one was which), but they were all pretty good. I'd recommend wrapping them in lettuce and using the dipping sauces (since the flavor can get a bit salty / heavy after a bit)

6. Bo Cha Dum - Beef Meat Balls (Steamed Beef Meat Balls)

This one was popular and consisted of giant meatballs. ....Not my personal fave out of the 7 but definitely not bad.

7. Chao Bo - Beef Porridge (Beef Rice Porridge with ginger and peanuts)

The porridge was delicious. I wish I knew how to make this at home. Too bad it came at the end - by then I was already full, but I still got seconds!

Minus one star for service - I had to call for a waiter and ask more than once to get my water refilled, and they were a bit slow in bringing out some of the dishes / drinks.  Ambiance is typical Asian home-style restaurant  when I went (loud, a little bit crowded, kids running around) which could be both a good/bad thing. 

Overall, I liked it.  I'd come back to have the 7 courses of beef again and to try some of their desserts, although I'd be curious to see how Anh Hong stacks up against other similar places.
author: Sarah T.

description:
They only deserve One star for the service and 4 stars for the food.  I was there last night for dinner with my husband and friends for our monthly foodie group adventure.  I have not been there in years so was looking forward to great company and food.  

Service:
Service was awful.  The first course came of Beef Fondue arrived with the rice paper.  They provided a bowl of hot water for you to dip the rice paper to rehydrate to make your roll.  Since the water was REALLY hot and I did not want to burn my fingers; I was doing my way of re-hydrating the rice paper.  The waiter stood behind me and said I was doing it wrong.  He threw the rice paper I had on to the side of the table and use his OWN fingers to help me.  I don't know where your hand/fingers have been nor if you washed them in between our table and kitchen.  He stepped on my friend's foot and didn't apologized at all for that.  Really?  Where are your manners?  
When we finally finished our meal and the bill arrived, we were trying to figure out how much for reach person.  As we were gathering our money, the two waiters were standing by our table with their arms folded like they were bouncers at a club.  REALLY???  You think we will skip the bill and run?  Come on... I might return for the food but not sure about the service.   I hope the owner will read the review and hopefully they will improve their services.
author: Jan S.

description:
If you're really hungry for some 7 course beef, this is definitely the place to stuff your face!  I came here with Lester W. and our non-Yelper friend, Mike.  

We happened to go at the perfect time to beat the dinner rush.  We were seated promptly, and the food came out very fast.  The service was excellent.  They constantly refilled our veggies and wraps.  Once the dinner rush hit, service was a bit slower, but that's understandable....at least we already had our food!

We all ordered the 7 Course Beef, and it was ALOT of food!  Dinner consisted of the following:
-Beef Salad ( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/Ua8cHlMkBNKb8N5R4LGbgg/l )
-Beef Carpaccio ( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/SjLp6KTIj53Xu96Ye--Wcg/l ) which we cooked in this neat little contraption  ( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/EYFeltAwcEwAyHDKd-Ah7Q/l )
-Grilled Beef Lot Leaf, Grilled Beef Lemongrass, Beef sausage, Beef Meat Balls ( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/lr1NwegyxquhQwXyYmwl6g/l )
-Beef Porridge ( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/DAnhFsKiyrz3U-2OjiCjGA/l )

I like eating 7 Course Beef because of all the veggies.  I feel healthier eating all those veggies even though the meat probably isn't that great for you.  My favorite couses were the Beef Carpaccio, Beef Sausage and Beef Meat Balls.  There was so much food, we couldn't even eat it all.  Even our non-Yelper friend couldn't finish it, and that boy can eat!  This was the first time I've asked for a togo box for 7 Course Beef!

The only down side is the fish sauce.  We went out after, and I had fish sauce burps all night.  *buuuurp*
author: Patra I.

description:
7 courses of beef is like 6 minute abs in reverse.  And while I recommend both ab work and beef work, I'm not sure Anh Hong is the best place for either.  Yes, you'll get your 7 courses beef and ultimately leave satisfied, but you may be unimpressed compared to the competition up the street at Pagolac.  They smile more, pace the meal better, routinely replenish the hot dipping water and veggies, offer a do-it-yourself grilling course in place of Anh Hong's gnarly pate course, and all-around whoop Anh Hong's ass in the first beef salad course.    

So, in summary: I enjoyed my meal and the damage it did to my finely toned abs, but Pagolac is altogether in a different league than Anh Hong when it comes to Beef 7 Ways.
author: Laurence W.

description:
I thought this place was really great.  
It's fairly basic, nothing special on the inside..,but it's got table clothes and stuff..so it's trying. I felt really comfortable. The people that work there are super friendly and laid back. I never felt rushed or anything. 

I liked the interactive approach to the food...everything involved putting something together or building your own little meal... I liked that. It was super fun and the food was delicious. :) 

I'll be going back.
author: Dayna E.

description:
if u have 5 people, order 3 (7 course beef), 1 raw beef, 1 shrimp on sugar cane ( I personally think its OK).  

That should be plenty of food.  Not each person needs to order a "7course beef"
author: Anna W.

description:
I love this place!

Raw beef salad = awesome
Shrimp and Pork Salad = Refreshing
Shrimp w/ sugarcane = Can't get any better
The beef sausage thing = omg!
Fish sauce = F**kin awesome

This place is so good, it's basically Vietnamese food that you kinda prepare yourself.  They give you lots of veggies and you order whatever meat you want and then you make your very own spring roll (rice paper is given).  It's a little bit of work but its so good.

The only flaw of this place is the fact that it's hard to find parking in the area of which they're located at.
author: Mimi P.

description:
Five stars for the restaurant that shares the same fabulous name as me! And I guess the food is pretty awesome too, haha.

If you think Vietnamese food is just pho, then you need to come here and experience the real deal! We had the papaya salad, the raw beef in vinegar, egg rolls, and 2 different kinds of beef sausage and beef (that you cook yourself on the table) for wraps. Everything was soooooo tasty and satisfying. It's a fun dining experience since you're involved in cooking & prepping your food -- coming in a group is suggested. It's really affordable too -- we were able to try a variety of food and at $25 a person, we were stuffed.

I love Anh Hong (the restaurant, but I guess I love myself too haha)!


(Pictures posted)
author: Miss H.

description:
Been going here since they opened and still think it's the best spot for 7 courses of beef in the East Bay. I love that they give you the option of just 3 courses, with the 3 types of beef sausages, since those usually end up being my favorites anyways. 

Love the various carpaccio plates they offer with the beef and salmon being my favorites. 

The quality of the meat, rice paper, and the fresh veggies always brings me back to this place and the prices are very reasonable IMO. 

Service is sometimes spotty here, but for the most part everyone was friendly, and brought out all of our food quickly and frequently asked if we had any questions. The only let down was on the refills of our water.
author: Phuoc K.

description:
My friend invited me to participate in eating 7 courses of beef with her. I was all over it. MEAT. I like activities like rolling 5 different types of beef in rice paper. The first course was a delicious pickled carrot and daikon (radish) salad with shredded beef and last was a type of congee/porridge with beef. The middle 5 involved a giant meatball and 4 types of beef in sausage form.  Everyting tasted good and for $18/person it's not a bad deal because we were STUFFED. I definitely had a large food baby after that meal. The reason this place doesn't get more stars is the service and the atmosphere. Service was slow...and I don't mean the pace. The atmosphere is also a bit on the ghetto side. 

Just a note: I hear Paglaoc is the other Vietnamese place that does the 7 course beef and I think there option is a bit cheaper. I'll have to check it out to do a proper assessment.
author: Debbie C.

description: They are closed often when they claim to be open an hour or two before their posted closing or after their posted opening times. I guess a management change has diminished their quality. Used to be good even excellent, but now definitely a miss.
author: Dean N.

description:
Happy Birthday to ME!!!  Thanks to my friends for taking me out to celebrate with Bò 7 món!!!  What a very painful (b/c my dress felt tight afterwards), but pleasant surprise.  

Actually, this was not my first experience with 7-course beef, my dear friend Daniel Le (of Re:Charge Medical & Day Spa) brought me here for our FIRST dinner together.

What I love about this restaurant, it brings people TOGETHER to bond over good food, conversation (and in my case LOTS OF LAUGHTER).  Seriously.  Friends, family and casual acquaintances  gather here and just enjoy the family-eating type of experience.

The service here is EFFICIENT.  They don't waste time with pleasantries.  If you don't understand WHAT TO DO, THEN ASK.  Or, go with someone WHO KNOWS what to do!  Or, if you're adventurous, like me, just MAKE IT UP *hahaha*...

Of course, the first time that I came here with Daniel, I didn't know how to wrap anything!  I also had this thing about using my hands to make any rolls.  It was a MESS and I took forever, so Daniel actually had to take over.  We talked and laughed and talked...

Tonight was no different.

If you never have had 7-course beef, here is the Wiki Link for what to expect:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%B2_7_m%C3%B3n 

I love that the restaurant employees didn't rush us and they let us be total Asians and steal the extra-veggies to go with our leftovers...

Oh and they were sweet and let my friends bring in an outside birthday cake.

Lots of love to this restaurant and to my friends.
author: Hiromi N.

description: Go to the Berkeley location instead. This location has a much smaller menu and the service could be much better. Once we were finished with our meal we had to ask for our check three times and wait 45 minutes for it!
author: Courtney L P.

description: It was fine.  Nothing great or amazing about the food, it was fine.  I was there at 5:00 on Sun. and one other couple was in the restaurant.  It took me 45 mins to get my to go order of rib/chicken combo.  I also ordered soup but they "forgot" and told me it would take another 10-15 mins; so I passed.  This is the beginning of Little Vietnam; go another couple of blocks and there are fabulous choice where you will want to go back.  Even though this is 1 block from my apt, not returning.
author: Dee H.

description:
Seven 7 Courses of Beef (bo mon). Just the name alone sold me.

For $18,95 pp, you get the following:

1) beef salad - loved it! totally refreshing with shredded daikon, carrots, and sprouts.
2) thin beef slices - served in a vinegar broth, you should quickly eat this as it cooks super fast in the hot soup.

The next 4 items are all served together on a plate. They are all made with ground beef, seasoned different ways. I liked them since they all had different flavors.
3) beef wrapped in leaf (kind of like a dolma but full of ground beef)
4) beef rolled around lemongrass
5) beef sausages
6) beef meat balls
7) beef porridge - nice hot, and honestly by this course, I was so stuffed I could barely eat half of it. But it was gold, with ginger notes.

Everything is served with fresh vegetables: rice paper, lettuce leaves, carrots, sliced cucumbers, daikon, sprouts, fresh mint, basil, and other Vietnamese herbs. You roll everything inside the rice paper and dip it in the sweet tangy fish sauce, and just EAT! It's filling but you feel good eating all these veggies.

We were greedy and even ordered the Chao Tom ($13.50), which are shrimp paste balls wrapped around sugar canes. You get 3 of them along with rice noodles and a side daikon salad. You're supposed to cut up the shrimp and size them down to fit your spring rolls that you make. Those were good too but honestly with the 2 of us, the 7 courses of beef would have been plenty.

Such a great experience. Gotta try it. Come with clean hands and get ready to get dirty!
author: Cindy W.

description:
I was here last weekend for dinner with 2 other friends. Great food and excellent service. Yes, it was a lot of fun, cooking our own food! We had ordered too much food however; we ended up having to take the rice claypot dish home... 

We ordered:
1 order of the 7-course beef
Rice claypot - Can't remember the name

We took a short walk to Union Square, before headed back to our car. Looking forward to coming back for another meal!
author: Annette L.

description:
I LOVE this place.

I never come here without getting:

Crab & Asparagus Soup
Spring Rolls
Bo Nuang Xa (Beef Wrapped Around Onion & Lemongrass)
Bo Mo Chai (Grilled Beef Sausage)
Beef Carpaccio

Everything here is generally amazing. All meats are so savory and great quality. It gets super busy around dinner time with lots of groups. The service isn't always the best, but the amazing food makes up for it. The veggies are always fresh, and they are pretty generous with all dishes.
author: Natasha S.

description:
I had seven courses of beef for the first time in my entire life the other day here at Anh Hong.  I'm a Huynh, but barely Vietnamese.  I can't wrap very well but I try.. even if my rolls don't look good, they taste good!

Anywho, my favorite was the beef stuffed with onion.  Mmmm yumm.  Minus points for giving us lots of rice paper that was damaged, and forgetting about our table.  Also had the shrimp cake with sugar cane.. very yummy.

It seems like people come to Anh Hong to show off their new babies.  My table was sandwiched between two tables with babies and tons of relatives and parents (including a dad with very hideous Armani Exchange sweater and a set of boobs) cooing and gaga-ing with the babies.  Ugh!  Give the babies a damn break and eat your rolls!
author: Vivian H.

description:
This place was good! But the service rubbed us the wrong way.

First about the food. It was SOOOO good! We did not know that you did not HAVE to order the 7 course beef for EACH person...I guess it makes sense...it's not a all you can eat...just portions...But anyways the food was really good...and it kept coming..it was cheap and delicious! Anyways...if you have a table of 4 just order 3 of the 7 course beef. If its more girls...maybe just half the orders..get my drift....4 guys....4 orders!

What rubbed my friends and I the wrong way was that...we got a shrimp and noodle dish which was mistakenly given to us...We did not read the menu so we did not know what the courses came with...So we did take a second thought and just ate it....When we got the bill we got charged for another $14 extra...We were like, "we never ordered that" the response was, "we gave it to you by mistake and when the waiter came back to take it back...we already ate it....", why didnt they stop us or tell us in advance and just try to sneek it in our bill? The guy behind the counter gave my friend grief about it..then my other friend explained the story and they comped us...

Yes we did eat it...but it was their mistake, we honestly did not know and assumed it came with the meal.
author: Brendan L.

description:
My preferred restaurant for 7-course beef. Yes...the decor is not as nice as Pagolac...but the food tastes better and the portions are definitely larger.

The restaurant is pretty big so they are able to accommodate large parties. I think I went with a group of about 20 before and it wasn't a problem for them.

I recommend getting 2 orders of the 7-course beef dinner for every 3 people in your party.

...be careful of one of the leaves that they give you with your veggies. It smells and tastes super fishy. Not sure why anyone would want that.
author: Lester W.

description: I would not recommend this place if you don't speak Vietnamese. I loved this place the first time I went with my Vietnamese friend. The workers catered to us and there were no problems. However, the next time I went our group didn't have a vietnamese-speaking person and we waited 10 minutes to even get a menu. We also never got our rice noodles after asking the workers twice. In the end, they still charged us for the noodles.
author: Michelle H.

description:
This is a great place for group. Everybody in the restaurant is so nice, friendly, and funny. There were a lot of people there but it was not so loud - or may be because we were the loudest group (Oops!)

So 13 people of us ordered:
- 8 courses of Seven Courses of Beef.
- 2 courses of Anh Hong egg rolls.
- 2 courses of Ta Bi Lu Nuong Vi.
--- $26/ person including tips.

And they were just enough! The food was well done no complaining!!! I could see the egg rolls were served right away because it was so crunchy and hot.

Really, nothing to complain and we all had a good time.
author: Tran N.

description:
this place was not good at all.  I had the grilled beef rice plate and my pops had the fantastic korean bbq rice plate.  Both entrees were mediocre at best.  The grilled beef had no flavor at all, and the menu in english is deceiving to those who can't read viet.  When i think grilled beef  at a vietnamese restaurant i think of the grilled marinated flank steak, not unmarinated rolled beef bites with white onion.  My roomate tells me yeah grilled beef is one or the other, but it's not specified in the menu, you'd have to know what each type was in vietnamese to not order the wrong one. 
  Anyway this place was over priced for vietnamese food and had no flavor and no Pho. bleh
author: Spencer W.

description:
This is my go-to-spot for bo 7 mon in San Francisco, and while I've had better in the the South Bay, making the 40 minute drive just sometimes isn't in the cards when I can walk here in all of 15 minutes whenever I''m hit with a craving. Like most other casual Vietnamese spots, it makes up for the lack of decor/location with some great food at fairly reasonable prices and surprisingly decent service [tonight one of the waiter's was teaching a first-time couple how to make the perfect roll...pretty funny when he told them the sweet anchovy sauce was "coffee" and then they smelled it...gotta love the crinkled nose look...my wife and I however can drink that sauce like a fishy smoothie - new Jamba Juice flavor perhaps?].

Overall just a fun place where you can actually play with your food, get your hands dirty, and not get yelled at by mom.
author: David H.

description:
one of the best vietnamese food spots in Nor Cal without having to drive all the way down to San Jose!

i had the Kalbi Ribs and rice and wasn't the biggest fan of as it was also served with a side salad and nothing else. kind of teriyaki shop style. but the Bo 7 Mon (seven course beef) was delicious! seems like there was already quite a few reviews on it already and i agree with all of them! excellent! their version of beef tartare was amazing as well!

lacking last star as the staff never seemed to smile and parking can be a bit of a hassle (but that's just the life of san fran)
author: Nam N.

description: My friends rave about this place all the time. They're saying 7 course beef is the way to go. I wasn't feeling all that hungry so I didn't order that. I ordered rare beef with lemon juice to share and the grilled chicken with egg roll and fried rice. The rare beef dish was yummy. The chicken was seasoned nicely. The egg roll was pathetic. It look more like a single small lumpia. The ones that are 1inch long. The fried rice was meh. Service is a hit or miss. I'll be back to try the 7 course beef. This place is okay for now.
author: Jo S.

description:
Incredible! I've been going to the Southern California location for years with my family and it was absolutely refreshing to experience the same high quality dishes at this location. The spices and flavors were perfectly prepared. Plus, the wait staff was very helpful and attentive. I especially love the unpretentious atmosphere. This place is not by any means fancy, but it's authentic and casual. Tip: If you're in a party of 4, consider ordering just 3 portions of the 7 courses. This way, you'll save $$ and have the opportunity to order up an appetizer.

Would I come back? You betcha!!!
author: Lisa R.

description:
If you love that vietnamese "7 courses of beef" (minimum of 2 orders) meal, then go here! It's good to go with a lot of people because there will be a ton of food to go around. It is mouth-watering, and I especially love the spicy shrimp paste/pineapple dipping sauce.

My favorite dish hands down, is the raw beef salad. It's #11 on the menu, I believe.  Raw beef, if you haven't tried it yet is amazing and at Anh Hong, it's even better.
author: kristin e.

description: I and my family, friends there. We loved to eat 7 kinds of beef style. Good Vietnamese food. Have fun there too.
author: Tony H.

description:
Ok so we went to this place many times to eat.  However, on a recent visit, i noticed that they have new people working here.  The woman behind the counter is well, every unprofessional.  We saw her eating a mouthfull behind the counter and not at all interested in helping the customers. 

The food is quite expensive for 7-course beef for sure.  We spent amost 300$ for five people. 

The FIRE is NOT HOT enough to cook the broth for seafood hot pot incase someone is thinking of orderting the seafood dish. 

Not coming back because of the bad service, there are plenty of good vietnamese restaurants in Little Saigon with better service.
author: Truong P.

description:
As a Chinkana WASP, with a passport that confirms I was born in Vietnam, I do not actually speak my "native" tongue. But I am extremely fluent in the international language of delicious family-style consumption of cow. 

So when The Usual Suspects issued a sameday invite to a chow-down at Anh Hong, I was definitely in! While not officially a UYE, the lucky baker's dozen of us were Yelpers... but we took very few pictures (Thanks, Tammy C.)! 

The East Bay (OAKLANDISH) contingent decided to carpool, and I'm going to blame (a) the wonky directions that Google Maps gave me; (b) the fact that my kick-ass navigation system hasn't been installed yet; (c) my Asianosity - aw... hell: (d) ALL OF THE ABOVE on the fact that I got lost several times en route to the meeting point. 

My directional incompetence forgiven, we set out for our destination. During the quick drive over le bridge, I was informed that we were doing the 7 Courses of Beef. Yippeee!!! 

Growing up, I lived 20 minutes away from THE Little Saigon - you know, the original? The one with the 714 area code? But I'd never eaten this infamous and amazingly orchestrated meal before. 

The fact that very few pictures were snapped (none by me at all) bears testament to the scrumptious things that you can do with beef. While most of us at the table were already well acquainted, there was not a lot of chatter going on - we were too busy occupying our mouths with the real bidness at hand: EATING. 

The price per person is less than $20, and is a full 7 courses of beef with all of the rice paper frisbees, pickled carrots, daikon and snapping fresh herbs that you can shove into your mouth. Fantastic. Eating Yelp Family Style, we were also able to order some fried imperial rolls, a seafood course and a dish that featured succulent chicken, earthy mushrooms and a savory, crispy-crunchy rice crust that I have only ever tasted in com tay cam... or however you spell it. 

I was swooning at the first course: beef carpaccio, VN style, chillin' in a bath of vinegar and the prerequisite fish sauce and peanuts. I couldn't get enough of it - and the flavor was luxurious and perfectly complemented by the quick marinade, not at all overwhelmed. 

A generous salad was tangy and crisp... which I piled onto my plate and into the baskets full of rice paper "frisbees" that you dampen in a bowl of hot water, circling, circling, circling... until "al dente" - they continue to soften once you place them on your plate and start filling them up with all manner of goodies which will tempt your palate. 

The imperial rolls were petite and full of meaty flavor without being greasy at all... but still, very rich. I guess you can wrap them in the frisbees with some foliage or eat them plain... I think they're better with the acidity of the pickles and some mint and basil. 

I have no idea how Manabu M. ALWAYS looks dapper (suit and tie; impeccably gracious, too) while eating with his hands!  He is such a gentleman, and I adore him to no end... but once, just once, would it be so wicked of me to wish a wayward noodle onto his sleeve?  Or a splash of fragrant sauce upon his tie?  

I didn't love the shabu shabu style dish at first, but found that if I just did a few courtesy swishes, so that my meat was still rare, I much preferred it that way. 

I skipped the squid and shrimp (a separate dish) because I was desperately trying to save room for the ensuing courses! 

I really enjoyed the 3 different "beef sausages" (add your own sophomoric joke here) - which are strange but delicious. They don't have a casing, but I believe that one of them is prepared wrapped in caul fat, which just takes it over the top. Extremely savory - I could only eat one of each - and that was a struggle. 

The beef porridge was, I suppose, the "light" component of the whole gustatory experience. I was only able to muster a few timid spoonfuls, dubious in my ability to waddle out of the restaurant of my own accord. 

Thank you to Peter L. for putting good food and good people together; and for finally showing up to your own soiree. At least you brought a peace offering of cupcakes! 

To JCP and her guests: always lovely to see you again, Gentleman K. and Ms. Gina - you follow in JCP's footsteps and are fabulous beyond words. JCP - another thanks for sharing the wealth of your spirit and your spirits (e.g. from the liquor cabinet) with us! 

And thanks to my Amigo, for being such a good sport and dining companion. 

At the conclusion of this meal - I looked around the table and saw blissful smiles, heard friendly jokes, and heartfelt toasts. I wondered: are we merely eating family style? Or are we truly eating as a family? 

I am going to choose the latter.
author: Kim D.

description:
Fresh. Delicious. And plentiful. I've been searching for these Vietnamese rice paper wrap dishes since I left Boston years ago. Not a place for Pho (they don't have it) but if you're a fan of the wraps you make yourself, you will be thrilled. They serve plenty of beautiful basil and other greens, bean sprouts, carrots, cucumber and the perfect dipping sauce. I had the grilled shrimp with rice cakes.

I also started with a small chicken soup which hit the spot and had a very nice broth that wasn't greasy or too salty.

The service is a little abrupt but I get the feeling the waiters do care about your experience. At one point, one waiter came over silently, as I was eating, and moved this large cup of dipping sauce away from me. At first I thought, hey....I'm using that, but then I saw that he was filling a small monkey dish with it and showing me the proper way to use it. Without a word, he left the table.

One of the best meals I had while visiting SF.
author: Heather M.

description:
Service was really bad. Was in a big group and made a reservation, but they gave our table away so we waited 40 minutes for enough space to open up. A lot of food was ordered so I'm not really reviewing that. 7 course was fine, nothing spectacular, but the basics of a restaurant seems to be missed. For example, when we ask 4 separate times for water, we shouldn't get it during the 4th course. We even ordered appetizers but they never entered it to be made!
They were busy and food did promptly come out, but if you can't get people water at the beginning of the meal, I don't know what to say. 
Also one of my friends has an allergy to nuts so we asked about her dish. We were told there was no nuts, but when the dish came out, the salad on her rice plate was topped with nuts! 
I would go again for the 7 course, but I'm in no rush to try them again any time soon.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Who can resist 7 COURSES OF BEEF...

Well, vegetarians, perhaps.  

Anyway, I, meat-loving girl, went with my co-worker and love the food.  I want to the one in Milpitas/San Jose as well, but I think this one is a tad bit better.

The service wasn't too great...I realize it was very busy (on a Wednesday night, a good sign), but I had to wave wildly for our server's attention.  Eh, not a huge deal.  The burner flames were shooting out wildly..a bit scary if you've got long hair like me.

What I love about the 7 Courses of Beef is that when the food comes out, you always feel a sense of "oh, that's it".  Then, when you start eating, you realize that it's an enormous amount of food and toward the end of course 5, you're struggling for more room.

My tip:  Less vegetables, more beef in your first few rolls so that you have room for the rest of the beef later on.

However, I do love how complex the process is - unlike American food where it's a huge slab of steak put in front of you, this is smaller portions that you have to make, therefore allowing you to digest the food properly, and also ensuring a more gratifying eating experience.

I'm ready to go back!
author: Helen F.

description:
A contender of Pagolac?  I think not, sadly.  It's definitely a better bang for the buck, but its just not the same and doesn't have the quality pagolac gives.  Theres 7 courses of course, but some dishes are lacking and hard to even acknowledge counting towards a course, and rather be an appetizer.  Simply, its just not good enough in quality and quantity even though its relatively cheap with $30 for 4 persons and 2 appetizers and round of beers.

7 course beef
-Beef paste - ehh
-Beef shabu - tasty
noooooo beef carpaccio
-3 rolled beefs, regular, leaf, and nuts
-Egg rolls - typical
-Sugar cane fried shrimp - pretty good with nice taste of sugar cane

relatively cheap...$30 for 4 persons and 2 appetizers and round of beers
author: Vincent K.

description:
The seven courses of beef here is wonderful! I've only had it one other time at Pagolac and i had absolutely loved it there! This is similar, but a little different and, in my opinion, better.  it costs more, but you get more food and its all so good!  I took my sister here who was visiting and she's still raving about it!

be prepared for a lot- and i mean A LOT of food. delicious.  Service was excellent, too.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Date/Time: Saturday - 8:00pm
Occasion:  Friends surprise birthday dinner
Party of:  28
Ordered: Five orders of seven course beef with bo tai chanh (raw beef salad) on the side for each table
Location:  Difficult to find parking.  Small and crowded inside!
Total incl gratuity: $25pp

I had Anh Hong in So. Cal a few months back and recently tried Anh Hong here in the Bay Area.  There's something about the so.Cal one that has been feening for non-stop beef.  This one, though still good, doesn't give me the same effect.  We came here to celebrate a birthday.  It's a smaller venue so it was a little crowded given there was almost 30 of us.  Definitely not a quiet romantic atmosphere.  Our table had 8 people and five orders was more than enough food.  Similar set up to so. Cal.  The first order was the salad, followed by the beef fondue, three types of beef sausage, a beef cake with vermicelli, and finishing up with beef porridge. 

It's an experience I recommend people to try.  Getting to wrap up your own little rolls is always fun.  You can put your own sauces and add meats of your choice.  They have this really yummy shrimp paste sauce that goes really well with the rolls.  The price is very reasonable! Service is nothing special but honestly I don't expect it to be.  They're quick and they get the job done. Since this one is so much more accessible, I'll head on over the next time I'm ready to "roll".
author: Jess C.

description: Reservations mean nothing. Plan on waiting. Good news is there is a liquor store close by with a nice selection of beer and wine.
author: Buddy M.

description:
Every time I come here, it's for the 7-course beef. I haven't tried the other dishes so this review is based on only the 7-course beef.

1) I love the beef salad, it's very light and refreshing.
2) Cooking the beef in vinegar broth is something I could skip, but it is fun to do. 
3) Then the beef is cooked in either 3-4 ways that look like sausages or the ball of beef. They are all good in their own ways, but after a while they all start to taste the same.
4) The beef porridge was my favorite, mmm. I wish they gave you more. haha.

The meal is filling and very good. Making your own spring roll takes a while to perfect, but once you get a hand of it, you can make them pretty fast. The vegetables (bean sprouts, mints, etc) are pretty fresh. Sometimes the servers are on top of things and refill your cups of water, or bring you more vegetables, and sometimes they don't. It's a hit and miss with this place. The food is good though. 

One drawback is expect to come out smelling like beef. Another thing is that your fingers may come out smelling like the dipping sauce. Other than that, enjoy yourself.

**Update:
Went here again recently with a large group of friends. Stood at the doorway for the longest time before they came to ask how large my party was. Seated and was still waiting on a friend so we didn't order yet. Waiter came by to take our order, we said we're still waiting. He kind of got angry I guess and walked off (I suppose they expect you to know what you want right away).

Our table was pretty neglected after we ordered. Had to ask them to refill our cups of water numerous times, and ask for more rice paper. The same waiter that was pushy earlier kept coming back to tell us how "We are supposed to eat" and at first it was nice, but then it just started getting irritating. If I want to roll it this way, LET ME ROLL IT THIS WAY. You don't see me telling you how to be a better waiter. After a while we just avoided asking him for water, just in case he was going to tell my friends and I that we're drinking water wrong too.

So the check came, and we were a party of 9 so gratuity was added automatically. Gave them exact change. Then the same guy comes back and throws it back at us and says it's not enough. We all look at each other dumbfounded. I guess he missed the $50 bill in there and thought it was a $20. So we went to a different cashier and told him. Then after wards he came by and said "Sorry, I didn't know." That waiter in particular kind of ruined my dining experience, and usually I enjoy it there. 

Food is good, service is kind of lousy.
author: Johnson S.

description:
Hot damn, this place is amazing. I came here last week for dinner but didn't go the whole nine yards and do the 7 Course Beef Menu. Instead my group of 3 ordered the Beef Lemongrass Rolls, Beef sausage wrapped in Hawaiian Leaf, and a Beef plate w/ onions that you cook yourself on a hot plate. This was enough to leave us all feeling stuffed.

What do I love about this place? The delicious brown fish sauce that leaves your breath kickin' for hours and your burps reeking till the next day!

You can't go wrong here. In fact, I think I will go later today because I am craving it now that I am writing this review.
author: Lisa T.

description: got the 7 course beef - delicious!! Really creative in the way that they incorporate the various kinds of beef. It also comes w/ a salad (with beef) and soup/congee at the end surprisingly - the congee was my favorite actually.
author: Victoria K.

description:
Love this restaurant for the 7 courses of beef. My favorite course is always the first, simply because I love dipping the rice paper in water, adding veggies, and wrapping. I could do simply veggie versions too. 

The parking here is a bit tricky if you drive a decent car as it is in the middle of TL. Also, don't except fancy service here. It definitely helps to have someone who speaks Viet here with you. The staff are much nicer then and you can more easier flag them down for refills on rice paper, veggies, hot water, etc. I prefer this place to Pagolac as it's less upscale and more down to earth. They also have round tables where family style is the way to go!
author: Yue Z.

description:
4.0 Stars

I actually tried this Anh Hong before I tried the one in Milpitas.

$18.95 per order of 7 Course Beef.  One order is more than enough for one person. For two people I highly recommend getting one order of the 7 Course Beef and then order some appetizers or side dishes.

It's important to note this restaurant is in the Tenderloin district in San Francisco so don't expect to find the best of people around the area.  Parking can also be a pain so public transportation is the best way to get here.

Since my dining experience here was very similar in terms of menu items, I'll borrow my review from the Milpitas one.

se7en

I'm not thinking about the Korean Pop Star. I'm talking about SEVEN course BEEF!

Let's count them out and keep track of my fullness for fun. Remember to pace yourself.

1) Special Beef Salad (Goi Bo)
*Nice, refreshing appetizer.
*It contained a mixture of pickled carrots, daikon, celery, and thin strips of beef that was all topped off with diced up peanuts and mint leaves.  The beef appeared really similar to pork because it was actually white in color instead of the brownish color I'm used to.

Fullness meter: [ |                   ]
*This was a light appetizer. I had room for more!

2) Beef Fondue/Hotpot (Bo Dung Dam)
*Fondue/Hotpot done table side.  They bring over a plate of raw beef with onions and then you slowly dip the beef and onions in a simmering red wine vinegar sauce.
*I recommend cooking the beef until you don't see any red spots left to ensure you won't feel sick afterward. If you have an iron stomach feel free to eat it still a little raw. I probably wouldn't do that myself.
*Don't overcook the beef though so be sure to carefully watch it.  You don't want it to be super chewy.
*Place it in the rice paper wrapper and toss on all the vegetables you want.

Fullness meter: [ | | |                ]
*Not even close to being full. I'm feeling pretty good.

Now they started stepping it up. 3, 4, 5, 6 all on one plate.

3) Steamed Beef Meatball (Bo Cha Dum)
*The meatballs were an interesting mix of various spices, nuts, wood ear mushrooms, peas, and noodles.
*The plate has some shrimp chips that you scoop the meatballs onto and eat.
*I found this dish mediocre. I wasn't all that impressed.

Fullness meter: [ | | | |             ]
*I didn't have too much of this dish. I left more room for the sausages.

4) Grilled Beef Sausages (Bo Moi Chai)
*Tasty grilled sausages that were on the fatty side.  They were still juicy regardless.

Fullness meter: [ | | | | | | |        ]

5) Beef Wrapped in Hawaiian Lot Leaf (Bo La Lot)
*The beef was nice, tender, and flavorful.  The beef was wrapped in these dark green colored leaves that brought out all the flavor.

Fullness meter: [ | | | | | | | | |   ]

6) Grilled Lemongrass Wrapped in Beef Roll (Bo Nuong Sa)
*This was my favorite sausage.  Apparently, these are tenderloin rolls wrapped around grilled lemongrass that are then topped with peanuts.  The innards had a crunchy texture to it so I thought it was grilled onions at first.

Fullness meter: [ | | | | | | | | | | ]
*I'm totally grabbing my stomach at this point. I had to take a quick break before the last dish.

7) Beef Rice Soup/Porridge (Chao Bo)
*If you have tried Chinese Porridge or 'Jook' before, you'll notice this is more on the watery side.  The thin beef strips, beef broth, ginger, cilantro, green onions, and peanuts culminate to make a nice dish to end the meal with.  
*It really had deep flavor, but I couldn't get myself to have more than one bowl because I was so stuffed.

Fullness meter: [ | | | | | | | | | | ]  | |
*See that.  I went over my fullness meter and it broke.  :(  I ate so much that I was waiving the white flag by the end of it all.

If you haven't tried this experience before, DO IT!

== A MUST TRY! ==
author: Jason H.

description: I love love love this place! They definitely have some of the best vietnamese food I have tasted in SF and the most authentic. I loved the beef wrapped in leaves. I would say the only downside is the service. The waiters don't speak very good english, so you might get low quality service because of the language barrier.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
More of a 3.5 - 3.75 stars, but I've been to Anh Hong twice and the food's not bad. If you dine here for the 7 courses of beef dishes, it definitely is a lot and I highly recommend coming with a group of friends with appetites. 

The table starts off with all the trimmings and a few baskets of rice paper (depending on size of group). When the first of the beef is served - COMMENCE MAKING SPRING ROLLS! Soften the rice paper by dipping into the bowls of warm water they provide, and then just pick all the stuff (veggies, beef) that you want, roll it up, dip, and enjoy! You're sure to leave with your stomach satisfied, if not more.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
If you walk past a chinese cafeteria looking place and find yourself on the other side of Hyde, stop, turn around, go back, you missed it. I did this. Three times. My sister waiting inside watched in amusement and actually called to make sure I was OK. All good, just hungry.

That was no longer the case after consuming an obscene amount of grilled shrimp and chicken rice paper wraps. I need to do this more often. Clearly my kind of operation - I get to pick what goes inside, built entirely to specifications. And these were good if I do say so myself. Besides the meat (delicious, if a bit on the oily side), plenty of veggies, and a few dipping sauces. This was sis' first time. I think she was sold.

Be sure to enjoy the food as you won't get much else - namely water refills or a courtesy check in. But that might have just been payback for initially dismissing this spot as a chinese cafeteria. My bad, my bad.
author: Jason B.

description:
Fun Fun Fun!

Thanks to the Yelp reviews, a girl friend and I ventured in for dinner. We both agreed we simply could not handle the 7 course beef, so we went with the BBQ pork and beef fondue to share.

Though we certainly could have figured it out, a server jumped at the chance to give us a demonstration/tutorial on making our spring rolls. He was firm but kind and encouraging on the proper technique.

Yummy yummerson!!

It was a teency bit odd that server dudes 1 and 2 kind of hovered around our table making sure we were getting the rolls right and commenting on how much healthier this food was over American cheeseburgers, but whatevs, it added to the adventure :-)  

We were both hell bent on finishing our food, so after a bit we had to stop and take little food breaks. Alas, we had to leave 2 pieces of beef behind - much to the chagrin of server dudes 1 and 2. 

I will definitely be back! Would be loads of fun with a big group doing the 7 course beef extravaganza. But I do wonder if they'd let you order for 4 if you had a group of 6...as another reviewer recommended to get the portions more reasonable?
author: Jen J.

description:
A group of 6 of us went here.
We ordered 5 orders of the 7-course meat dish, plus 2-orders of the shrimp dish per the waiters unsolicited recommendation (shrimp wrapped around sugar cane).

First, let me say 'thank you' to the waiter for making the shrimp recommendation.  It was awesome!

As for the 7-course meat meal.  Not only were most of the courses very tasty, but also there was entertainment value in the build your own taco-like contraption, and in the fondue style cooking we used on one of the seven courses of meat.

When one combines the flavors, the kick-back and enjoyable atmosphere,  the fantastic wait staff, the low prices, and the fact that one knows it is good because we were the only non-Vietnamese in the whole place.....I come up with only one logical conclusion for a rating: 5-stars!
author: Marc P.

description: Woah. You wanna take a free trip to Vietnam without the jetlag? Check out this place! Best freakin' Vietnamese food in the city. I didn't even understand the menu, I just told the waiter I wanted something authentic, and my food was awesome. I've been there a few times, and once went there with a big group. The waiters even taught my friends how to roll their rice paper to make awesome rolls! Hands on instructions right at our table!
author: Sheryl M.

description:
Looking for a Vietnamese restaurant tonight and picked this one randomly. The place was absolutely packed when we arrived so we knew it had to be good. Yes, the food was really good.

Food - Yum..Vietnamese coffee (sugary yum!)

Service - well, it honestly felt like they either didn't want us there...

Will we go back? No. There are plenty of other Vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: Mark M.

description:
Delicious bo 7 mon! I also had the beef carpaccio...that was my favorite! The meat was tasty, veggies were fresh and abundant, and wrappers didn't fall apart on me (and I didn't have to double up!). The servers were very nice and quite entertaining. One of the guys was oddly sarcastic.

Once we were done with our meal, they seemed to have forgotten us. We sat there for a long time waiting for our bill. That didn't bother us since we needed the lazy time to digest all of the delicious meat anyway. I enjoyed the food and will probably return the next time I visit SF again.
author: Linda T.

description: If you have three people, order (2) seven courses of meat and you will be satisfied. If like eating your meats by wrapping it with rice paper then this place is your go to. Similar to other reviews, the service here is so-so and it could be immensely improved. I would give this place five stars, if the atmosphere is better, but hey this is close to the tenderloin district.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I had the honor and sudden pleasure of arranging a birthday dinner for a friend who had told NOBODY that it was his birthday.

So, with two hours' notice, I had to pick a venue and get people attending.  Nobody I know is going to eat their birthday dinner alone - not on my watch.

Well, we had nine people at dinner and the location I picked was Anh Hong Restaurant.  I had heard lots of things about Anh Hong, but every opportunity to go had been sabotaged by one thing or another.

First off - seven courses of anything for $18.95 is a bargain.  Make it beef, and you have an almost automatic fan.  Two in our party knew the owner well, and special treatment was rolled out to us - much appreciated!

We had the Vietnamese raw beef dish, and it was good.  The quality of meat was fresh and lean.

We all ordered our drinks - and several of us opted for the white wine.  The owner didn't ask which, so I assumed there was only one and expected nothing great.  However, what he served a Mosel Riesling that was FANTASTIC.  Even cooler was that once we got our drinks, he basically dropped off the bottle of wine at our table for the price of 3 glasses of wine.

I think I fell slightly in love at that moment.

He asked us if we'd be having the regular seven courses of beef, and one of my friends  told him to just give us whatever is best.

Well, folks - the seven courses of beef turned into more of a 10 courses of sensation.  The first dish that came out was a salad of some sort, and it definitely wasn't beef (more like pork).  It tasted great, seasoned perfectly, and was very refreshing.  Then came the rice wrappers, hot water, vegetables and other condiments as  the other meats came pouring out of the kitchen.  Included was this ENORMOUS prawn type creatures that were cooked perfectly (they were so big I initially thought they were lobsters) as well as fresh beef, sausages of some sort, wrapped and unwrapped, etc.  It was ENDLESS food.

ENDLESS!

Some people threw in the towel after 4-5 courses; I, myself, chugged along to the end with a few others, but I was on the verge of throwing in the same proverbial towel when the porridge came out and I realized the onslaught of food had finally ended.  (The porridge, by the way, looked mediocre but tasted amazing; perfect ending to a perfect meal.)

ALL of us were unreasonably full.

Anh Hong serves up delicious food, and while the neighborhood is a bit shady - DO GO and try the SEVEN COURSE BEEF.  It's so good, and such a great meal and experience to share w/ friends.

The service - everyone from the owner to the waiters - were exemplary.  They were efficient, and got the job done fast.  Everything we needed, we got.

I was there last week, and while I am out of town for the next week or so, I intend to go back before 2009 is over to have it one more time.  It's delicious.

Having said all that - our million course meal came at a higher price that broke down to $43/person.  Since each of us had 2-3 drinks each, factoring that into the $18.95 cost would equal about $32 or so, and the addition of the shrimp and such, along with the raw beef we ordered in the beginning, brought the total significantly higher.  

Even so, the meal was well worth it.

The place can easily accommodate large groups; just call ahead and ask them for a reservation.

ANH HONG is AWESOME.
And Happy Birthday, Nelson!!!!
author: Grace K.

description: First time in San Francisco and we decided to try a few places around town. It was getting late though and we were already to tired to travel to far from where we were staying. So we wanted some Vietnamese food and this was the closest with pretty good ratings. Walking in seemed okay we were seated and we're given menus. The moment you try to order (if you think of going here) unless you know EXACTLY what you want, don't even try to change your mind it will only upset them. I felt as though they only cater well to other Vietnamese customers since they can communicate easily with each other. We felt uneasy as we waited for our food they waiter (who seemed like the owner) kept staying around our table and just continue to watch over us. We honestly felt uncomfortable, the food was okay but coming from where we only have 1 or 2 Vietnamese restaurant this place made our restaurant look like 5 stars.
author: Mark C.

description:
A friend of mine owns a business that works with this restaurant as one of its clients, so my groupie and I decided to come here for dinner. Food was mouth watering, but the service was a-okay. I still give props to the grouchy old man who took our order, he looked like he hadn't slept for a few days.

If you're expecting pho here, you can forget about it. This place is more of a family style dinner place where a group of people share the entrees such as fondues, sugar cane wrapped with shrimp and served with rice paper and fresh veggies. They also have their 7 courses of beef style dinner, which is seven different courses of beef cooked differently. Some are served with lemon grass, rice paper and/or vermicelli. 

All in all this place was attentive in refreshing our hot water and veggies for the rice wraps. If you like burritos, you can think of this as the Asian burrito, except healthier. AND, you get to make it yourself. As for dipping sauces, there was a sweet fish sauce with shredded carrots and a pungent vinegar style sauce which blew up my mouth in terms of spiciness. 

My friends and I had a good time joking about the sugarcane shrimp.

Eric: you have to stick it (sugar cane) in your mouth and enjoy the size. ic Tiff likes to nibble that like a chipmunk
Tiff: I like squirrels better.
Me: however you eat it, don't forget to swallow. (hehehe)
-Eric almost spits his food across the table at Tiffany-

Overall, this place has great food, service. Other than that, good luck on parking since it is the Tenderloin.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Showed up at 8pm on a Saturday with 2 other people. We made a "reservation" around 7:30 but it wasn't necessary, we were seated after a very short wait.

I got the 7 courses of beef, and the others got the make you own rolls, one shrimp and sugar cane (didn't try) and the other BBQ pork.

The 7 courses of beef were very good. Not a huge fan of the first course (beef salad), but the rest were great. Three slices of "beef fondue with vinegar", was an interesting dish I hadn't had before. Basically just slices of beef that's been cooked in hot vinegary broth. The next four courses came at once. Various beef sausages (the one with peanuts inside was incredible, but all of them were good) and steamed beef meatballs was super tasty and unique. The final dish was the beef rice porridge, which was also very good, with great fresh ginger included.

The BBQ pork wraps were awesome. Attempting to wrap the rolls gave me a new appreciation for them. It was tough to get the wrap completely closed while shoving as much as I wanted in there. I usually ended up half-wrapping it and shoving it in my mouth. Delicious either way.
author: Ned F.

description:
we no longer just get only the 7 course beef because it gets boring, and we don't like every single beef dish.

so for 4 ppl, instead we order

1- 7 course beef. bo bay mon
beef carppacio bo thai chanh- always a must get
grilled beef with rice cake bo thit bun hoi- yum yum, flavorful
egg rolls, ga gio, crunchy and super yummy, but extremely hot when it comes out, so wait!
and additional plate, sugar cane shrimp or something else. (excuse my vietglish spelling), sugar cane shrimp, u can cut into many pieces. we tried the shrimp and beef one, where the beef wraps around a shrimp, that was okay, but had onion bleh.

but this gives you wayy more variety and super filling! i really like their grilled beef, yum.

total is around $75 before tip. Way better than just getting 3-4 orders of the 7 course.
author: Christine M.

description: Probably some of the best vietnamese food I've had ever. Their 7 course beef menu is absolutely fantastic - I can recommend anyone to eat here and even the service is outstanding. Prices are great value for your money.
author: Cathrine A.

description:
7Courses of beef! It was pretty good and I was famished after Yoga class. It took many trys before I was able to perfect my rolls and each time I got better! :) This is a fun place to eat at with at least 4 people There was 6 of us that ate there last night and we ordered 4 orders of the 7 course beef set menu. I think we ordered too much...3 should be good enough. 

For all you who do not know what 7 coursed of beef is...its basically 7 dishes of beef served differently. The last course is beef jook ( rice porridge) 

Give it a try!
author: Sandy L.

description: This is my grandma's favorite place when we eat out so we go here a lot. The food is pretty good but it does get old to me probably because I go here so often. We always get the beef that we wrap ourselves. The meats are usually very oily which is why I gave 4 stars instead of 5 but overall this place has very good flavor and s the most authentic 7 course beef place in San Francisco in my opinion. OH! I almost forgot about the rare beef salad. It is a MUST try! It is probably my favorite dish from this place. The sauce is perfect--just enough sour and sweet in the fish sauce and the beef is fresh.
author: Jenita N.

description:
Hmmm, I'm not sure why this place has such high reviews as I personally found this place to be average tasting at best.

Naturally, my friends and I ordered the 7 course beef because well, that's what the restaurant is known for! The service was okay, and the food was also just okay, nothing spectacular. 

Just FYI, if you order the 7 course beef, be prepared to make your own wraps using all of the ingredients available that they provide. You basically take a piece of circular rice paper, dip it in a bowl of hot water, throw it on your plate, add various ingredients on top of the rice paper, and then roll it up into a neat little spring roll! Then, dip in fish sauce and proceed to devour! Lather, rinse, and repeat!

If you're new to wrapping, then it might be a bit difficult for you, but I have had numerous experiences wrapping Vietnamese food so I had no trouble wrapping for myself as well as for my friend sitting next to me.

Overall this place was a good unique experience and a must-try if you have never tried it before, but again, the food was only average tasting. I'm sure there are better 7 course beef places out there.
author: Albert L.

description:
Do you like beef? I do. How many courses of beef can you eat? I can eat an infinite amount of courses, but here I think 7 courses is fine. 

I came here with a group of friends one night to try this place out. I heard that this was the place to go if you want to have vietnamese dining experience and on top of that have 7 courses of beef to go with it. As the meal progressed, I started to get slightly disappointed because three of the courses ended up being different styles of beef sausages. I wasn't too big of a fan of that many sausages, but I lived with it. 

The cost for this experience is currently $18.95 per person. In my opinion, I think it is outrageous to be charging this much per person for just okay food. The flavors are not too intense even with the special dipping sauces. One sauce, which was the salty fermented fish sauce almost made me gag, not saying that it is bad because I'm not accustomed to how the sauce should taste like, but I'll tell you what... I'll never forget that taste =) 

All in all, this place is okay, it is not horrible, but I will not return. If you want to try out a unique experience, then I'd say give this place a shot. If you do not wish to partake in the 7 courses of beef there is other things you may order off the menu.

***I've posted pictures of the 7 courses of beef. Take a look at them it might interest you in having it one day***
author: Michael J.

description:
Come here on a day when you're starving in desperation and order the seven course beef. You will not regret your decision. In minutes you will embark on an epic journey through the seven trial of beef. If you exit the seventh gate intact, then you will end your quest satisfied with the spoils of your travels settled in your belly.

It's much more reasonable to split the seven trials with a friend, but you get more XP if you go solo.
author: Tian X.

description: 7 course beef was good. I haven't tried the other dishes. Just come for the food.....don't look for great service
author: Lawrence Y.

description:
3.5 Stars! COME HERE IF YOU'RE A MEATLOVER AND STARVING!

Even though it's SF, there's not a whole lot of Asian restaurants that's open past 9 PM on a weekday. Me and my GF were feeling like Viet food after some after work shopping. I remember hearing about Anh Hong and their 7 Course Beef Menu and immediately hopped on YELP to see what time they closed. It closed at 10 PM, so Anh Hong here we came.

As we entered, we were promptly seated. We were given our menus and quickly after the waiter was hovering over us. *sigh*  

FOOD:
*7 Course Beef Menu:
-Beef Salad: It was ok. The beef looked more like pork b/c it was white in color. It was a bit tough. The salad was made up of pickled daikon, carrots, and cucumbers.
-Beef Carpaccio: It was good! The beef was very tender and the broth gave it a unique taste different from the typical beef slices you get in pho. The broth was very rich and had a vinegar base.
