-Grilled Beef Wrapped in Lot Leaf: YUMMY! The beef sausage was super tender and flavorful. It was wrapped in a leaf similar to the leaf used in dolmas. 
-Grilled Lemongrass Roll: This was another yummy dish. The beef was perfectly grilled and juicy. We couldn't make out what was inside the roll...possibly tendons b/c it has a crunch to it...I don't think it was onions as the menu had stated. 
-Beef Sausage: This was my FAV out of all the meat items. It was super juicy and very tasty. Well maybe b/c the cut of meat was super fatty! And, anything fatty is good!
-Beef Meatballs: It was ok! It tasted like all the standard steamed Viet meatballs with the vermicelli noodles in it. Nothing really stood out about it. 
-Beef Porridge: This was the first time I've tried Viet porridge and it's very different from Chinese Jook. It's watery and boiled to the point where the rice has not broken down to it's starchy form. The rice is still a bit al-dente. Other than the texture which I wasn't used to, it had great depth of flavor from the beef broth, ginger, and peanuts.

I have to note the 7 Course Beef Menu was a little misleading. It's more of a menu comprised of different beef appetizer items; like an ham tray if you will. But, it will leave you stuffed! And, like ALL the other reviews say it's enough food for 2 people!

*BBQ Pork Rolls (wrap your own): One of the BEST rolls, I've ever had!  The pork slices were thick and huge, perfectly grilled and seasoned, very flavorful and juicy! The accompanying noodles were in a cake format and was still al-dente; just the way I like it!  The accompaniments (basil, mint, lettuce, bean sprouts, cucumber, carrot, etc) were VERY fresh and added the perfect crunch to the roll. Luckily, the waiter had persuaded us to order this item; otherwise we would have missed out!

SERVICE: Overly attentive in a creepy matter from start to finish. As soon as we got in, the waiter was hoovering over us. During the ENTIRE meal, he would stand in back of our table (I had the pleasure of facing him) and STARE. When I would look up and ahead, he would come running up to us and asking if we needed anything. This is such a change from the service I normally get at Asian restaurants. Goodness, can a 2 girls eat in peace?!?!

Would I come back...YUP, definitely for the rolls! They were DELISH!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I've been going to Anh Hong to get my fix of eats for about 8 years now - and I love them!!!

If you're expecting some fancy pants San Francisco foodie style place, go elsewhere. And if you're expecting the waitstaff to be beside themselves in excitement you're there - go elsewhere. 

But if you want to eat some of the best, mind blowing Vietnamese wraps made by your own loving hands at the table then you're in the right place. I also recommend getting the sugarcane shrimp -mmmm.

Over the years I've had a variety of various experiences with the wait staff from cold indifference to kindly given helpful hints on how to roll my wraps better. 

Perhaps because the staff hasn't changed since I first started coming and I've grown quite fond of them or maybe the goodness of the food more than makes up for their shortcomings - I can't say for sure - but it doesn't bother me in the least if they're a little grumpy one night.

Tip - There's an indoor pay garage across the street,
author: S K.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night with a few of my friends. My friend made reservations and I saw the table waiting for us even though we were a little late so I thought it was going to be a good night. Well, I agree with most people in that service is HORRIBLE but food is pretty good. 

So I don't eat beef and when my friends told me they're known for their 7 course beef, I had to look for something good to eat fast! They had lots of options but I just went for the #18 I think. It was bbq pork with rice paper. It was so good! If you don't eat beef, order this. The meat was flat and lean but juciy and flavorful. I wrapped it with the flat noodles and lettuce and dipped it in the sauce. So good. 

Other than that, the service is so bad. They didn't give us menus right away and when we told them our party size is smaller, he gave us a bad look. They never asked us if we wanted anything and finally we flagged a man down to order. We ordered three things for 4 people. The bbq dish and two orders of the 7 course beef. The waiter said thats not enough and kept telling us to order. He just wants our money!! So, they dont provide good service, give dirty looks, and just want money.

Oh yeah, the lemon soda was nasty. It had a weird taste to it and the soda was flat. Actually all my friends sodas were flat.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Woohoo~~ Heard from my Vietnamese friends about this long time ago that, unlike us we always have to order spring rolls from a Vietnamese restaurant if we want some, they make their own at home, and now finally I got to make my own!!!!!

Seven courses of beef, the name says it all. First course is beef salad. The second course is beef fondue. It's more like you boil the raw beef yourself. The next 4 course came all together, coz, I guess, they are similar kind of food? They include 3 kinds of beef sausages and one huge beef meat ball. And all these came with mixed vegetables, cucumber, bean sprouts and carrots, most importantly, the rice sheets!!! What you have to do is take a piece of dry rice sheet and immerse it in a bowl of water in a circular motion, and then take it out put it on your plate. Then you can start to put vegetables, beef and sauce on it. (btw, their sauces are really stinky but good @@)  By the time you are ready to wrap those stuff all together, the rice sheet is already softened like what you had with spring rolls =D, this will only take a minute or two. So now you just wrap it and eat! The last course is the beef congee, kind similar with those Cantonese dim sum kind congee.  

It was fun and the food was so tasty, oh, did I mention it's cheap too. 4 of us, ordered 2 of the seven courses of beef and a raw beef in vinegar appetizer, which was also really good. These added up about $15 each. I'm totally gonna come back again!
author: Serena H.

description:
Yummy yummy. Came here before and still just as good. Saturday right before 8pm and 4 of us were able to get a table easily, but the restaurant was packed and more people arrived to wait after 8pm. 2 orders of 7 course beef, 1 order of spring rolls later, we were full, satisfied, and the 7 course beef virgins I was with LOVED it. Something new for our eating adventures, and worked out perfectly. Definitely can't complain about finding parking a block away either!

Anh Hong, I will try not to stay away too long next time. If you opened for lunch, I would love you even more.

Additional Note: 7 course beef also tastes good with Banh Hoi (vermicelli - sounds like "bun hoy") that you can use to wrap into your spring rolls as well.
author: Anita C.

description:
What more can I say?

Came here after I was told all about 7 course beef.

I tried it at Pho Garden on Clement, but let me tell you, nothing beats Ahn Hong, so far. 

Rolling up everything there was on table in the teeny tiny wrap was so accomplishing. Then dipping it into the fish sauce spiked with that spicy sauce they give you, can you say DELICIOUS? I would tackle you for this any day. 

Can't wait till the next time!
author: Winnie L.

description:
I don't usually eat beef, so we didn't try the seven course beef. 

What we did try was great.  Because the waiter understood almost no English, we ended up with more food than we thought we ordered, but it was so good we kept eating.

We had one of the "fondue" dishes, in this case prawns that you cook in a broth at the table, wrap with softened rice paper and lettuce, and a bunch of vegetables inside.  Then you dip it in sauce.  Really excellent.  This was the dish we didn't think we had ordered.

Then we had the fresh spring rolls, also very good although not that much better than most restaurants.  What followed were two of the rice plates, one with pork and one with prawns.  The pork was amazingly good, thin sliced and tasty, with rice and vegetables.  The shrimp was also quite good with similar accompaniments.

We ate everything and were way too full, the meal cost a little under $60 and could easily have served three, a real bargain for the quality.

The waiter was not Vietnamese, not that this matters.
author: Spike S.

description: i've tried 7-beef at other restaurants and Anh Hong is just average, the beef was dry, sauces were not spectacular, and they don't have raw beef salad either... it might be a good family restaurant due to its spacious environment and time-consuming courses, but definitely not my favorite 7-beef restaurant in the bay area. Also quite expensive to eat a whole bunch of dry sausages/meatballs-like beef rolls.
author: Bo C.

description:
7 courses of beef.

Poppy was so full she couldn't finish her glass of wine.  Her food baby looked like triplets.

It's really better to go with three or four people and order 7 courses for two.

Not gourmet but so tasty and a bargain at under twenty dollars a person.
author: Poppy C.

description:
Was looking forward to a massive amount of beef, but alas, quantity did not overcome the lack of quality.  The salad in the 7 courses was too fishy, but the rice porridge and meatballs were pretty good, as were the unlimited veggie/herbs and rice paper.  But next time, I would try individual dishes rather than the hit and miss assortment.   And there might not be a next time.  

Still looking for something in the city comparable to Vung Tau.
author: Lisa S.

description:
I wanted to like this place but I couldn't. Not really. After an errand in the city my wife and I parked near Little Saigon and went walking in search of a Vietnamese dinner. Hey, there's Lee's Sandwiches. Not. Pho 2000? Nah, not really in the mood for pho. Pagolac! Let's try that. Rats, it's closed. So we decided to keep walking for a few blocks to get to Cordon Bleu, a restaurant we enjoyed a couple of years ago when one of my friends was visiting SF. When we finally made it to Cordon Bleu, you guessed it, it was CLOSED. Call it our Monday night bad luck that so many Viet places shut their doors on a Monday. We kept walking and eventually got back to Larkin St. and decided to cross over and try Anh Hong.

As we entered there were a few tables occupied but a lot of empty tables too. The waiter for some reason decided to motion us to the rear corner table, behind the aquarium and close to a table of four rather large people. We were like, no, we'd rather not be so cramped over there. After a couple of minutes he had another table cleared so we sat down and checked out the menu. Lots of 7 courses of beef, lots of fondue items and grill-it-yourself meals. I wasn't really in the mood for fondue or bo bay mon (especially not for $21 per person).

We settled on bo tai chanh for an appetizer. For main dishes my wife ordered #39, a kind of beef dish where the beef is rolled around onions in little sausage shapes, which comes with a boring side salad (mostly iceberg lettuce) and a mound of rice; and I ordered #49, rice steamed with chicken and shrimp in a hot pot. We asked for ice water.

Bo tai chanh came out rather quickly and we gobbled it up due to hunger. It was decent, but the sauce was too sweet. 3 stars out of 5. A few minutes later my wife's dish arrived. It was under-seasoned. 2 stars out of 5. 20 minutes later my order still had not arrived, nor had the ice water we ordered. Finally we asked again for our ice water and they brought it, and a couple minutes later my food arrived, steaming and sizzling in a hot pot. My wife was nearly done with her food by then but she was clearly intrigued by my order. Once I started eating, my disappointment began to fade. The steamed rice was better than I expected; the mushrooms were very tasty. Also, the bottom layer of rice was crunchy (almost like popcorn) and delicious. So I'll give my dish 4 stars out of 5.

Given the prices this place charges - consistently a couple of dollars per dish higher than we're used to paying for comparable quality Vietnamese food - I'd say I'm kind of disappointed. Only the surprisingly tasty #49 hot pot rice pulled it from a 2-star experience up to a 3-star experience.

Would I recommend Anh Hong or return? Probably not, given the other Vietnamese options in Little Saigon. I just have to remember that Monday is not the night to go out looking for Vietnamese food.
author: Richard C.

description:
I go to this same joint when I visit my parents in Santa Clara (they have a sister location in Milpitias). My parents are linguists and can pass as Vietnamese (more or less). 

That being said, I confidently ordered the seven course beef for a party of two. Me (Asian) and my better half (non-Asian). It was already awkward that the whole bustling place became dead quite when we walked through the door, but we kept an open heart. During the course of the meal, it was evident that they didn't care for our business. I was thoroughly disappointed by their lack of customer service. I didn't expect much from this place, but they obvious neglect was unacceptable.

The food was mediocre at best; the flavors were good and we were left  "satisfied"--not enough to have visit again.
author: sally y.

description:
This is one of our favorite places to go for Vietnamese cuisine in SF.  We think it rivals some of the restaurants in San Jose, which is the capital of Vietnamese cuisine.  We've yet to be dissapointed with the food or service.  This place is best if there are 4 or more of you.  That way you can order 2 orders of  the 7 courses of beef for variety and also order a few other entres to complete the meal.  If you a new here, start with the 7 courses and order extra servings of whatever you like in the 7 courses of beef.  Chances are you won't love all 7 courses but will love 1 or 2 dishes.  I don't know if it is Vietnamese food or not, but we LOVE the wanton soup here and almost always order it to finish our meal. 

The negative is that it is located in the Tenderloin.  Luckily there is a valet parking lot across the street from this place.
author: Samantha N.

description: 7 courses of beef place. Amazingly consistent. Great service with prompt refills of water, herbs, crunchy lettuce and pickles.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Horrible Service !!!!!!!!!!!! Get it thru your thick skull . Bad Service = No Business.
Its that simple and some businesses just won't get it.
Food is okay , small portions , very chinese-taste in Vietnamese cuisine. Enough said.
author: Kristine S.

description:
Definitely the wrong place for a vegetarian to be. I came here since I was a kid, but it was only until about a year ago that I realized just how awesome the seven courses of beef was. I always came with family, since a bunch of cheap Asian friends wouldn't want to fork out twenty dollars for some good Asian food.

Since we couldn't eat much, we ordered an order of seven courses of beef and my favorite, bo la lot. The Banh Hoi is also good with the rolls. Take a date here, and that's another point for you unless she's vegetarian. Then you'd probably never see her again.

I recall getting the rice plates, but they weren't that great, I definitely recommend coming here for the seven courses of beef.
author: Glen H.

description:
Walked past this place on Christmas Eve and it was packed, line out the door; knew I would give it a try in short order. Glad I did: great freshness and flavor, which explains the full house at 8:30 on a cold, rainy Tuesday night. Even the deep fried stuff is subtle and light. I had the shrimp/chicken pan fried noodles and was pleased that red meat had been included, along with four varieties of mushroom. Service is pretty dece, and the vibe is that people are genuinely enjoying their food.

Now I've had more Vietnamese food in the past two weeks than in my entire life, I'd wager. So once again I cautiously take the noob pulpit to say: this place is great, and after one meal I'm giving it four stars, with the possibly foolish confidence that when I finally indulge in a feast of the much vaunted seven-course beef (a convivial, messy, and booze-assisted feast) my admiration will be fully vindicated.
author: Peter B.

description: So maybe this is silly of me but not a pho place. I guess I should have read the menu before coming here. It was a nice surprise though, the food was really hearty. The shredded pork and grilled pork plate was flavorful and really filling. If you get the clay pot with the chicken, be prepared for a wait but it was worth it. Mix it with the chili sauce and that gives it a nice amount of heat. The service is more on the slow side but makes sense since it was almost a full house on a Sunday night.
author: Eve C.

description:
A healthy alternative! Been to both SF and Milpitas, both locations are pretty good. This restaurant is somewhat more traditional compared to other Vietnamese places. You wrap your own spring rolls which is fun and slightly messy if you're a beginner wrapper like me. They offer two sauces: fish sauce and shrimp paste; which I usually just mix the two. 

SF:
7 course beef:  most of the beef dishes are well prepared. Some of the sausage tasted the same.  Love the fondue and porridge. 
Sugar cane shrimp:  well balanced and flavorful. 
Imperial rolls: who doesn't love fried food?   Tasty and the right ratio of filling to meat. 
Large prawns:  wasn't sure if this was on the menu, was recommended by a friend and it was absolutely delish!  Prawns were almost the size of my palm!  Drool...

Milpitas:
7 course beef: I think the flavors were more spot on compared to SF. 

Differences between the two locations:
SF has basil and cilantro to wrap your own rolls, which gives a more fresh and vibrant taste. 
Milpitas: has the grilled whole catfish. Been wanting to try it but it's too much fish for two and was $55 MP. 

Service:
Both locations were attentive. I'm a big veggie eater and the staff kept refilling our  plates of veggies and rice paper wraps without us having to request for them. 

Overall, good food for a reasonably priced meal.
author: Foodie F.

description:
The 7 course beef was good.  The goi (papaya salad with beef) was ok, the beef was a bit tough to chew.  The beef fondue was good.  There were 3 courses of beef sausages, the sausage with the green wrap was delicious but one of the other two was really bland.  The beef ball was yummy and the beef ginger porridge was a good end to the meal.  

I give this place a 3 star because the food was good but the service was poor.  We barely finished the fondue when they came and took the hot pot off abruptly with a bbq lighter, I usually expect ok service at a Vietnamese restaurant but  I can't tolerate it when it's dangerous.  We had to flag them down for the last course and water and there were probably only 22 people (5 tables) including us there.
author: Phuong H.

description:
It has been a while since I came here but last night after bringing friends to eat I would be back. The best deal here is the 7 course meal. If you haven't tried the 7 course it is a good deal for the amount of food you get. 

This is a Vietnamese style way of eating using wraps. But rice and vermicelli noodles can be added if you aren't the type to wrap your food. Usually considered to be a quick snack and a meal eaten with family members this can become a very intimate dinner. 

Btw after cooking your raw meat in the vinegar soup, let it cool down and drink it. Really good to kick out the cold and to clear the sinuses, not for everyone but try it at least once. 

Very good service but be patient and you will see the food laid out in front of you like you are royalty. Also, be careful what you may take to be peanut sauce is actually fermented shrimp sauce so don't spill on yourself. 

Give this place a chance and make your own decision. Enjoy!
author: Nana R.

description: 7 course beef meal and its pretty damn good.
author: Linda A.

description: Great beef dishes. Best 7-course beef offering in SF or anywhere... Favorite dishes: raw beef in fish sauce and grape leaf wrapped beef. It's not located in the best area of SF, but the food is worth it. Good for large groups... as with most Asian restaurants are meant for family dining.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
If you come here, just get their 7 course meal. Make sure to be hungry too. I thought I would be disappointed with the portions, but boy I was wrong.

Definitely a nice place to be social as you're pretty much making your own rolls

You definitely get your money's worth here. Just be prepared to smell like fish sauce :)
author: Eric A.

description:
Tips for when dining at Anh Hong:

* Get the 7 course beef!  

* If it's a dinner for two, insist that you only want one order of the said 7 course beef.  It's $18.95 for one very generous order that will leave the two of you very stuffed (granted you are on a date with a woman, and not two ravenous lumberjacks).

* If your appetite is bigger than you think, try their BBQ pork chop over rice -- it's delicious.  Other items I've ordered off of their menu were hits or misses.  Stick with the 7 course beef, I tell ya.

* Want to add some vino to the romantic dinner?  Bring in a bottle of wine and they'll charge you $10 for corkage fee.  A better deal than ordering from their not-so-impressive wine list.

* Try not to pack so much onto your rice paper.  Yes, the ingredients are extremely fresh and you're inclined to pack in as much as you can.  But the key to making a good wrap that won't break apart is to be moderate. 

* Roll up your sleeves.  When biting into the wrap you just so diligently made, the fish sauce and fermented anchovy sauce you've slathered your meat with will dribble down your arms.

* Bring some potent antibacterial soap with you or just avoid any hands-on interaction (e.g. giving someone a massage, allowing your date to smell your hands, etc.) after dinner.  Your hands will smell like fish sauce, no doubt about that.

* Enjoy your meal!  Anh Hong is one of the nicer Vietnamese restaurants with white linen-covered tables and very polite and friendly service.
author: Diane L.

description:
I've been coming here since I can remember.  We always get the 7 course beef along with the BBQ pork. Their porridge is yummy and a good way to end the meal.  One of the waiter guys always look mad, but I think that's just the way he looks. Once you warm up to him, he's not that bad. 

We took many first-timers here and they are all regulars now.  Make reservations because it gets really crowded.
author: Anna C.

description:
It takes a lot for me to dislike a restaurant I would never step foot in again.

The food is decent, but not worth it when the service is extremely rude and pushy. When I go out to eat at a Vietnamese restaurant, I do not have any expectations for service, but for a server to get visably angry at a customer is unacceptable. There's an older guy who always insists in ordering more than necessary. Really, I can do without that $5 egg roll appetizer you are making me order.

I won't be back.
author: Bruce M.

description: Their menu is awesome! They never fail me every time I eat there. Excellent food and the porridge at the end totally hits the spot!
author: TifFancy N.

description:
Nothing say's hello ladies like fish and shrimp sauce breath after leaving here.  But if you're not getting friendly after dinner... then definitely stuff your face with as much beef sausage as your little heart desires.

My personal fave is the thinly cut raw beef. This is Ol' Dirty Bastard's last meal requested.

"Oooh baby I like it raw!
Yeah baby I like it rawwww!"

Honestly.
author: Donsta L.

description:
BBQ pork + rice paper = make your own spring rolls = AMAZING.

Everything else was a bit lackluster to me.  The bf tried the 7 course beef, which was just okay.  Most of the beef I tried was either chewy or not memorable.  

But BBQ pork represent!  I will def be back for more of those suckers.
author: Kristine B.

description: umm...yeah this place is for real.  i'm not vietnamese but i have a lot vietnamese peeps in my circle and they vouch for this place.  we went here for the 7 beef course and i swear i died and went to food coma!!  it's freaking amazing and that is all that needs to be said.   i'm sure it doesn't quite live up if you can make the 7 beef course homemade and all, but for restaurant made i think it redeems itself pretty well.  service is eh, but it's an asian restaurant so i never expect service to be all that.  i go for the food not the service...and food did not disappoint here!
author: Mao K.

description:
Tip #1: You will smell when you leave here. Your clothes, your hair, your hands...they will ALL smell. Your significant other might later be repulsed by your aroma, but believe me, it's worth it.

Tip #2: You will most likely cook your own food, depending on what you order. Don't be afraid. You will get through it.

Tip #3: If you want to drink wine, bring a bottle with you. The corkage is only 7 bucks. If you are a beer drinker, things will be a-ok with the selection. Options of "Red" or "White" does not a wine list make.

Tip #4: Try the 7 courses of beef, but go family style and split it with someone. It's a whole lotta beef. If you are in a group, just order an assortment of dishes and share. Reaching is acceptable here.

Tip #5: Bring your vegetarian friends here AND your cheap friends. They will all love you for it! 

My girlfriends and I enjoyed our experience and our waiter was too cute. It was obvious we had never been there before so he was really helpful with showing us what to do. We ordered a ton of food and each of us were able to try everything. We brought a couple bottles of wine with us (thank god). The bill was $28/person including a generous tip to our super sweet waiter, but you could easily go here for under 20 bucks a person. And yes, there were leftovers.
author: Kandace K.

description:
I'd give my experience here 3.5 stars

Secretly, I was delighted when my friend called to inform me Pagolac was closed.  I'd read the Yelp reviews and several people wrote Anh Hong was much better so I immediately told him we need not fret because courses of beef at another restaurant in the vicinity were waiting to be consumed by us.

In terms of portion size, Anh Hong definitely wins over Pagolac.  However for taste, Pagolac edged out ahead by just a hair.

Between the three of us, we tackled 2 servings of 7 courses of beef and the Com Tay Cam (chicken, shrimp and mushrooms with jasmine rice in claypot).

The Goi Bo (beef salad) was a winner, and a refreshing way to start off dinner.  J pointed out the slices of raw slices of beef that we swirled in broth were thicker than Pagolac, which I agreed was not as tasty.  The Bo La Lop wrapped in piper lolot leaf was with chunks of peanut nestled inside, Bo Mo Chai (grilled beef sausage) and Bo Nuang Xa (beef rolled around onion and lemongrass) were all savory-sweet crowd pleasers, with a lot of flavor and texture.  I wasn't particularly a huge fan of the steamed meatball, which tasted like bland meatloaf and the lackluster beef rice porridge wasn't nearly as delicious as Pagolac's; I'm also not a huge fan of ginger though, so the thin slivers of ginger caught me by surprise when I accidentally bit into them.

We all really liked the claypot, with chunks of soft, marinated chicken and shrimp and a generous handful of mushrooms.  The savory sauce, flavorful meats and vegetables and crackling rice were a huge hit with our table.  Definitely a pleasant surprise given our waiter didn't give us much feedback when we asked whether it was good or not.

I might go back for the claypot and the grilled beef (or go to Pagolac when it's open!)
author: Janet L.

description:
You know it's a good sign when you walk into a jammed packed Vietnamese restaurant filled with their own folks.  I'm telling ya, they know their stuff.

You can never go wrong with the 7 course beef.  IT IS TO DIE FOR.  Like seriously.  But beware, it's a whole LOTTA beef.  Beef salad, raw beef cooked in fondue, 4 different types of beef sausages and last but not least, beef porridge.  The portions are alarmingly generous so if you're on a "diet", go elsewhere. If you're not into flavor, go elsewhere.  And another thing, it might be smart to wear your fat pants, if you know what I'm saying.  The fullness factor was equivalent to me hitting up a buffet.  It was all bad...
author: Lisa W.

description:
Pretty good for the food. 
Ordered; 

Raw beef salad. Very flavorful.

Beef wrapped in Hawaiian Leaf.*
BBQ Beef, wrapped around green onion.*

*Dishes are wrapped in rice paper with assorted fresh leafy greens.
If it doesn't come to your table, ask for the pineapple/anchovy sauce.

I also noticed the charge for tea, usually a free item.

I'm sticking with Pagolac around the corner on Larkin.



Minus 2 stars for the poor service.
author: Geordie E.

description: Very good (better than Pagolac for sure), but not as good as the one in Berkeley. It's about $3 cheaper at $18.95 but they give this boiled meat dish instead of of the carpaccio. Otherwise, the meat rolls, soup and papaya salad are all very good! Most reviews will say that one order of the 7 course beef is enough for two people to share and it is definitely true. I was a little hesitant and ordered imperial rolls to add on leading to way too much food for our party of two. Try it and enjoy!!
author: Christina L.

description:
I've always liked 7 course beef.. but the only place I've had it was in San Jose at Lion Plaza... but this place people kept telling me was better.. and local :D 

SoOoo finally got to try this place.. and I still love wrapping all the rolls. :) I have mastered "roll making" 

so there was 5 girls. 3 orders of 7 course beef. Order of the raw beef/salad. and an order of Cha Gio.  WAAAAY too much food.. next time we're going to do 2 orders of the 7 course beef. :o) but it came out to about $20/pp based on what we had.. not too shabby yeah?

fun times. good food. :) will return.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Move over Pagolac! Anh Hong is THE place to go for 7-course beef. This is probably the best Vietnamese, non-Pho restaurant that I've ever been to -- fresh ingredients, awesome taste, and big portions. 

Me and a friend split one order of the 7-course beef, an order of the Cha Gio Anh Hong (Vietnamese egg rolls) and the Grilled Pork w/ Egg combination dinner. Everything was awesome -- the 7-course beef was really well-made. One thing that Pagolac had that Anh Hong doesn't is the grilled beef slices, which I would have much preferred instead of either the beef pate or the beef rolls w/ ginger. Pagolac does spice things up with allowing you to cook your own meat -- but when it comes to quality, Anh Hong wins bar-none. 

The cha gio was insanely good. Much better than at Pagolac or most other Vietnamese restaurants for that matter. I love how it comes with the vermicelli. The grilled pork was also really tasty.

This is how good the food at Anh Hong is: during dinner, I found a nasty fly floating around in my fish sauce. I told the waiter and he just took away my bowl without so much as a "sorry". Even a "oops, my bad" would have sufficed. Usually this would be the defining moment where I claim that I had a horrible experience and vow to never come back.

Yeah... I still give 5 stars.
author: Roy C.

description:
Came here last night for a friend's birthday and it was my first time at a vietnamese restaurant that didn't just serve pho. We ordered 5 orders of the 7 course beef for 10 people and some other things that I can't remember the name of. It was some type of shrimp cake. I was a little unsure of what to expect at first but as our food arrived and I tried 5 out of the 7 dishes, I actually enjoyed the food. I thought the sausages were the best though! 
oh! the vietnamese coffee was the best i've had! maybe it was because i was completely drained or maybe it was that good.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
Everyone comes here for the 7 course beef and for sure it will fill you up. If coming with a larger party, you may not even need to order one for everyone because the portions are pretty generous.

The ambience and quality isn't as good as Pagolac to me but they have more tables so it is usually a default for larger gatherings.
author: Katie K.

description:
Since I haven't been able to find a good Vietnamese joint in NYC...I'm sure it will happen soon but in the meantime I make sure to hit up old favorites in SF when I'm in town. Pagolac is my numero uno but with our large group we had to settle for Anh Hong. I've been here in the past and remember enjoying my meals so when we took our seats I felt pretty confident that the food would make up for the dismal decor and empty tables around us. 

Things we learned during our meal here:
- this restaurant doesn't serve pho
- shrimp wrapped around sugar cane is always good
- 7 courses of beef is a lot of beef

Basically, the food is good and the restaurant is good for groups but compared to Pagolac this place doesn't stand a chance.
author: Jane K.

description: Five courses of Beef.  I don't really get it but it was okay.  I prefer a big bowl of pho or bun instead.
author: Suz L.

description:
I need you to get the GASP ready....


This was my first time having Vietnamese food (insert GASP, yeah yeah ok) and I loved it. Thankfully I had Jane K to serve as Ambassador and she was fantastic at teaching how to roll up the rice paper and added tips along the lines of:

1. Do not soak the paper in the water as you will not be able to use it.

I was glad for the instruction and having someone there to share their fave dishes.

I was feeling slightly less than 100% so I also ordered a cup of chicken soup and it was perfect and included mushrooms. 

Mmmmm chicken soup.
mm mmm mmm shrimp and sugarcane
mmmm hhmm seven courses of beef
author: Maria A.

description:
One of the best 7 course beef joints I've tried over the years (Le Cheval, Mai's, this other place in chinatown oakland with a the pink awning, and a few other places i've tried in socal). Those places dont come close. They are over priced for the food they provide. 

We went last friday night for dinner, and for 2 of us, 7 courses of beef, including salad, fondue, 3 different kinds of grilled beef, 1 beef pate and a beef porridge to finish off the meal, was a total of $41!! ($18.95 per person, plus tax). The grilled beef was so good - my favorite is the grilled beef wrapped with Hawaiin leaves. Its freshly grilled, you still get the smokey aroma - goes so well with the salad wraps!

We tried to finish off everything and we did - But we were stuffed! This could've easily fed a 3rd person. The meal was completely satifying -fresh, good quality ingredients- freindly, curtious and prompt service. I am surprised at this price range and the amount of food they serve, the quality was not compromised at all! 

The decor is somewhat expected. Its been here for over 20 years. I think they've done a restoration once in that time, but they could go for another one. And they would probably draw a more yuppy crowd (sorry, Yuppies was the best way to describe it) and get more business like Le Cheval in Oakland does. Not to mention its in the Tenderloin dist. AND on top of that, parking requires about 15-20 minutes of circling around this wonder area in SF. 

So rightfully, this place serves the typical patron of your traditional vietnamese family , who expects quality/authentic food for an honest price. With that said, dont expect the waiter to give you the 101 on how to make your own rice paper wrap. Bring a friend who knows what they're doing or ask the guy at the cashier - he's the owners son, and actually does speak english and can  help you. The waiter on the other hand, is there to make sure you have everything, and serves you promptly - you'll appreicate this with the 7 courses of beef which you'll constantly need things to be replenished  - the salads for the wraps, hot water to soak the rice paper, sauce and whatever else.

My advise,  for every 3ppl, order 2 servings of the 7 course beef, bill will be $41 and you'll be very happy and full!
author: Mai T.

description: Came here for pho, and must say this is one of the better spots for pho.  I normally wouldn't come to this neighborhood, but my friend convinced me to try their food - and it really is better and/or cheaper than other Viet places in the city.
author: Josh Q.

description:
After reading some reviews and having experienced the 7 course beef meal at Pagolac, I thought it might be worth experiencing someone else's version just to compare.  I went to the Anh Hong website and learned how they purportedly invented the 7-course beef experience, and I was fooled by the pictures of a brightly-lit, 80's-ish restaurant and thought I was going to get a retro-feeling establishment with a full bar and decent lighting.  Not so much.

Anh Hong looks like a faded-out version of a diner without a counter.  Way faded out.  The place could stand to get a makeover because it's kind of hard to tell that the restaurant is even open when you show up ... so much space and no atmosphere.

If you are hungry when you arrive, you leave without an inch of space in your belly if you order the 7-course beef meal.  It's a ton of food, and it does taste pretty good.  What is hard to ignore, though, is the lack of care that goes into preparing and presenting the food at Anh Hong.  

If you want to get filled up on food with a large group, drink some beer and have your food plopped down in front of you, this is perfect.  If you are trying to impress a date, or you're not a fan of places that make you wonder what the Public Health score is, you might want to avoid Anh Hong.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I really love the food here.  It's clearly a restaurant that is frequented most by Vietnamese folks, which generally says something about the authenticity and quality of their food.

As for suggestions, the grilled pork meal is great.  The meals are big, fairly priced, and the pork wasn't fatty at all.  I really enjoy their light rice.  I also love their sizzling beef soup and their fresh rolls.  The only thing I don't like here are their Korean BBQ ribs because the time I had them they were literally 50-60% fat.

Aside from the ribs, I'm taking one star away for the service.  The first time I went we had a waiter that was not friendly at all and chastised my friend for ordering Hong Kong Rolls at a Vietnamese restaurant...then why do you have it on your menu?!?!  

Minor complaints aside, Anh Hong is definitely my favorite Vietnamese in the city.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Its been several years since my last meal here...and all I can say is that its still as good as the last time.  "7 Courses of Beef" is definitely the way to go.  I had dinner here tonight with my girlfriend and it was her first time here...judging by the look on her face, I'd say her favorite dish was raw beef with lemon juice.  

I will definitely be back here again...and I am sure my girlfriend will be too.
author: James L.

description:
Ok, so I haven't had bo 7 mon in a lonnggggggggg time but this place cranked out a pretty good set.  I would have to say that the initial salad and the final porridge were kind of lacking.  But the three types of meat rolls and the shabu style beef were off the hook.

The service is kind of random... it seemed like they kind of just crammed everything on to the plates.

I was so damn full after.  If you're going with a group, I'd say order 2 courses for every 3 people or else you'll just be overwhelmed.
author: Joey S.

description:
Wow.............Great food!!!  Very fresh........you will not find a better 7 course beef restaurant in San Francisco.  Look for Kent Le........and tell him jason g sent you.  You get what you pay for at this restaurant.  It is not cheap, but the food here is fantastic.  This is what you should order:
7 course beef set menu.........if you have 4 ppl order two set menus and add this

Tiger Prawns in chili hot sauce( 1 each would be perfect)
Imperial rolls
carpaccio

Get to know Kent Le..............he makes a world of difference when it comes to explaining the food and how it is suppose to be eaten.  I am not vietnamese but "do ma"  this is the best vietnamese 7 course beef out there.
author: jason g.

description:
Decent.

Nice service. I had the 7 courses of beef. 

Courses 3, 4, 5, & 6 all came on one small plate and were disappointing. Courses 1,2, & 7 were very good.

Do not come here with a vegetarian... we made that mistake.
author: Sara K.

description:
Meat up with us at Anh Hong!
Believe the hype. The 7-course beef dinner is too die for. Poor ol' bossy did, so the least you can do is honor her by cleaning your plates.

'Some assembly required' allows you to tailor everything to your taste. I discovered mine nearly always called for rare with that wonderful fermented anchovy sauce. 

Everything was delicious, each course uniquely flavored and complimented by a near bushel of vegetables, some pickled. The veggies allow you to savor pounds of 'la vache dlicieuse' and still feel that you did something good for your body. Lord knows, it was good for the soul.

Cutie opted for the ala carte chicken, which was juicy, tender, and perfectly charred to balance the marinade. Another platter full of raw beef, shrimp, calamari, chicken and sweet onions arrived along with a grill to cook your own--so for once, the calamari was perfect, without a hint of rubbery texture. Order this.

I am SO taking the Ohioans here when they visit.
author: Andy R.

description: Over the past few years I've eaten here numerous times and have always ordered the seven course beef dinner. The first few times I had this selection I thought it tasted great but the last 2-3 times I thought the food was just so-so. Not sure if something (chef.... ownership...recipe??) has changed. Some of my items have recently been generously stuffed with semi sautéed (ie still somewhat crunchy) onions which I didn't care for too much. I'm hoping my recent experiences were isolated as I really enjoyed the food in the past 1+ years ago.
author: Kent W.

description:
I've come here twice to try their seven course beef.
That being said, I was excited because I read on their website that they were the family that "invented" the dish and inspired the whole thing. So, naturally I thought it was going to be amazeballs. 
Eh. I dont know what it is... don't get me wrong, it IS pretty tasty, super filling, and full of flavor... but there's just something about it that doesn't 100% do it for me. 
First of all, the server guy suggested we get the "beer 33" which he claimed would "change our lives." It was the most expensive beer on the menu and did not change our lives. boo. 
Second, the second course where you cook the raw beef in the boiling broth was really... bland! I tried to dip and eat with other stuff, but nothing did it for me! Maybe I just cooked it wrong. who knows.
Third, I hate how my plate gets hella wet when I start wrapping the other courses of beef in the rice paper. annoys. 
Fourth, The service is kinda shoddy and took forever to give us anything we wanted. I attribute this to the fact that we were not vietnamese. 

OK, but other than that, I love the 3-4-5-6 courses of beef. My favorite is the one that's wrapped in the leaf! I personally don't like the onion wrapped one, but others really liked it. I just didn't like the weird texture. OOOH and the jook at the end was good yum as well.

We ordered this sugar cane shrimp dish as well which was SOOO over priced. As Betty W put it, it was like $15 dollar dimsum. o hael no. 
Their vietnamese egg rolls were delicious though. 

Oh... and when I tried to make a reservation with them, they got the date wrong and thought my name was dim.. or din... or tin. They called back to correct, but my name never really got resolved. How fun.

OMG! one last thing, right outside the restaurant a homeless man caught me off guard and held my hand very tenderly and asked dearly for some money. I ... yeah. thank you soap?
author: Tim B.

description:
moo~~ moo~~~ moo~~~~....this bovine slangin'..beef serving....meats galore will definitely put that cow in your belly.....7 course beef satisfied the carnivore in me.....tangy beef salad....beef soup....tasty beef meatballs....grilled beef...shabu shabu style beef....wrapped beef....what am i missing?....anyways..it's beef~!.....feeling a bit like a cow this morning.....price is right...food is right....it's a bargain dinner for a carnivorous beef eating treat...

mmmm...mmm....33...to quench my thirst....chug~! chug~! chug~!....*buzzin~~~*.....feeling good in the tummy and head....

*various other dishes are served here...but 7 course beef seems to be the winner in my tummy.....
author: Hen A.

description:
Seven courses of beef for only $18.95! Although none of the dishes totally blew me away, I left content and udderly full. I also had the crisp and delicious spring rolls ($5), which didn't have beef but was the best dish of the night--how ironic. The beef dishes were:

1. Beef salad - Disappointing. The little beef in there looked like pork.
2. Beef hot pot - Good and good for you (not that I care about the latter).
3. Grilled la-lot leaf-wrapped beef - Just fantastic. Flavorful and smoky.
4. Grilled lemongrass beef - Overshadowed by #3.
5. Grilled beef sausages - Absolutely succulent.
6. Steamed beef meatballs - Interesting texture. Tastes better than it looks.
7. Beef congee - Too watery. Too bad.

Despite the bad start and finish, the middle dishes made up for them. Overall it felt more like four courses than seven because #3-6 were served all on one plate. If I came to Anh Hong again, I'd stick to ordering a la carte. It's not always about quantity =P
author: Liz T.

description: The servers here have attitude.  I guess this place is so popular that they dont give a shit.  The skinny cow asked some bitch if they had pho.  Obviously it wasn't on the menu but she asked anyways.  The guy just said "dont ever ask me again if we have pho.  Its too easy to make."  I was blown away.  YOU ARE A 50 year old WAITER.  You can eat my fat ass.  I wanted to leave but I was hungry.  I was so pissed off the entire time I was eating I couldn't enjoy the food.  Enjoy your $1 tip fuckers.  Fuck this place.
author: Fatty A.

description:
I did not have the 7 courses of beef.  I'm glad because even without it, I still spent the night out smelling like grilled meats and fish sauce.  Delicious.  

We had the imperial rolls, hawaiian leaf wrapped beef, lemongrass shrimp and then the beef, shrimp and squid to grill.  We wanted to order in 2 stages but that was not allowed.  Good thing we had a wrapper (do it!) because I'm lazy and I would've ended up eating the veggies and meat like a salad.  With Euge, it was like an art form.

Everything was great and they had us in and out within an hour or so on a Saturday night.  We had good timing because halfway through our meal, we noticed there was a big line.  I'll be back to try the 7 courses of beef on a night I will be staying in.
author: Seong P.

description:
7 course beef dinner?  Um, yes please.  

I came with 8 co-workers and heeding the other Yelp reviews, we ordered only 7 of the beef dinners... however, we also got 2 orders of egg rolls...

The beef dinner comes with beef salad, raw beef slices you cook in boiling water, beef meat balls, 3 types of beef sausages and beef soup...beef, beef, beef, beef, beef!  

My favorites by far were courses 3 & 4, the meatballs and sausages that were served together.  The sausages were short, fat, and slightly sweet in flavor.  I must have I had about 8 of those babies.  And the meatballs, weren't really balls at all, more like lumps of meat, big, juicy, delicious lumps of meat.

The key is to wrap up everything up in the rice paper you are given.  This is much harder than it sounds...when my first attempt at "wrapping the beef" (dirty?) failed, everyone made fun of me...co-workers can be cruel, especially fellow Yelper Cathy T.  According to Cathy, you are supposed to wrap it like a burrito, which if you ask me is much easier said then done.

The only course I wasn't really impressed with was the thinly sliced beef wrapped around grilled onions.  Everything else was delicious and totally worth the whooping $22 (with tax!) that I paid.
author: Katherine C.

description:
7 Course Beef. 

My favorite: Bo Nuong La Lot (Beef wrapped in a Hawaiian Leaf). 

$18.95 per person. 

Leaves me stuffed and guilty every time. Go!
author: Regina L.

description:
First, I highly recommend taking the 38 Geary to get here because that is definitely a great way to meet people!!!

Came here with some coworkers for the 7 courses of beef.  I know what you're thinking, "7 COURSES OF BEEF?!? THAT IS CRAY CRAY."  And you know what?  You're right.

I wasn't too into the beef soup or the onion filled sausages but everything else was pretty awesome.  Also, rice paper is not like a tortilla and I definitely failed at every attempt to wrap up the beef.  Speaking of, always wrap up your beef.  ALWAYS.

Basically, this place is a total sausage fest.  And, fortunately, that's how I roll!

But seriously, cheap, fun and tasty.  That is all I need for a successful Monday night.
author: Evan L.

description:
If you have a fear of beef, avoid this place!  Vegetarians skip to the next review!!  However, if you love beef, read on.

In the latest Yelp event sponsored by Connie and Shatangi (did I even see Shatangi??!!), we hit this place up.   The 7 course beef meal is not to be missed.  Don't think you will be in a meat coma after eating a five pound steak.  This is Vietnamese food, and is light and lively.

The meal includes:

1)  Beef Salad ... Think of it like "Chinese" Chicken Salad.  Fantastic!

2)  Beef Hot Pot.  You get a pot of soup, veggies, and a plate of raw beef.  You can figure out what to do next!  Also you get rice paper, and a bowl of hot water to soften them up in.  Fill it with beef, veggies, lettuce, bean sprouts, etc.  Take the 1..2..3.. sauce, which are cups of anchovy paste, fish sauce, and chili sauce.  Great!

3)  Char grilled Beef.  Do the same thing ... fill the rice paper.  Also with this is calamari, shrimp and chicken.

4)  Beef Sausage!  About two inch long grilled sausage, not to sweet or salty.  YUM!  Either wrap or eat alone.  I chose to eat alone.  Have to practice my chopstick holding anyway.  Failed miserably.

5)  Beef Pate.  With this you get shrimp chips to load up with the pate.

6)  Two kinds of rolled up beef things.  Don't know what they are, but they are great!  One is rolled in a grape leaf maybe?  Closest thing to is is Lumpia Shanghai.   Another was kind of like a spring roll, but I did not see any wrapper.  This had glass noodles in it maybe?

7)  Last, and not least, is a soothing Beef Soup, with just a hint of ginger.  Just the thing to aid in digesting all that protein.

All this for $17.95.  Great deal for good food, and it actually is pretty light and not too filling.

My roommate was texting me all evening wondering what I was going to bring home.  When was I coming, are you done YET??!!  The kitchen was closed when I place a to-go order, the they made a combo grill anyway.  1 additional star!  She tore into the box, and devoured the grill plate plus the extra rolls from our table.  So that must be good too.  I was finally home at midnight.

And to Grace --- the fish sauce and Beard Papa is just plain WRONG!!
author: Michael M.

description: I was here on a Saturday night with a group of 7 of us.  The service was great, they were very attentive, the timing of the courses was perfect, and we all really enjoyed ourselves.  The 7-course was amazing!  I cannot wait to go back again.
author: Joe S.

description:
I won't go into the seven courses of beef since everyone else has described it (oh, the sticky, smelly hands problem can be easily solved by a quick trip to the bathroom. Hurrah for soap!) but I have to rave over the egg rolls! My mom explained that in Vietnam they don't use the yellow egg based wrapper but rather they use rice paper (banh trang). This way, the egg rolls come out super crispy and light. 

Anyway, tonight I nearly stabbed my mom in the hand with my chopstick in order to snatch the last egg roll. She called me a bad daughter! But boy oh boy, was it worth it. Yum.

And another thing, that grey, stinky sauce is called "mam nem" and it's English translation is (avert your eyes you of delicate sensibilities), fermented anchovy sauce. The ingredients include fermented anchovy sauce or paste, vinegar, crushed pineapple and garlic. Not too bad!
author: Nathalie L.

description:
I didn't do the 7 courses of beef here, but that didn't really matter because I was smelling like beef for the rest of the evening. 

We ordered a few things off the menu. We wanted to order in waves, but our super charismatic waiter grunted at the request and stated "NO. Order one time, now" and he proceeded to stand at our table and waited for us to order. I hate feeling rushed to order, because then I always order the wrong thing. 

We ordered the beef rolled in Hawaiian leaf. This was my favorite. 
Beef and Shrimp in lemongrass for the grill. 
Squid in lemongrass for the grill. 
Shrimp in garlic and lemongrass. This dish was really good, but pretty annoying to eat. I don't know why they cut the shells and curled them at the end, without removing them. It seems much harder to do that, instead of pulling them off completely. 

This place is good, but I won't be in a rush to come back.
author: Jen D.

description:
This is a great little Vietnamese restaurant somewhat in the Tenderloin district.  It seems like many other Vietnamese places I've been to but at this particular place I was able to experience something I haven't found at any of the others:  Seven Courses of Beef!

You know I was really excited to experience this Seven Courses of Beef when I first heard about it.  I didn't have a clue how this would be served but I expected to be stuffed by the end of it all.

It turned out to be a pretty labor intensive process, which may attract some peole and turn others off.  The first several courses consisted mainly of making your own spring rolls.  There was definitely a novelty factor as I have never done this before.  I liked dipping the rice paper in the hot water to soften it up.  I liked attempting to place all the ingredients on it and roll it up.  None of my rolls actually rolled very much though.  I will admit that after a few attempts I just decided to eat the veggies like a salad and plop the meat we were grilling straight into my mouth.

My favorite courses were the little ground beef and onion sausages.  They were super tasty!  The meatball type thing was good too.  I wish I had more room in my stomach to eat them all up but I was pretty well stuffed by that time so I had to setting fo small tastes.

With a big group the 7 Courses of Beef can be pretty fun but next time I'm ordering off the ala carte menu.  I was looking around the restaurant and the few dishes I saw looked really tasty.

Other things to note are that the service was pretty good considering the size of our group, which I believe neared 30 people.  They are very patient and very accomodating.
author: Luis M.

description:
Although i haven't ate here in a while, i think this place is pretty good. Its always packed!  As a kid, i hated this place because the bathroom is upstairs and its always dirty.  Now that they have remodeled a bit, i think its the bomb. i just hate parking around that area and walking to and from the restaurant.  It's filthy ghetto, you see all types of crackheads and whores. besides all that, the food is 5 stars and i recommend this place to all the vietnamese cuisine lovers.

ps. As a kid till now, everytime i eat here i only eat the seven course beef, i guess that is what they are known for, so keep that in mind
author: David T.

description:
I always ALWAYS come here with the family. It's a great place to sit around and pig out on GOOD food. It's definitely one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco.
Go for the 7 course beef but do NOT forget the shrimp around the sugar cane. It always seems like when I go with the family, the food just keeps coming and coming and that I start to think we've ordered too much but by the end of the meal ALL the food is gone. It's so good that you can't stop eating!
It's always fun to bring people here who have never tried it before and teach them how to roll up their little spring rolls like "burritos."
Dee-lish!
author: Lisa G.

description:
Just wanted to write an update about the SERVICE here. My friend, Helen V. and I have been here countless times with our families...and we never get any beef (no pun intended) about how many orders of 7 course beef we order. 

HOWEVER, whenever we come with just our friends...the workers here treat us like little kids and try to bully us around. Usually, you place 1 order for every 1.5 - 2 persons with maybe a side of egg rolls. Last night, we had a group of 14....so we wanted 8 orders of the 7 course beef and 2 orders of egg roles. 

The waiter..."Mr.Know It All"...looked pissed and kept insisting that this was NOT enough. He was trying so hard to get us to order more...but we were adamant about not needing anymore. We told him we come here ALL THE TIME and we know what portions we want. And you know what...we had MORE than enough food left at the end. 

They are just trying to make money and will trick you into ordering more if you look vulnerable. Stick to what you want...don't let them force you into doing what you don't want to do. NO MEANS NO!
author: Allan M.

description:
I love living in San Francisco because of the bomb food, even in the hood. Vietnamese food is my favorite and this place is spring rolls paradise.

I come here with the fam bam and order the 7 course beef, the eggrolls, and my brother oddly a rice dish. IT IS ALL ABOUT THE SPRING ROLLS KIDS!!

The vegetables were fresh, pickled vegetables were a delight, meat was hot and juicy and I left there a happier man. And a happier man makes me a better man.
author: Dorian T.

description: Came here with a bunch of friends for the 7 course beef menu! We sat at a giant round table with a lazy susan in the middle. We really had no idea what we were in store for! The food was pretty good, heavy on the sausage for my taste but definitely worth the money and a fun experience! Can't say I'd be back anytime soon though...
author: Claire b.

description:
Hands-on Eating...by Make-Your-Own Vietnamese Rolls!

At Anh Hong, you can order specialty dishes and it comes with dry rice paper, a bowl of hot water, mint, sweet basil, lettuce, cucumber, condiments such as fish sauce, hot sauce and shrimp paste.

The idea is to make your own roll by dipping the dry rice paper into the bowl of hot water to soften it and then adding your own ingredients from the specialty dishes and dipping sauces.

Some of my favorite specialty dishes are:

- Sugar cane shrimp
- Grilled shrimp
- Grilled pork with vermicelli
- Grilled beef with lemongrass
- Beef sausages wrapped in Hawaiian leaves

It's tasty and fun way to play with your food!  The more the merrier!
author: Lis A.

description:
It's beef and there are seven course... enough said.

This place is pretty cool, I think it was about $15 /person.  You definitely want to go there with 4+ people.  It's very low key; the crowd is mostly Vietnamese families.  The food is tasty; those familiar with Vietnamese know that some prep and participation is required.  The meal starts with a beef soup, beef pate etc. Worth a visit.
author: Nopadon W.

description: Yea yea, everyone knows and loves 7 courses of beef, but this place also has Beef Carpaccio AKA "Bo Tai Chanh", and it makes me melt in my seat. Very rarely will I find a dish I can call "divine", and this, my friends, is one of them.
author: Robin H.

description:
I went here last week for the latest installment of the 'let's stuff ourselves with food until we make strange bodily noises and pass out' Yelp dining event, which this time was organized by Shatangi and Connie...between these meals and all the happy hours thrown by Yelpers I'm gonna run out of usable organs soon!

I tried the seven course beef meal (which actually ended up being eight courses), and it was fantastic! Sadly, I never tried the last course (the beef rice soup) but I more than made up for that omission by eating what felt like 6,723 sausages and various beef rolls...if crack were a sausage, Anh Hong would be an illegal pleasure.

Pretty much everything was great, but my faves were courses two through seven (assuming that we had eight courses):

- The second course was thinly-sliced slices of tenderloin that you cook in a red wine vinegar sauce (fondue style) and add to veggies to prepare your own spring rolls.

- The third course was beef, chicken, shrimp and squid that you cook on a hot plate and again add to veggies to prepare your own spring rolls. I didn't see this item on the menu on Anh Hong's website, so I'm assuming that it was either a 'bonus course', or that it's combined with the fondue (which would bring us back down to seven courses).

- The fourth course was some very tasty charcoal-grilled beef sausages. Suffice to say, I ate a bunch of these...

- The fifth course was some large steamed beef meatballs that you chop up and enjoy with shrimp chips...excellent!

- The sixth course was minced beef mixed with spices and wrapped in Hawaiian leaves. This was by far my favorite item of the meal, and I would guess that I ate no less than eight of these bad boys!

- The seventh course was charcoal grilled tenderloin rolls topped with peanuts and lemongrass sauce. I was running out steam at this point and only had one or two of these.

Every once in a while a meal comes along that is so good, but also so huge that you need to unleash your 'inner fat guy' (I weighed 300 lbs. at one time) to take it down, and this was definitely one of these meals! It was worth every stomach-stuffing (towards the end) bite though...and very affordably priced.

Count me in as a future Anh Hong repeat customer!
author: Art D.

description:
My first impression of this place was that it was filled with Asians, and over half of them were Vietnamese. Always a good sign. The menu lists a plethora of traditional Vietnamese dishes but as the place markets its specialty as 7-course beef, that's what we opted to order.

The first dish was goi bo, or beef salad. It was validating to see traditional Vietnamese salad ingredients such as basil, mint, red onions, and carrots - all julienned or finely chopped. They even served two sauce options, both fish sauce-based and very delicious.

The second dish is a favorite in most Vietnamese households and is so very refreshing: beef fondue with special vinegar sauce. The dish is served with slices of raw tenderloin beef, an overflowing plate of greens, and pickled veggies. To eat, you just cook the beef in the fondue pot and then make a spring roll with the cooked beef, greens, and pickled veggies. Dipping sauces are the same as the salad above.

The third, fourth, fifth and sixth courses all arrived at the same time on one platter. It was a sight to behold! One item was steamed beef pate - delicious meat balls mixed with nuts, mushrooms and various Vietnamese spices. Another item was grilled beef sausage with a flavor that made me miss Grandmother's cooking. An item I don't think I've ever had was the beef wrapped in Hawaiian leaf. This was also mind boggling. But my absolute favorite of this combo was the slices of tenderloin in lemon grass and green onion and grilled to tender perfection. 

By the time the seventh and final course arrived, I was ready to burst. I had already scanned ahead and knew that beef rice porridge was coming. I expected a thicker consistency but was relieved to see that the broth was at once watered down and strongly flavored. 

Now that I am just getting to know SF's Little Saigon, I am reluctant to But I do want to say that this place kicks ass.
author: Baochi N.

description: I love Vietnamese food, always have.  Lots of leafy greens, meat and plenty of spices.  I usually get the "do it yourself" wraps with rice paper.  I change up my meat options and always enjoy the meal.  I have yet to try the 7 courses of beef, but I will one day soon.  When that day happens, life will be complete.
author: Corey V.

description: Tweedle Dumb and Tweedle Dumber -the two guys running the place - are the two worst "servers" I've encountered in San Francisco. I've been to so many Vietnamese restaurants that are fantastic, but this is not one of them. Tired, run down... it's what I imagine dining out was like immediately after Saigon fell.
author: Adam R.

description: Seven course beef. *drool* what more can i say? If you've never had it and you like Vietnamese food, it's definitely worth a try. Be prepared to use your hands and wrap the beef with stuff they give you (that's how you eat it).  It took my husband about two tries to fully appreciate the food and its aromas and the extremely hands-on process. If you don't get dirty, you're not doing it right! Well, unless you're my husband. In which case, I'll be wrapping everything for you 'cause you don't do it right lol JK honey
author: S. D.

description:
You know a busy Vietnamese restaurant is legit when you're the only caucasian there.  

Perhaps I'm biased due to its proximity to where I live and that I frequent it, well, frequently, but this is the best Vietnamese restaurant I've found in the city so far.  

My personal favorite is what I like to call the "Vietnamese Burrito".  They bring raw meat and shrimp to your table, you cook it yourself over an iron skillet then you wrap it up in rice paper with mint and veggies.  

Considering I'm the one doing all the cooking and assembly you'd think it would be less expensive, but its not unreasonable and the process is a lot of fun.  

I wouldn't go so far as to say the waitstaff is friendly, though it could just be a cultural thing.  Basically you'll learn more by spying on the families sitting around you then you will asking the waiter, should you need some tips on how to wrap up your roll.  

Where the restaurant lacks in ambiance it makes up in GREAT food that comes to your table FAST.  I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who wants to try something a little different and have fun doing it.
author: Ted T.

description:
SEVEN COURSES OF BEEF
oh yes.  Gotta love it.  You make a little mini vietnamese spring roll out of everything--and no rice noodles to get in the way of your enjoyment of the meet and veggies.  The veggies include fresh mint, lettuce, pickled daikon and carrets.  You get these little round rice paper things that you dip into hot water, and then soften, and you roll up your food in it.  SOOO good.

You also get your choice of 2 different fish sauces (I'm not vietnamese so I don't know the names) but one is your "normal" clear, sweet-and-sour  fish sauce.  The other is a greyish pasty thing that smells really bad, but tastes really good...strong flavor and very sweet.  There's NO WAY this isn't authentic.

Baochi has described the courses, so I won't go into that.  My favorite is also the rolled up slice of marinated steak with the onions inside.  SOO tasty.

16.95 plus tax and tip, so it comes to ~$21 a person, plus any beverages you got.  Simple to budget eh?

The manager (who is I believe nephew of the owner of the San Jose branch) told us he enjoys the 7 courses with a nice Riesling.  I'll have to try that next time... ;)

Ah I love this place.  This and the one in SJ are the best "normal" vietnamese I've had in SF. awesome.  Simply awesome.
author: Fong L.

description:
He says :  I would give it 5 stars.....but my car window did get smashed once while parked on a neighboring street.  The food is so good though, I still go back (but I insist on parking on a better street and not leaving ANYTHING not locked up in the glovebox or covered). 

We usually get the 7 courses of beef (YUM YUM YUM!) and/or the shrimp w/ sugar cane, the egg rolls, and more.  Almost everything is supposed to be ROLLED up, wrapped like an asian burrito (filled with noodles, fresh mint, carrots, etc) and dipped into vietnamese fish sauce.  They don't explain the dishes or help newbies like Pagolac (nearly around the corner!) but don't be shy!  Roll 'em up and eat!

RECOMMENDED!!

She Says:

So I basically grew up with the knowledge that this was THE PLACE for seven course beef.  It's still as good as it was when I was a kid.  If you have a open mind and love Vietnamese food, this is a good place to experiment, roll and eat.  I savor the banana leaf sausages and egg rolls and the porridge.  If you are feeling extra adventurous, try the RAW beef salad (different from the one in the 7 courses).  It's like Vietamese Cerviche!  Tasty!!!
author: Miss Bonnie B.

description:
I came here last night with my parents for my mom's birthday. I've been here many times before in the past, but this was the first time I've been here in about a year. It was crowded like it's always been. We were lucky that there was one last table available when we got there. 

Between the three of us we ordered 2 orders of the 7 courses of beef and 1 order of the Cha Gio Anh Hong (Vietnamese egg rolls with pork and shrimp). The Chao Tom (Shrimp on sugar canes) is also delicious. The price for the 7 courses of beef, $18.95, was higher than the last time i came, but still a good deal for the amount of food that you get.

The 7 courses of beef consisted of:
1. Beef salad
2. Beef carpaccio
3. Grilled beef wrapped in lot leaf
4. Grilled beef stuffed with onions and lemongrass
5. Grilled beef sausages
6. Steamed beef meatball with shrimp chips
7. Beef porridge

Each order of the 7 courses of beef comes with a bowl of rice paper, a plate of greens (lettuce, mint, and cilantro), and a plate of sides (bean sprouts, pickled carrots and daikon, and cucumbers). I always love to make my own rolls with the rice paper and all the different sides. All of the beef was very tender and flavorful. The beef carpaccio comes with a small charcoal hotpot and beef broth to cook it in. Items 3 through 5 come together as a sort of a sampler of beef sausages. The beef wrapped in lot leaf was my favorite! 

The service was very good. As soon as we finished one course of beef, the waiters brought out the next one almost immediately. Although there are other 7 courses of beef places in San Francisco such as at Pagolac and Pho Garden, Anh Hong is the best!
author: Danny T.

description: great place for cheap vietnamese food. Quite dirty, but their 7 course beef was good, but I feel like Pagolac is better. I had ordered this and it was very filling and can definitely be split between two people.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Pho is to lunch......7 courses of beef is to dinner.  This place ROCKS for all of you that love beef and vietnamese food.  Their specialty is the unrelentless onslaught of beef when you order the meal set.  It consists of...

1.) Rare beef salad (well, it's suppose to be rare....but this place serves it semi-cooked with cucumbers, carrots, onions, greens.)

2.) Steamed beef pate' (meat balls with nuts, mushrooms, spices)

3.) Rare beef fondue (for cooking at table)

4.) Grilled beef sausage charcoal-broiled

5.) Beef wrapped in Hawaiian leaf

6.) Grilled beef with lemon grass

7.) Beef porridge 

All this is served with thin rice paper and cabbage so you can wrap your own roll. Add some fish sauce and mam nem pha san sauce (fish sauce with fresh garlic and lemongrass)...and you are set for a great meal.

If you are not a meat eater....they also got a variety of combo plates which are average.  Comes with fried rice, salad, egg roll and your choice of meat (BBQ chicken, short ribs, etc.)

Located at a more safer side of TL....there's only one bum on the street at a time.

2x Yummy for my tummmy
author: Dave L.

description: Best 7 course beef in the city. Been going here since I was a little kid. I dont like the area, but I'd trek down to the TL just to eat there!
author: Chris L.

description:
YES FINALLY......BO 7 MONG!!! (seven beef course meal)
CAN U SMELL THE FISH SAUCE??? YUMMMY!!!

typical vietnamese setting which is BLAH.   Service is typical vietnamese which is terrible.   so i dont try to rate it accordingly.

amazingly flavorful.... but a bit too sweet ... i haven't had a great Bo 7 Mong till here.

if it was just a lil less sweet and the service is better... then it will be 5 stars for sure.

Fish sauce is yummy
Eggrolls are yummy.  
of course the Bo 7 Mong course is yummy too
author: Joanne H.

description: It's always a fun experience to come here and eat. It's very unique and you don't need to think too much about what to order. This place is always busy so expect a short wait on the weekend. If you are a fan of rice paper, this is the place for you. Highly recommended. :)
author: Sandy L.

description:
How do you say "Oh dear, I do believe I'm going into anaphylactic shock, please pass the epinephrine" in Vietnamese?

Just curious, you know, so I can be prepared next time...
author: Mister X.

description:
$17.95 is cheap for 7 courses of beef!

I've eaten at this same-named place in SoCal and in Milpitas so I know they know their beef.  I couldn't eat after course 5!  So, so stuffed.  Everything was good, I'm surprised I don't go more often.  It's such a great deal and no one leaves hungry.  The only thing I would change is the first course - they give you the option to switch out - and instead of the beef salad course, you should get the beef marinated with lemon/lime.  They also ask if you would like to order appetizers or extra dishes - JUST SAY NO!  You will thank me later when your pants are still buttoned and your party doesn't have to roll you out.
author: Lynnie P.

description:
This is one of my top favs in SF. 
Not sure if he's the owner or what, but he's super cool and can speak Dutch. Very friendly too. 

We had the 7 course beef and it was so filling!!
author: Judi K.

description:
Don't wanna write too much

Had 7-course beef but  Pagaloc was better in my opinion.  (although i did like the beef porridge)   waiter recommended the fish cake wraped in sugar cane which was interested but not to die for.

Parking too hard, Service was pretty good, but came stinking like the food. (maybe we were too close to the kitchen)  I really would give it a 3.5 stars but i really did stink.
author: Sum W.

description:
totally awesome! YUMMERS!!!
grilled chicken rice plate is great! bbq pork rice plate is the BEST!
7 courses of beef is totally outta this world!
lots o' bang for your buck, buckos!

food is great but service NEEDS to be improved!!
author: K K.

description:
this is the spot for Bò 7 Món (seven courses of beef). my family and i recently ventured to this restaurant for dinner. we ordered 3 portions of Bò 7 Món and that was more than enough food for 4 people. 

Bò lá lot (beef wrapped in lolot leaf) is probably my favorite of the 7 dishes. Its perfect when dipped in Mam Nem Sauce...definitely not something that everyone's palette can handle. 

great service. the waiters were always there when we needed something and even took the time to notice that we needed more lettuce at the table and brought some more out for us even though we didn't ask for any. 

come and check it out. be ready to eat and make sure you wear clothes that don't have to be dry cleaned because you're gonna be smelly when you leave. =P
author: Linda N.

description:
WOW - this is as good as it gets when it comes to authentic Viet 7-course beef!  I was first introduced to this by my brother-in-law about a year ago and it's been addicting since.  I go at least once/twice a month. 

My favorite dish is the beef sausage.  The shrimp on the sugarcane is a very popular dish that is a must if you enjoy seafood.  It gets very crowded in the evenings as they only open for dinner.  I recommend making reservations in advance if you can, otherwise, it can be quite a wait.   It's not in the greatest location and the atmosphere of the restaurant is nothing to really talk about, but the food is excellent - generous portions and the price is right!  7-course/person is about $17.  It is very filling and the beef rice porridge is very delish.  They also make their own homemade fish/anchovy sauce that is quite powerful to the palate.  A must try!
author: JADE L.

description:
My BF + family loves this place. 

I was going to end there, but I guess I should add to it to strengthened this review's credibility. My BF's family came from Vietnam, so they know authentic Vietnamese food when they taste it. If you run by there at night, they are almost always packed with people, especially Vietnamese people. Honestly, if you are going to go to an ethnic restaurant, you would probably want to try the ones that people of the same ethnicity would go to too. What better proof of authenticity than that?

This was also the first place I've tried 7 course beef, and boy was it fun! Lots of different types of food/options I've never tried prior, like eating different textured porridge, rolling your own Vietnamese rolls, delish papaya salads, cooking beef in a little pot-pan-wok. I love imperial rolls, you can't keep me away from them. There is also a dish that comes with a couple of (shrimp-like) chips, and I usually hoard those.

I forgot to mention that the food is delicious! The portions aren't as big as your regular pho bowls, so you might have to add to it with additional orders, dishes etc. It's also nice to go with someone you know, or ask the next table, to make sure you are ordering the right stuff!
author: Tiffany L.

description: Came here looking for pho and what did I get? BEEF, BEEF AND MORE BEEF. Holy crap, I was beef'd out by the time my friend and I were done. We ordered two appetizers and one 7 course beef meal. We saw that everyone raved about it online so we had to try it and to our dismay that 7 course beef was almost the death of us! Haha. We began with our appetizers - beef carpaccio and imperial rolls. This place is family style so you can imagine the portions... We were definitely ill informed. Lol. After the appetizers came the waves of beef. Beef spring rolls, 3 different sausages, and jook. Man, how we came out alive, I don't know, but this place really surprised us not only by its volume, but also because we enjoyed it. The food was good and servings generous. It was also fairly priced. Great place for big parties, not so much for two little women.
author: Jackie M.

description:
Warning: Before reading/eating, be prepared to smell like all sorts of beefy goodness when you are done. 

---------------------------------------------------------------

Given that there are not many other options for 7 courses of beef in San Francisco AND they share the same name as an outstanding venue in Orange County...plus the abundance of fresh herbs and really nice service...I give them a solid 4 stars. 

The beef offerings in the 7 course set is not exactly the same as I am used to having in Southern California (Orange County).
