However, that was easily addressed by requesting an order of Tom Bo Nuong Vi (marinated beef and shrimp for self-grilling at the table; similar to korean bbq). Here are the highlights:
- beef papaya salad was a little bland and lacked the variety of texture that is what usually makes the dish; maybe the papaya was not as fresh as I'm used to, or they could have added some shredded celery stalk for more crunch.
- beef fondue with vinegar broth, this was tasty...although the beef slices were a bit thick, that made it easier to not overcook the meat. Plus, they put some additional seasoning in the broth (not just straight vinegar)...I like.
- shrimp was hard to cook because of the butterfly cut, but it was very pretty while grilling. They seasoned the beef and shrimp with the Mam Nem...yummy! The additional sauce tantalizes your taste buds with sweet saltiness.
- Bo Cha Dum and the variety of "meatballs" were their best offerings of the 7 courses, in my opinion. Very well done on this one. Everything on the plate was delicious.
- Chao Bo...I love love love porridge. And usually Bo 7 Mon restaurants don't put much care in the last course because it's just meant to wash down the previous 6 courses. However, Anh Hong makes a delicious beef porridge. They include slivers of kidney and liver which you can hardly taste unless you're paying attention -- and man, was I! YUM-MEeeeee!

Ok. So if all of that doesn't have you walking out your door right now, just think of the mad bragging rights you'll have after your visit to Anh Hong..."dude, I just had SEVEN courses of beef. That's right. Seven." Don't forget the beer. If you want to do it Vietnamese style, go with a beer with high bitterness rating (e.g. Bud, Heineken, etc).

Because I mentioned the service earlier, here is an obligatory anecdote about it: En route to said restaurant, my friend's finger got in the way of a car door shutting. So I told the waiter about it and asked him for a bag of ice. They did not have ice but he pulled out his wallet and furnished a bandaid -- and a few moments later came with a spray can, which I think was a pain relief, antibacterial spray. haha. Something was lost in translation but how caring...!
author: Cat T.

description:
SO much fun. Seven-course beef, big group of people, and a very hands-on meal! 

*Fry, dip, fill, roll* 
*Fry, dip, fill, roll* 
*Fry, dip, fill, roll* 
*Fry, dip, fill, roll*
*Fry, dip, fill, roll*
*Fry, dip, fill, roll*
*Fry, dip, fill, roll*

And that's only one of the seven courses.......................... YESSS.

I walked (stumbled? rolled?) away stuffed to the brim and sublimely satisfied. Totally worth the sketch walk through the Tenderloin. I can't wait to come back!!!
author: G. J.

description:
Anh Hong is the name of my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in San Diego (that also serves a mean 7 Course Beef), so I admit I had high hopes for this place.  The 7CB here is just ok.  I was disappointed they left out my favorite course - the thinly sliced beef that you grill yourself with butter and onions.  

In comparing it to Pagolac, you get more food here, but I think Pagolac is better overall because: 

1) the beef carpaccio at Pagolac beats the beef salad here any day, 
2) the cut and flavor of the sliced beef for the fondue course was not quite as good here, 
3) Pagolac has the butter grilled beef course, 
4) the beef soup is slightly better at Pagolac, and 
5) the service is waay better at Pagolac (though somewhat bad and inattentive service may lead to a more "authentic" Asian dining experience, so take your pick) (I can say that because I'm Asian).  

Anh Hong gets a point for having the meatball with chips course missing at Pagolac, but I'm afraid that is not enough to overcome the other factors.
author: Leslie L.

description: oh. my. gosh. the food here is so good!!!!! order the 7 courses of beef and the beef carpaccio, you won't be disappointed. friendly staff, but you might want to make reservations, this place gets packed on the weekends.
author: Jen D.

description: always one of my favorite.  Excellent food and recommend to try the 7 courses.  Thanks for always treating me as VIP.  Friendly environment.
author: tomcat f.

description: Never coming here again. They refused to serve us because we weren't that hungry and wanted to share some plates. They said there was a minimum order. That's a first for me. We walked out.
author: A L.

description:
Awwww Shieettt....  My associates always tell me that if you are going to eat 7 courses of beef, you have to come here.  Well, I guess I have taken their word for it cause I haven't tried it anywhere else.  And why would I, I think I would just be disappointed because the food here is always top notch.  And I always walk out of here with a very BIG BELLY!  This is one place I am ALWAYS STUFFED after the meal.  Can't help it though.  The food is just too good.

By the way, just in case anyone is interested, the current price per person for the 7 courses of beef is $17.95
author: Mark W.

description:
Hmm, seven courses of beef? I'm there! 

I feel like a slight failure of a Vietnamese girl for having never even heard of this meal before, but that's ok, since this multi-course meal is considered to be more on the higher end of Vietnamese cuisine. Your good little Vietnamese friends have probably never had this meal either.

Anyway, the food was awesome! The beef salad & jook didn't really seem to highlight the flavor of beef very much, which I guess is why they are the starter & finishing dishes. The beef salad was pretty good , but the jook -- well, my mom can make better. The 3rd through 6th courses are the highlight of the meal, of course, being an array of rolled up beef, sausages, & meatballs. My favorite are the la lot wrapped sausages.

Just for anyone who doesn't know (hey, I didn't), the proper way to eat courses 2-5 is to roll the meat up in the rice paper w/ the accompanying fresh vegetables to make spring rolls & then dip them into the sauces. You could probably roll up course 6 also, but I like to eat those w/ just the rice crackers. Even though the price is "$18.95 per person", you can order one serving's worth & probably feed two people. I went with 8 people & we were pretty full with 4 servings. & a final note: I personally think it is really important to understand that these dishes are all considered "drinking dishes" in Vietnamese culture (ok, except for the jook -- that's considered a ~good health~ dish). So, to really enjoy the meal, drink a lot of beer!
author: Ruby H.

description:
Great food! My group of 5-6 usually get three orders of 7-beef, 2 orders of the raw beef slices (with the lemon sauce), and spring rolls. They got the best viet spring rolls. yummy! You basically take the vegetables and the beef and roll it up with the rice paper that they provide. You get "unlimited" vegetables and rice paper with your 7-beef orders. But I wouldn't come here often. Maybe once in a few months.

Oh yes, my favor dish of the 7-course-beef is the last one, the porridge/soup. It's the bomb!
author: Sam W.

description: Only been here once but the service was great, the food was terrific and the place was clean.  Bad part, the parking sucks and it's not the nicest restaurant by far.  But yeah, order the 7-course beef meal and ask the owner to help you out with the rolling and you should be good.
author: Don A.

description: The food was not bad, but their portion sizes were incredibly wasteful (a whole open glass of fish sauce, way too many greens to possibly eat). And the service was absurdly slow. Their floor was also quite dirty.
author: Irene M.

description:
This place is great for 7 courses of beef. Came here hungry, left COMPLETELY full. I felt like I was waddling out the door. It was a good thing I walked to get there!

Food had great flavor and I would definitely come here again.
author: Chris B.

description:
We tried to eat here twice, we were successful once.  Unfortunately for us.  Apparently if you are not Vietnamese, the waitstaff completely ignores you, seats about 3 other parties and serves them food before they come to the corner they have stuck you in to see if you are still alive.  I did not try the beef invasion, we had a horrible deep-fried something and ran out of there as fast as we could. NEVER AGAIN!!!
For a GREAT Vietnamese place in a better neighborhood and with GREAT service, try Aux Delices on Polk street between green and union.  They are so much better!
author: Nilu r.

description:
SEVEN
FLAVORS
of
BEEF!!

Seriously, do I need to say more?  Well, I will.  I ate my weight in beef that glorious day celebrating 25 years of chink.  I only begrudge Ed M. for not taking me there sooner.  Come on man, we shared a drywall!

They lose a star for having a couple things that just felt like slight variation of a prior course.  But that's not to say that it wasn't delicious the second time around.  The best was the make your own rice paper roll.  

The staff was great about coming around and pretty much giving a couple tables worth of ignorant, loud asshats lessons in how viet food (outside of pho) works.

Me: Ed...
Ed: That was really good, huh?
Me: You know how I've said before how I don't want children?
Ed: yeah...
Me: This is yet another reason to never get knocked up!  I can feel stretch marks forming on my stomach.

Ed, you knocked me up with a beef baby.  You bastard.  Where is my child support?
author: Michelle P.

description:
I've been going to Anh Hong since I was a kid.  We used to come here whenever someone visited us from out of town.  The food has always been good and at the time, my parents kept saying that their veggies are really fresh and nice looking.  Yesterday, we took a friend there for her birthday and I must say that they have kept their quality of the food very consisent.  I also noticed that they printed new menus but everything else was the same.  

A must try is their shrimp in sugar cane... yum!! and of course everyone comes here to eat the 7 course beef.  I don't really like all 7 courses, so I like it when my dad orders other more authentic vietnamese beef dishes.  You can still wrap them, but they are just different kind.  At Anh Hong, you can get the kind where they give you a grill, and you can grill your own slice of beef and all.  Sooo yummy.
The seven course beef is only $17.95 per person and they are not sticklers here that they count the # of people.  YOu can say you want 4 orders only and try other stuff on their menu.  

The super thing about this place is that we only had 1 server for a party of 12. That's right.  He got us our food, bussed our table, re-filled our tea, and whatever else we needed, like napkins, extra forks, water, etc.   He did not even miss a beat.  Shit.. this is what i'm talking about good service.  

and some things never change.  The owner is this fat dude and he hasn't changed one bit since I was a kid.  He still has that big belly, still a bit bald and wears those weird patterned shirts.

1 star off for having  dead fly on our table and a fly found in a bowl.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Love this place! went last nite, long wait on a thursday nite and only for a party of 2. Big family dinner restaurant.

Had the Beef carpacio (raw beef) for the first time, and it was DELICIOUS! Had the 7 course beef for the second time, it was just as good as when i had it the first time.

The owner's were really nice/friendly. This girl tried to steal our table (we were there frist and had signed in at the front), the owners were very accomodating/fair and let us have the table first, as we should!! They even comped us for the Beef carpacio bc of the wait/the girl!

Great service, great food. Will be bringing my family there when they visit SF.
author: Diana T.

description:
That 7 course meal is the only reason why I come here with my family. It is AMAZING. I mean, it's not completely out of this world, but it's a fun! You get to make your own spring rolls and everything. How do you NOT get full? 

By the time the 7th dish comes around, we're too full to move. I love that feeling. LOL. I would come back here soon if it didn't cost so much.

$21.95 for one, just to let you know. :o
author: Jessica T.

description:
I have been going to this place for years on the advice and with some of my closest Vietnamese friends, we go for birthday and other celebrations. For some reason I have never yelped it before this. I have only had the 7 course beef which is yummy and you can never eat it all which makes me feel a bit wasteful so luckily bring you a to go box which will put a bad smell in your car for while even if you stick the food in the trunk, so my suggestion is to have you friend drive :) 

The staff is friendly, not totally on top of it but not terrible either, I enjoy interactive food, kind of like lazy people cooking if you ask me and best of all you don't have to do to the dishes. Much better than TV dinners, do they make that in Vietnamese food? hmmm possible invention in the works...

I enjoy everything about 7 course beef, however I would be more than OK with 4 or 5 courses of beef.
author: Bobby B.

description: Been here for a few times. The 7 course beef is of course very good. I like that the food is traditional Vietnamese, with tons of delicious herbs and greens to pile on. The service isn't great. The male waited we have had the times we have been there was actually pretty rude. But, it wouldn't stop me from returning. It's pretty solid.
author: jen w.

description:
Me and my friend had our first time try at this restaurant tonight, this is the worst experience we ever had!! This waiter was telling us what's the best there, we didn't order 7 courses of beef cuz we were not that hungry, we came here just because we wanted to try out Vietnamese food and found it on yelp. Very disappointed in their service! NO SERVICE AT ALL! 

And this waiter ordered the food that he told us is good without telling us. When we asked for another menu, he was like I already ordered for you! I go what did I order? He pointed the food on the menu that he suggested! I go alright, fine, since you said they are the best! However, the food was just ok. 

Well I guess the point is the server... again, NO SERVICE AT ALL! pissed us off ! we still paid tip tho, which I don't think they deserve any!

Def will NOT go back again!
author: Jessie c.

description: 7 course beef vietnamese.
author: Jim J.

description: 7 course beef extraordinaire!  Super yummy and can't wait to return.  Though am sad they removed the grilled beef course from the choice.  Was here a few years ago and remember one of the 7 courses included grilling your own beef.  But now if you want that you have to buy it separately.
author: Lev E.

description: This review is not for the food but rather their business hours. Went all the way there on a Tuesday evening 5/21 at 5 pm and the place was closed.
author: KL H.

description: l love this and I order this every time I go here: Shrimp wanton soup, Tom Nuong Banh Hoi (grilled shrimp with rice cake, prepared oriental style). ....slammin!!
author: Fatemah N.

description:
I know all this hoohah about Anh Hong's and the Seven Courses of Beef... but I will have to give it an okay review.  

Maybe its because I went in a huge group of about 20 and the food quality declined a bit...maybe it was the huge fish swimming in the tank behind me or my position at the end of a table staring directly at the birthday boy...tried the 7 courses of beef, but I think because they put everything onto one plate even though several people ordered the beef, we kinda got shafted... there wasn't even enough for everyone to get full! I came out hungry, and for a foodmonster, this is UNACCEPTABLE! : / Argh ( I know, I'm a pirate ;D)

However, the saving grace was the salad, it was THAT good, and i liked the sausages too.  The salad was just beefy enough but also light enough that it had flavor and substance to it, and the sausage thingys were just pure carnivore heaven!  I also liked that there was a beef congee thing at the end so you could wash out the flavors in your mouth.  A nice end to an otherwise heavy meal.  

I'm disappointed to say I had an okay experience, but I am willing to give this one another go, with my OWN Seven Courses of Beef please!!! Anyone down?
author: Linda C.

description:
Atmosphere: A family spot for the Vietnamese food goers.

Service: The food comes out quick, especially during dinner time since they have so many customers to squeeze in. Very good service for a Vietnamese Place.

Food: Always the seven course beef! Make sure not to over order. One order serves about 2 people. For big eaters like me, add the egg rolls and the shrimp wrapped sugarcane.
Make sure to use the wraps, don't be lazy. I'm not a fan of the shrimp paste sauce, and I'm sure a lot of other people aren't because of the smell.

Overall: I've been coming here since I was a kid and always enjoy venturing over here for special dinners. Definitely better than Pagolac and their Berkeley location. Have a date with someone that enjoys something different? This is the spot to hit up.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
An Anthropology of Vietnam in Seven Courses
Omid T=======.
Anthro 132A


 In the course of examination of a culture, it would be irresponsible to omit the study of foodways as a cultural phenomenon as tied to religion, holidays, ethnic identity, domestic economy, and history.º The ideas expressed herein are the result of 2.5 hours of immersive field study at Anh Hong restaurant in San Francisco, CA, as related to Bo 7 Mon, (Bo Bay Mon) known commonly in the English language as Beef Seven Ways or Seven Courses of Beef.


 Bo 7 Mon is ideally representative of Vietnamese culture from the first millennium BC to the present day, reflecting Chinese, Khmer (Cambodian), and French influences in everyday foodways. Created as recently as the 1950's by the progenitors of Anh Hong's ownersºº, Bo 7 Mon is now widely served at Vietnamese wedding banquets, as well as restaurants throughout the world. The influence of this feast is not only far-reaching, but has been propagated in a relatively short period of time. It is the aim of this paper not to examine the meal's influence upon culture, but culture's influence upon the meal.


 Before continuing, it is important to identify the components of Bo 7 Mon, as presented by Anh Hong. Please note that other restaurants may present the dishes in a different order, or with several different components altogether.


 Bo 7 Mon is comprised of Goi Bo (a beef salad mixed with assorted vegetables), Bo Dung Dam (beef fondue in which slices of raw tenderloin are dipped in a hot pot of vinegar sauce), Bo Cha Dum (steamed beef pate with nuts and mushrooms), Bo Moi Chai (grilled beef sausages), Bo La Lot (mince beef wrapped in Lot leaf), Bo Nuong Sa (grilled beef roulades around scallion, flavored with lemongrass), and Chao Bo (beef rice soup with scallions, ginger and lemongrass).


 The first and most obvious element of Bo 7 Mon is Bo or, more simply, beef. While Chinese cuisine serves as the basis of Vietnamese cooking (i.e. the use of broths, noodles, and the extensive incorporation of rice), the consumption of beef is representative of the vast influence of the Mongol empire, namely the Mongolian invasion of the 13th century.+


 Furthermore, the Khmer influence from neighboring Cambodia brought forth the use of what is commonly referred to now as small plates, as opposed to large, centralized meals.+


 Taking the above-named influences and mating them with the abundance of fresh vegetables and herbs and rich fishing waters of the Mekong Delta has resulted in much of the Vietnamese cuisine that survives to this day. Thus, one is commonly able to consume beef accompanied by rice noodles, rice wrappers, fish sauce, carrots, daikon, sprouts, mint, and basil at any of thousands of Vietnamese food outlets.


 The brutal French occupation of Vietnam from 1858 to 1954 resulted in much bloodshed and colonialist fallout, as documented in various historical studies. In terms of foodways, it had the more positive effect of widening the scope of Vietnamese cuisine by introducing French cooking techniques and customs. The Bo Nuong Sa is an exemplary dish, using native lemongrass to flavor thinly julienned green onions wrapped in a tightly rolled beef roulade,++ a cooking method unused in the region before the occupation.


 It was also the French proclivity to serve meals in multiple courses that influenced the Bo 7 Mon consumed by millions of Vietnamese today. Per the research of Steel,ºº the proprietor of Anh Hong's great grandmother wanted to introduce French-style, multicourse meals to Vietnam.


 As uncovered further in these field studies, it is common practice to drink Vietnam's 33 Export beer as a gustatory enhancement for Bo 7 Mon. Research into the background of 33 reveals further French influence, as well as Dutch. 33 is a beverage brewed by an arm of Netherlands-based Heineken International that specializes in the manufacture of beer in former French colonies, such as Vietnam and Morroco#. (Previous work by this researcher has found that 33 in Morocco is identical to 33 from Vietnam.)


 It can thus be gleaned that the components and the whole of Bo 7 Mon (and its accompanying beverages) as found at Anh Hong exemplify regional and colonial influences on modern Vietnamese culture, and that foodways are indeed a suitable means of examining a culture.


 While it would be irresponsible to condone invasion and occupation, or to make light of people's struggles against said invaders and occupiers, it can be scientifically concluded that the Chinese, Mongolian, and French sacking of Vietnam have resulted in something truly delicious.


 Sources:
º Jaffe and Fredericksen, 2005; ºº Steel, 2006; + Civil, 1995; ++ Pepin, 1976; # Heineken International annual report, 2006
author: Omid T.

description:
Went here for the first time in a couple years last night, and pretty  much as I remembered.  We skipped the Beef 7 ways this time and just go the "roll your own" rice paper rolls (bahn hoi, i think it's called).  we had the beef wrapped shrimp and the oriental grilled shrimps.  the beef wrapped ones were good, the oriental ones kinda boring.

by the way, if you don't know what to do when they bring you  the plates of round dry rice wrappers, lettuce, beans sprouts, etc. veggties, and the hot water --   dip the wrapper quickly in water to soften, lay it flat on the plate and put some lettuce, mint, basil, carrot, bean sprouts, the meat, rice cakes....etc. in the middle.   Roll up into a little cigar and dip in your choice of sauce (regular fish sauce, or something that sounds like mum nem, which has anchovy paste or shrimp paste or something like that, and is more tasty; i also dump in a bit of chili sauce) and eat.  (don't be embarrassed, we've all sat there looking confused at the plates of wrappers and veggies before someone told us what to do with it! :-)

service was slow; there were only two waiters handling the whole place, and we had to ask several times for our spring rolls and for water refills.  the prices seem to be a buck or two higher than comparable places around.

not bad...but not as good as pagolac, my fave in the neighborhood.
author: John R.

description:
I just tried this place yesterday night. The place was packed but really good (seems traditional) vietnamese food. We ordered teh 7 course beef, cos that's their specialty and let me tell you it was both fun and very good!

So they start with beef salad, beef fondue (which is like hot pot), and then they give you 4 types of beef sausage, or veggie wrapped beef and concluding with a beef rice soup.

And on the side, they give you rice paper, lettuce, basil, mint leaves, carrots, bean sprouts and cucumber. And basically you wrap your beef with all of these 'condiments'. You can make your own rice paper rolls or you can wrap the veggies and beef with a lettuce. Then you eat it with the fish sauce.

IT was a lot of food for $18.95 per person. So it definitely isn't super cheap but they do give you a lot of food! Try it!
author: Brian P.

description: Must order the 7 course beef, it was soooo good here. The only drawback was the $, kind of pricey.
author: Princess N.

description:
Ghetto location yet surprisingly the food was not bad.

Had separate dishes of the bo 7 mon (instead of ordering bo 7 mon aka  7 courses of  beef, we ordered individual dishes from the selection)....

The wrapped leaf beef was yummy, raw beef salad not bad,  egg rolls (alright) and their FRESH PRAWNS was really really good (MUST ORDER).
author: Katy N.

description:
"Let me show you guys how to eat."  This is what our waiter said to us after we let our Vietnam-born friend do the ordering who was apparently ordering the "white boy" dishes.

"Okay sir,  you pick for us."  He pick out the 7 courses of beef for 3 people, the Carpacio, and Papaya Salad.  Dayam....he hooked us up!   What he ordered had the 5 of us happily stuffed.  My favorite dish of the night was the Carpacio.  The beef was excellent quality and was seasoned nicely with lime, oil and topped with freshly chopped leafy herbs.  Actually, all of the beef dishes were made with high quality beef, each had its own unique flavor and everything was really good.

4.5 Stars!  I haven't had Vietnamese food this good since my last trip to Westminster.
author: Steve D.

description:
IF you love beef and vietnamese, this is your type of place.
Bring your group of friends or family here to try the 7 courses of beef.  Its a fun experience sharing and enjoying them together.  There will be plenty of food so don't worry.  Get ready to use your hands and dig in!
author: Eric Y.

description:
I usually go to Pagolac but thought to try this place. It is definitely much bigger than Pagolac so seating was fast.
We ordered the 7 course beef with an order of the Beef Carpaccio which I think was my favorite.  The courses were good and the beef was very fresh and tender.  bottomline, the food was good.
The place and location is not fancy, so don't expect some high end place. It is very very casual and the service is okay. Our waiter pretty much never stopped by our table unless the next course was ready and he didn't bother explaining how to eat anything, he just dumped everything on the table and assumed we knew what was what.  I was just wondering how it would of been if it was someone's first 7 course beef experience, they would be of been a bit confused.
author: Eva L.

description:
7-course beef ftw!! 

yeah it was that good.
author: Valerie N.

description:
I was disappointed that I wasn't starving when I came here but... as usual I put away a large portion of food nonetheless. Came here with the girls on a Sunday night. My friend was the only white girl- good sign of authenticity! The portions are extremely generous! We ordered fried wontons, beef 7 ways, crunchy fried noodles and a combo plate with chicken, ribs and rice. We asked our personality-deficient waiter if it was enough food for our group of 3 girls and his response was "it's ok". What did he think we were... bottomless pits? There was no way we could have finished everything we ordered... there was plenty of leftovers. 
The fried wontons- yummy! 
beef 7 ways- the restaurant's special dish. Definitely a fun way of eating! Couldn't even get thru all of it! 2 people could easily share 1 order of this meal. Or 1 super-starved fatty.
Combo plate- the chicken was delish!   
Crunchy fried noodles with chicken and veggies- I saw this on a table nxt to us and had to get it! Very tasty! 

Service- meh but not like I expected it to be fantastic! Go for the food and their excellent portions, not the service!
author: Amanda W.

description:
This place is overrated, that or I'm not use to wrapping all of my freaking food with the same flavors and ingredients over and over.

At first, the beef carpaccio looked good and was really exciting but the next 6 courses of beef to come were pretty much the same.  Either thinly sliced or in sausage form.  You continue to wrap everything in lettuce, mint, cilantro, carrots, daikon, cucumber.  JEBUS....your hands get wet and all the unpleasantness of that made the meal all the less enjoyable.

Seriously, it's the same frigging thing over and over and you are left with this wet sticky feeling in the hands.  Of course, I've only had a the 7 course beef the two times I've officially eaten here so I can't say much for the rest of their food but I would say, stay away, it's not really worth the $16.95 a person.

The only thing worth while was at the end, when they served a thin congee with ground beef and liver.

OVERRATED.
author: Winnie L.

description:
Hey Sum, it doesn't stink that much. It's better than Korean bbq. :)

This is the first time i tried 7 course beef. I like the the do-it-yourself spring rolls, beef onion wrap, and the porridge at the end. The meatball thingie is only so-so. As everyone wrote about anh hong had mentioned, if you have 5 people, you only need to order 4 or it will be too much. 

Price seems reasonable for the amount of meat you get.

Since it's only a couple blocks from my home, i will definitely go back out of convenience.
author: Hinling Y.

description:
Seriously!  Everytime I roll up in here - I have at least 20 people...20 people who are on a budget and hungry.  FYI - make sure you make a reservation!  Anyways suffice it to say, the people here are awesome!  I tell them what I want - and listen up because what I want is really delicious - and they deliver (not literally)!  

Order the following:

Sugar-cane shrimp balls
Imperial rolls
Beef Carpaccio
7 courses of Beef

Now tell the guy you want to feed this X amt of people and how much you want to spend and he'll cater the portion to your prefs!
author: Julie H.

description:
Come hungry and be prepared to carry the scintillating smell of 7-course beef on you all night!  (I ran into some friends at a party one time and they told me they went there for dinner earlier and I could totally smell the fresh scent of Vietnemese food on them!!) ;)

I've only ordered the 7-course beef special, and it does not mean a plate full of meat at each dish...its actually a nice blend of soup, light beef slices (like carpaccio), and then beef for your hand-made spring rolls that are de-lish!

It can definitely be shared between 2 people and its actually fun to go with a group of 4 so you can order other things for variety.

This place is typically crowded so as long as you are prepared for that, it can be a wonderful way to get your fill on Vietnemese food!
I'm rating this place simply on the food, not the decor or ambiance (that's another story).
author: Ahnee M.

description: Like all the other reviewers, I recommend the Seven Course Beef.  My sister loves this place; when we come here, we always get extra plates of pickled vegetables and no complaints from the wait staff.
author: C L.

description:
I remember my Vietnamese friends asked me if I wanted to some grubbing Viet food and pho was out of the question since we had that all the time. So they brought me here and boy am I glad they did.  This is the only place I go to for 7 courses of beef.  Out of the 7, my fav was the beef salad. A good start to a great meal.  Least favorite was the jook (rice porridge).  A little bit too watery for me.  I just love wrapping the beef and all the veggies up in the rice paper and dipping it into that pineapple shrimp sauce they have.  I just gobble it all up and on to the next wrap.  

It's located in the Tenderloin area and the parking is not that great, but I don't mind parking a little farther.  Just make sure you have a bodyguard with you.
author: Lucky M.

description:
Hard to believe......One star versus 4 star .... OR maybe some people are  just really really Cheap, rude and uneducated. Payless and expect more.  I have been here with my family for more than 15 years and never had any prob, food is good as always.





Gaile C Wrote

friend said (and wrote on the receipt where the tip should've been) "BAD ATTITUDE, BAD SERVICE, BUT GOOD FOOD"

my friend decided she wanted to go here for dinner. being viet herself, she knows her viet food. this being her second visit here in one week, she knows the portions too! *i came one last year, so this is my second time, and now i remember why it took me a year to come back, i tend to block bad experiences from my memory LOL*

they sat at least 3 parties that came in behind us ahead of us, even though we kept reminding the host that we had called in and he kept telling us we were next. when we finally got a table we were promptly ignored for a good 10 minutes. no menu, no water, no tea, no hello, NOTHING! finally someone came to throw the menus at us, and my friend already knew she wanted the 7 courses of beef so she tried to order that first. for those of you who have had 7 courses, you know that's quite enough to fill two people. the waiter wouldn't let us order, he kept saying we have to order more! so my friend said "ok, just order the 7 courses for us first, we'll look through the menu and add some appetizers" he was not having it, he yelled "YOU ORDER MORE!" and said something rude in chinese and walked away! UM HELLO! I'M CHINESE I UNDERSTOOD WHAT YOU SAID ASSHOLE! AND DON'T MAKE COME IN THE KITCHEN AND CUSS YOU OUT IN CHINESE, ENGLISH, SPANISH AND VIETNAMESE!!!! but per my friend's request, i bit my tongue! we ended up ordering 2 orders of 7 courses since we were able to get her mom to join us who was right around the corner. halfway through the meal, the bowl of water for the rice wrappers had gotten cold so we asked for it to be refreshed as well as a refill on auntie's cup of hot water and our waters too! he came back with a refreshed bowl of hot water and that was it. we proceeded to wave someone down for the next 15 or 20 mins to get our water refilled. no luck. even though they was coming by to throw our food on the table, they acted like they didn't hear us about the water. FINALLY, she got someone's attention and asked him to refill CUP OF HOT WATER AND CUP OF COLD WATER! the waiter/owner came back with one hot water. so she asked again for her cold water. he let out a big sigh and came back with the called water and told her "you tell me to come here too many times! you asked for hot water and then cold water and what else you need now?" my friend calmly told him than "no, i asked for refills on the hot and the cold water the first time YOU DIDN'T HEAR ME!" then she told him in vietnamese that she's been asking for the water for 20
author: jenna l.

description: Being a block from here and after reading all the review, finally we came and tried it! I actually thought this place is out nice, it is like a typical authentic Asian restaurant, the hole on a wall kinda of place. We order the infamous 7 course of beef. I thought they were all quite interesting. I like how they presented all different ways of cooking the beef. But I was kinda expecting more, because in one case, the dish with 3 rolls were supposed to be three different kinds. And I like some of the dishes, like the one with beef wrapped in leaves. I thought that was very delicious. We also had the BBQ beef where we get to BBQ our own beef in front of us in a tiny grill. The beef slices were super thin and were just perfect for the grill. And the point is after the grill, you get to eat the meat the Vietnamese way with them wrapped in rice paper and veggies! Overall, I will definitely recommend this place for trying something new and unique.  But I don't feel a draw for a crave to return for it.
author: Fung S. O.

description:
So for the record, here is why I'm only giving Anh Hong one star.

Food -- okay
Atmosphere -- okay
Service -- unacceptable

Much like every other time we've been to a Seven Course Beef restaurant we politely asked for seconds of the vegetables.  However, this time instead of receiving perhaps 50 cents worth of additional vegetables to enjoy with our dinner, we were denied.  I was beyond words.  I can understand if the question was to get more beef, but to deny us additional servings of the cheapest item on the menu?  Unacceptable.

Hence the one star.  Others may go, and I may even go back.  But we will never forget.
author: David M.

description: I was very excited to try 7 course beef and I left dinner very disappointed. I liked the beef fondue in the vinegar broth (i think), and the raw beef dish but all the other dishes were very similar to the point where they all tasted the same and looked the same. I expected more variety in the 7 courses of beef. So I don't think I will ever do 7 course beef again.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Foods and services are excellent at Anh Hong. However, the owner reserves and steals all tipping cash from his employees; no one there are allowed to share the tips, people close to the matter told. I just secretly tip waiter who serves me at the table. Hoping the owner will realize this matter soon; this is a CRIME.

Staff deserves 5 STARS.
Owner deserves my rating 1 star.
author: Best R.

description:
7 course beef for $21! 

Sooooooooo amazing. Second time here and we got the 7 course beef, the shrimp and sugar cane rolls and also the egg rolls. Comes with rice paper, lettuce, bean sprouts, and picked carrots. 
- Shrimp rolls were delicious! especially being wrapped with rice noodles in rice paper. 
- eggrolls: sooo good. but nothing special
- 1. beef salad was OK, not usually a big fan of that but it's really refreshing. 
- 2. beef carpaccio? with raw beef and you dip it in a soup like hot pot. this dish is one of their worst dishes and so we decided to get something else to substitute it. 
- 3. grilled beef lot leaf: DELICIOUS. one of my favorites! i love how it has peanuts inside to give it that crunch factor.
- 4. grilled beef lemongrass: also one of my least favorite dishes because the beef is dry and the onions overpower the beef.
- 5. beef sausage: my ALLL time favorite!! the number one dish that i look forward to.
- 6. beef meat balls: love this so much! it's AMAZING.
- 7. beef porridge: watery compared to what i'm used to. not really a fan but it's a good way to cleanse the body after all that beef. too much of a  ginger flavor. 

definitely recommend coming to this place! soo good! but parking can be a little hard.
author: Grace S.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a child and although I've always been sketchy of the neighborhood, this is probably the best Vietnamese restaurant in the bay so it's worth passing by crack heads and hobos.

They have the best Chao tom(sugar cane shrimp) and Cha Gio(egg rolls). You wrap them in Banh hoi(rice paper) with fresh veggies, dip them in Nuoc Mum and there goes half your meal. I've also recently tried their Tiger prawns in chili sauce. It's pretty good but it's pricey. I was actually shocked at our total for 6 people.

I would recommend Anh Hong to anyone who wants to try authentic Vietnamese food.
author: Michelle F.

description: 7 course beef anyone? This place does it right and it's really cheap. Me and the gf came here and we ate for about 2 hours. They did lag on serving us one course but after that the food flowed in and we ate until we no longer could. I really had a great time wrapping my own spring rolls and trying all the different ways they use beef. This is a must if you want try the 7 course beef. Great place and cheap.
author: alfred k.

description:
this is the first place i had 7 course beef and it was delish! i can't wait to try the real thing in vietnam. 

we also ordered the raw beef, which was delicious though it seemed to be drenched with a little too much fish sauce making the dish a little too salty. the 7 course beef was very good, basically its beef prepared in 7 different ways, there was a salad, a vinegar "hot pot", and 5 different types of beef that you wrap in lettuce/mint/etc. very filling!!

the place was packed with viet/chinese ppl, which is usually a good indication that this place is authentic.

overall, very good...wish they had this in nyc.
author: Flo T.

description:
We don't really care about service much, at least not when eating asian. But the service on the day we went (the day after New Years) was epecially bad.

But we do care about the food. The veggies were alright, but H thought the basil was uninspiring.  We both thought that the food got pretty boring. All the meat dishes tasted the same in the Seven Flavors of Beef.

We also got the sugarcane shrimpcake. We could not figure out how to eat it, so we ate it with our hands, sucked on the sugarcane, and pretended our parent's weren't watching.

We both would rather have good Bahn Mi than eat here again.
author: Huynh C.

description: You know when you're on a date and you're thinking, this dude is ok, but he really makes me miss this other dude?  Yes?  Such is the experience at Anh Hong if you've ever been to Pagolac.  The food is pretty similar:  imperial rolls, wraps, mounds of greens.  The place feels more like a chinese restaurant with the same kind of menus and the tank of karp.  Pagolac feels a little bit hipper with stone floors, vietnamese hipster servers, and amazing flavors that pop.  I wasn't too impressed with Anh Hong's shrimp on sugar cane -- tasted meaty rather than flavorful.  I was also kind of bummed that they expected us to pour our dipping sauce out of a glass because it meant that there were puddles all over the paper table cloth.  If I had never been to Pagolac though, Anh Hong would be good and nice and I would come back.  However, Pagolac is a few blocks away and it's just sexier.
author: Elena S.

description: I love Vietnamese food, and I especially love wrapping everything in rice paper and lettuce and bun, and BEEF! SOOO GOOD! This was my first time coming to anh hong and I loved it! Everything was great! The raw beef salad was "OMFG". I can't even explain it, yeah it was that good!  My favorite of the seven course beef was the beef sausage and the sausage wrapped in some kind of leaf. YUM! WRAP, WRAP, WRAP! ROLL ROLL ROLL! I think i used at least 50 rice papers to myself that night! LOL! Yeah i'm a fatty..what can i say... hehe
author: Brian P.

description: Went there tonight with my girlfriends and we got 4 orders of the 7-course beef for 5 people.  That's plenty of food.  In fact, we couldn't finish all the food so in retrospect, 3 orders would have been more than enough.  I really enjoyed courses 1 (beef salad), 2 (beef fondue), 3 (beef sausage), 4 (beef balls) and 7 (beef porridge) but courses 5 (beef with lemon grass) and 6 (beef with Hawaiian leaf) were a bit of a let-down.  Course 5 was hard to chew and course 6 was a little bland.  I think this place really deserves 3.5 stars but too bad we can't give out half-star ratings.
author: Sandy W.

description:
As beef tenderloin is to cow, Ahn Hong is to SF dinner options.  A center-cut, great choice, offering beefy possibilities galore. 

How fitting then, that this Vietnamese restaurant should be nestled in the heart of the bustling and hustling Tenderloin, a neighborhood that I love for its character and originality.

Slightly off the path of the other restaurants on the Little Saigon strip, I noticed that the quality of the food, the cleanliness of the restaurant, as well as the friendliness of the staff sets Ahn Hong apart from some of its neighboring businesses.  While our Yelpish group (nicely organized by Connie & Shatangi) was definitely the more multi-cultural than the other clientele in the restaurant, I did not feel that I would need a translator or guide for a return visit.

The 7 Courses of Beef dinner was a culinary delight and an excellent value (approximately $15 for the dinner as listed on the menu).   Shatangi wisely added an 8th course which was a combo grill of chicken, shrimp, squid, and of course...more beef - adding variety to our already vast spread of dishes.  Shatangi told you and now I'm telling you:  good choice.

1/ Beef in a Salad - excellent start, fresh greens, veg, onions, chopped peanuts in a citrusy dressing with very thin slices of beef - the least beefy of the beef dishes, and a great segway into the gluttony to follow...
2/ Beef in a Hot Pot - you cook, you assemble, you dip, you eat, all wrapped up in rice paper wrappers.  Provided to you are the raw beef, veggies, greens & herbs, and dipping sauces.  The anchovy one is deliciously sweet & savory - good on everything (even cream puffs, but I'm getting ahead...)
3/ Beef on a Grill - you cook, you assemble, you dip, you eat...
*Extra Course*/ Mixed Grill (Chicken, Squid, Shrimp, mo' Beef) - you cook, you...oh, you're getting it now
4/ Beef in a Sausage - lil links of savory goodness.  Not too fatty or greasy, very filling
5/ Beef in a Ball - meatloaf-like consistency (sorta, kinda) to scoop onto a big rice cracker.  Yum.
6/ Beef in a Wrap - Tea leaf wrapped around beef sausage AND Beef wrapped around sliced onions.  Just when you thought you could not pop one more thing into your mouth....they hit you with these little wonders
7/ Beef in Soup - brothy/ricey soup with bits-o-beef, ginger, spring onions.  Helps to ease 1-6 down the necessary passages.  Well, that's what I told myself.

Beverage of choice:  for me, Beer 33.  Cold, light and highly drinkable.

After dinner, we were treated to Beard Papa's Cream Puffs courtesy of Michael M.  An unholy match was made when Grace M. doused her Puff in the anchovy dipping sauce and declared it delicious.  Do not try this at home.

This type of dinner takes time, so my advice is to go with people you really like who are open to new experiences and are somewhat adventurous in their eating habits.  Also, since you are constantly cooking, dipping, etc, wear clothes that will not suffer should you splatter a little.  Other than that, just bring a big appetite and you will not be disappointed.  And how, Ahn Hong!
author: Liz S.

description: I think I would have liked this place more if I knew more of what to expect, my friend had found it on yelp but never read the reviews and had us meet here.  This is definitely a place that you come for the beef, since the waiter kept repeating "no noodle, only beef".  I think I found myself laughing most of the time because the waiters were hmm.. I guess very "involved" in our food experience.  After showing my friends how to wrap their food, they would constantly stand over our shoulders making sure we were doing it right and if we strayed from the path they would let us know and question every choice we made.  I think they were just trying to be helpful but I'm not gonna lie it was kind of intimidating.  I was boring and just had the chicken which was fine and I was able to try whatever beef dish my friends had and thought it was pretty good.  Now that I know the whole process I think I wouldn't mind giving it another try.  But I am slightly nervous about going again and accidentally wrapping it incorrectly.
author: Rebecca D.

description: The food here is delicious!!!!!! This is definitely the place to go if you havent tried a 7 course meal- there's a LOT of food. Putting your food in the wrapping can get messy but its well worth it! Parking can suck at times and the neighborhood is pretty shitty. Be sure to come here hungry!
author: M W.

description:
The owner of the Anh Hong in San Jose is a family friend, so I was excited to find out that there is one in San Francisco, which is owned by a relative of the San Jose restaurant.

Seven course beef is a traditional Vietnamese cuisine. The Anh Hong restaurants have passed down the secret recipes of their seven beef courses down through the generations, thus serving the most authentic Seven Course Beef! The seven courses are as follows:

1. Goi Bo (Beef salad): This is a mixture of carrots, bean sprouts, Vietnamese basil, garlic, lemon grass, onion and a few other things, tossed in a lime/fish sauce dressing.
2. Bo Dung Dam (Beef fondue): They provide you with raw (completely redred raw!!), thinly sliced meat and onions and a pot of boiling broth. You are supposed to first take one of the hard rice papers and dip it in the bowl of warm water that they provide. This makes the rice paper soft. Put it on your plate. Put some lettuce/carrots/daikon/cucumber or whatever veggies you want. Then you take a piece of meat and swish it around in the broth and put it on top of the veggies. Roll it up like an eggroll, dip it in the sauce the give you and enjoy!
3. Bo Cha Dum (Beef...meatloaf?): This is like a meatloaf/meatball of beef mixed with some veggies like peas and other things. 
4. Bo Moi Chai (Beef sausage): This is sort of like a beef sausage the size of like..two of your pinky finger. They grill it up for you to enjoy.
5. Bo La Lot (Beef sausage wrapped in leaves): This is a different kind of beef sausage as the prior, but about the same size and has a thin leaf wrapped around it before its grilled. You're supposed to eat the leaf :)
6. Bo Nuong Sa (Beef rolls): This is a thin slice of beef wrapped around onions (I think) and then grilled.
7. Chao Bo (Beef porridge): This is....well, it's beef porridge. Porridge with bits of beef in it.

As you can probably tell, it's quite the meal! Last time we came with 7 people, ordered 6 orders of the seven course beef and everyone was stuffed. Very reasonably priced too; we each paid ~15 bucks.

Overall, such a great place to get some good, authentic Vietnamese food. I always go home full and happy!
author: Christine L.

description: My mom brings the whole family here when her birthday rolls about.  For good reason too, the seven beef course is a good deal and the dishes are very authentic.  One of the better Vietnamese restaurants in the city that doesn't rely on Pho as a main attraction.  I forget the name of the appetizer but, there's this one appetizer with raw beef seasoned with cilantro and nuts and you cook it with lemon juice.  My goodness that appetizer is delightful.
author: Doogie H.

description:
At our last Yelpy international dinner, Shatangi suggested that we have our next one at Anh Hong. He raved about the famous 7 Courses of Beef Menu. To make sure I wouldn't be held responsible for killing any Yelpers by meat overdose, I planned our Vietnamese 7 Course Beef Extravaganza to occur 3 weeks after the Meat-O-Rama at Espetus.

The owners at Anh Hong were so accomodating to our party of 35. They allowed us to take over the entire mid-section of the restaurant without charging us for overbooking. Hen and I arrived at 7pm, and the tables were already set up and reserved for us. Since we were a bit early, we decided to sneak a cocktail down the street at Rye before dinner. Fortunately , we ran into Michael M on our way and kidnapped him and his 2.5 dozen of Beard Papas cream puffs. I was about to eat one of each flavored puff, thinking, how can a $15.00 7-course beef dinner be filling? $15?? It can't be THAT much food. But I refrained from grabbing the yellow boxes from Michael and promised I would wait until after the dinner. After a round of refreshing cocktails, we headed back to Anh Hong, where almost 2/3 of our party had already arrived. I LOVE it when people are EARLY and ON TIME!! (we got there at exactly 7:30)

As I passed out Yelp schwag and made people wear name tags, Mitch went on a photo-taking frenzy and the servers took our drink orders. They had a good selection of Asian beers, Vietnamese coffee and teas. 

And then, our 8 course beef dinner was served (believe it or not, Shatangi added one more)...

Each item was served with rice paper, mixed vegetable & greens, cucumber, carrots and bean sprouts. My fiancee had perfected the rice paper wrapping technique during our visit to Yummy Yummy, and was happy to showcase his talents again. I also sat next to Cassio, who found this rice paper to be genius. He referred to it as a big thin communion wafer. The plate of 50 or so wafers and hot water was placed in front of me, and between my fiancee and Cassio, I could have sworn I was judging some rice paper wrapped food eating contest. My fiancee would have won for presentation, but Cassio would have won for creativity. That guy was wrapping EVERYTHING! Let me explain:

Course #1. Goi Bo Special Beef Salad - A refreshing flavorful mixed salad:
Though the rice paper was not for this course, Cassio wrapped all of it in rice paper.
 
Course #2. Bo Dung Dam Beef Fondue - Slices of Tenderloin fondue at your table in a simmering red wine vinegar sauce:
As the beef was cooking in the fondue, Cassio wrapped ALL other available non-beef contents in rice paper. 

Course #3. Beef and shrimp to char-grill yourself:
Cassio finally started to wrap beef in the rice paper, and managed to stuff an entire wrap into his mouth as Kristina took his picture
 
Course #4. Bo Cha Dum Steamed Beef Meat Balls - Delicious Meat Balls mixed with Nuts, Mushrooms and various traditional Vietnamese spices: 
Me: "This is the last course right? We've been eating for ever. UGHH!"
Cassio: "I NEED MORE WRAPPERS!" 
 
Course #5. Bo La Lot Beef Wrapped in Hawaiian Lot Leaf - Minced beef mixed with spices and wrapped in an aromatic leaf freshly flown from Hawaii:
"We need more hot water!" In the meantime, Cassio managed to wrap food into a half dry rice paper.
 
Course #6. Bo Moi Chai Grilled Beef Sausages - Sausages mixed with spices grilled over charcoal to perfection:
New hot water bowl served. Cassio concluded, "The wet rice paper is definitely easier to wrap."
 
Course #7. Bo Nuong Sa Beef Grilled with Lemon Grass - Delicious charcoal grilled tenderloin rolls topped with peanuts and lemongrass sauce: 
"I LOVE THESE THINGS! I'D WRAP ALL MY FOOD IN THESE ALL THE TIME!!"
   
Course #8. Chao Bo Beef Rice Soup - A rich flavorful beef rice soup:
Cassio tried to wrap the soup, but failed. Instead, he wrapped whatever was left over in rice paper and dipped it into the porridge.

I made sure to keep the rice paper away from Cassio when he was eating a Beard Papas. Unfortunately, we could not keep Grace from dipping her cream puff into the fish sauce.
author: Connie C.

description:
The place to get a overdose on beef injections.  Well, that would be the next best thing to the 7 course beef meal.  Lovely and euge party tonight, thanks to organizers Shatangi and Connie for rallying up this mob of hungry Yelpers.  I made sure I had a light lunch to beef up for this beefy meal. 

The highlights of the 7 course beef meal was actually not the beef for me, but what enhanced this meat.  
1) this salad of julienned and sweet pickled cucumbers, turnips, carrots, with thin slices of beef, was topped with chopped peanuts and pieces of FRIED GARLIC.  yumm!
2) hotpot-cooked thin slices of rare beef, wrapped in rice paper, with lettuce, mint, cilantro, pickled carrots and turnips, sliced cucumbers, and bean sprouts.... the star of this dish... Vietnamese fish sauce (this has a recurring role for tonight's performance, as i used it in everything I ate tonight)
3) shabu-shabu style grilling of different meats: thinly sliced chicken, beef, calamari, shrimp, and ONIONS... all about the grilled onions.  Then you, again, serve this with the rice paper roll and veggies from course #2.  Damn the onions were good.
4) browned ground beef sausages with ONIONS--eaten with the wrapped rice paper roll or by itself.
5) beef mush with mung bean thread noodles formed in a gelatinous ball (looks like "pate"... but it's not), served with shrimp crackers. 
6) caramelized ONIONS wrapped in thin slices of beef---this is the beef roll.  You can eat this by itself or in the spring roll format.
7) the same browned sausages from #4, but this time, wrapped in some form of green leafy vegetable and grilled (not sure if this was mint)

Courses 2-6 is a great way for your group to work for their food.

((((my favorite: course #8 (because Yelp got the hook up): a lovely rice porridge/jook/congee/lugaw with strips of beef liver, chopped green onions, and GINGER!))))

I didn't really feel like I had all that beef in me because of all the wonderful roughage served with the different dishes.  I hope that will help with the anticipated constipation.

****try the Vietnamese fish sauce with a Beard Papa vanilla cream puff.... oh damn that was good. ****
author: Grace M.

description: The 7 courses of beef is exciting but the experience was totally destroyed when they hustled us out at 10:01 (they close at 10). I was half way through it so i was not actually able to enjoy all 7 courses. Perhaps they should not serve the 7 course beef meal after 9.
author: Jozias D.

description: An extraordinary beef wave.  An eight (8) course wave of beef assaulted us like platoons of attacking jihadis spilling out of the windows of all the nearby tenements and massage parlours.  At the end, I thought I was going to be paying 50 bucks.  When I was presented with my bill, it said $16.95!  What the FAWK?!?!?!  You so funny, Mr. Hong.
author: Rick H.

description: This 7-course beef kitchen served me the heartiest meal in over one year. So long as you have at least one Vietnamese dinner-mate who can instruct you how to assemble each course, this place is the land's end of Eastern cooking. What you get in each course will remain a surprise. On your first visit, if you profoundly enjoyed every course, CONGRATULATIONS. You are now a connoisseur of Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I suddenly had a craving for Vietnamese food and decided to take a trip down to the Tenderloin. This is one of our favorite places to go for Vietnamese cuisine in SF. We brought Vietnamese family members and friends and they do not have anything bad to say about this place. 

Start with the 7 courses and order extra servings of whatever you like in the 7 courses of beef. I recommend the shrimp rolls with the sugar cane in the middle. Last but not least you have the get the congee it is the best after your meal and is something that I always look forward to after eating at the place. Trust me you will have a extra stomach for this soup.
author: Becky T.

description: Anh Hong is the place to be to enjoy the variant Vietnamese delicacies. I enjoyed the wraps, the 7 course beef, and off the menu items. I normally go with friends as - its a great place for groups to feast. Service is great as well.
author: Johnson H.

description: Most of my Vietnamese dining usually involves pho but this was different-two orders of seven courses of beef for four people was more than enough and decently priced.
author: Tricia L.

description: I came here with 15+ friends last night. I didn't have the 7-course beef, but the dinner combination that I had, grilled pork with house salad and fried rice, was great. I was really surprised at the amount of pork they had provided. The pork was thinly sliced and had very distinct grill marks. It was mild and delicious in flavor. There was a good portion of house salad and fried rice as well. They were both okay. My meal costs $9.95, which I consider a bargain, considering the amount of food that was on my plate.
author: Diana C.

description: i came here for a friend's bday dinner and it was such a great experience! the food was spectacular and it just kept coming. The only reason why I give it a four instead of a five is due to its location in the TL and its priciness. I would come back a lot more if it were more closer to $15, but over $20 is too steep for vietnamese food for me...
author: Rosa K.

description: Authentically good 7 course beef... lots of food so come hungry!  This place is down and dirty 7 course beef... no fancy presentation.. just good food.  service is tolerable and fast.
author: Alan N.

description: Came here with my relatives who live in SF and claimed that it tastes better than the one in LA. Ehhh....not really pretty much the same. The first course salad doesn't have shrimp (unless you have to request the add-on since I didn't do the ordering). The beef on the salad was so bland, seemed like they just boiled it in water. The mum was not stinky enough... the stench is suppose to linger on my hands after I wash with soap and water but it was gone.  The last course beef porridge didn't have those tiny abc, star shaped pasta. We also ordered the sugar cane shrimp which was pretty good. we also ordered the egg rolls and were not crispy enough.
author: Keri T.

description: Anh Hong is pretty good.  Pagolac has better ambiance and slightly better taste, but Anh Hong has a larger area and bigger portions.  Better for groups.  This is more like the places I am used to from OC.
author: Bert N.

description: my family and i have been coming here for over 10 years... enough said. dont order anything else other than 7 course beef because thats what this place is known for. OH but you have to get the sugar cane shrimp... my buddies and i ALWAYS get the 7 course beef and sugar cane shrimp. its almost become a tradition to get the 2. ive never gotten the other stuff but im sure its good too. if you dont get the full 7 course ordeal, you HAVE to get the a la cart grilled grape leaf wrapped beef. thats my favorite dish.
author: Sam L.

description: The seven courses of beef is always a crowd pleaser.  It's also a great date restaurant if you just get the beef fondue.  The staff is even friendly after you've gotten way too drunk and loud with your friends the time before.
author: Charlie S.

description: My favorite Vietnamese 7 course beef spot. For $16.95.. you get a whole lotta food!! Their shrimp in sugar cane and Anh hong egg rolls are a must try also. I come here every chance I feel like wrapping up some meat.. You always come in hungry but leave with food coma.. and smelly clothes.. Friday and Saturday's are always busy filled with Vietnamese families.
author: Juliane N.

description: Best Banh hoi chao tom ever.  Chao Tom is the ground shrimp wraps around a sugar cane then grill it to perfection.   It comes with some banh hoi (the thin kind of rice noodles that is baked together so that it looks like a cake).  Cut the shrimp to slices then wrap with some banh hoi, veggies and dip in the fish sauce... it's like heaven :)  Believe me, you got to try it.   They have really good mam nem (shimp sauce), but most of my American friends don't like it, they think it's stinky.  If you like mam nem, make sure to get some from here.  The 7 courses is also pretty good, the portion is a little bit big.  They have awesome Bo la lot (beef wraps in betel leaves then grill).  You will get out of this place smelled like grill beef.
author: Lily K.

description: Don't be fooled, the portions are filling. We ordered too many dishes thinking there wasn't enough food but quickly realized we were in over our heads. However, thanks to all the food we learned a new craft, rolling spring rolls! The trick is to roll, not fold. Sounds obvious but it isn't intuitive. And if you don't know, now you know.
author: Richard S.

description: Came here with two of my friends and had the seven courses of beef . The first course was the beef salad was alright but failed to impress me . The second course beef carpaccio which was basically a beef fondue where you take the beef and wrap it in rice paper along with veggies to make your own spring rolls which you later dip in sauce . The beef carpaccio was pretty good ... the beef was very yummy . You can wrap the third , fourth , and fifth in rice paper if you wish to as well . The third course was the grilled beef lot leaf sausages which was alright . I forgot which course but there was one that was really good ... it was either the fourth course which was grilled beef lemongrass or the fifth course which was beef sausage . One of them is very good and the other is just alright . The sixth course which was beef meat balls weren't that great ... it crumbled easily and did not taste that great . The seventh course which was beef porridge tasted weird at first but ended up to be kinda good later on . I've never had the 7 course beef before so this was my first time . The name is kinda deceiving . I kinda expected more food because " 7 course beef " makes it sound like it would be a heavy meal but it's actually quite a light meal . I expected there to be more food ... I didn't expect 4 courses to be on one plate . Also , it does get a little annoying making your own food after a while . I would recommend trying the 7 course beef here if you haven't tried it before because it's definitely worth trying at least once . As for the food ... it was not bad but failed to impress me . I think if I wanted to have a meal like this , I would rather have it at home . I still prefer eating ready-made food when going to restaurants ...
author: Eileen L.

description: Every time I've gone here, it's been busy, but the wait usually doesn't take that long. You can order a variety of beef dish including soups, bbq or salads. It's definitely a good place to go to when going out with family or taking people from out of town out to eat. There's little vegetarian options but if you talk to the waiter, they'll make something for you. Overall great place with great customer service as well.
author: julia n.

description:
I had never tried the 7 courses of beef action before coming to anh hong.
and i never really tried something called raw beef salad...i think they should call it something else, for the record. 
but everything was absolutely great!  i loved the raw beef, and the many different types of beef mixes...even had a little hotpot action. 
we had 4 people, but didn't pay attention to how much we ordered, but it was just right...maybe the staff can help you with how much to order. 
great evening and i will definitely recommend this place to anyone who hasn't tried this type of vietnamese cuisine!
author: Roy N.

description: So I took a big group of gringos here to try the famed Seven Courses of Beef. That's right. SEVEN COURSES. It was almost too much for them to handle. There were eight of us so we ordered seven servings of seven courses of beef. We killed the first and second courses, faltered on the third and fourth and totally failed the fifth, sixth and seventh. Standouts included the beef wrapped in lot leaf and the beef meatballs with shrimp chips. This place is pretty good and a pretty good deal as well as the whole meal set us back twenty bucks or so (including tax and tip!) The ambiance is not as nice as Pagolac but the portions are more generous and some of the dishes are definitely better. And when it comes to wrapping the beef, remember Katherine, wrap it like a burrito!!
author: Cathy T.

description: another place that i find that is pretty over rated.  The food here is whatever. All i have to say is they charge you up the  @$$ for making your own spring rolls when it cost near to nothing to buy the ingredients wtf? i havent went ate here in a long time because i dont care for the food here.  There are plenty of other places i would rather eat in tl instead of here. Another quick tip is when you pay for your bill remember to double check for what you order because this place tend to charge you for things you dont ever get or order.
author: Art N.

description:
7 courses beef?!?! ok, i'd really prefer brazilian bbq if we're talking 7 courses of beef, but the vietnamese don't do it too bad either.

i'm horrible, HORRIBLE at wrapping, but luckily my gf is fabulous at it.  slightly degrading since you feel like a 5 year old, sure, but it helps you eat all that much more.  i wrap one ugly one while she wraps a nice one just as i've finished eating my ugly one.  constant stream of food!

the food is pretty solid for vietnamese.  but again, find a practically vietnamese gf first or be prepared to make a mess.
author: Steven C.

description: Can you say "beef" seven times? By the end of the night you will be beef out by their 7-course beef meal. This place is not your typical Vietnamese restaurant and I can't say how authentic the meal was, but the food was really good.  No extra points for the ambiance or service. Hey what do you expect, it's an Asian restaurant...as long as the food is good, I don't have any complaints. I wouldn't mind going to this place more often, but the location has kept me from going back.  The tenderloin is not exactly the safest area and parking is a real BIATCH!!!
author: hello k.

description: My huband and I took my dad here for Father's day last Sunday. We love their sister restaurant in Berkeley, but since we weren't going to order the huge baked cat fish (which is not available at the SF location), we decided to stay local. We ordered the fried spring rolls, which were perfectly crisp and not greasy and got 2 orders of the grilled beef and shrimp. The shrimp were rolled in thin slices of marinated beef and sat on top of flat noodles sprinkled with crushed peanuts. We were provided a bowl of hot water for our rice wrappers and each of us rolled about 4-5 of these tasty treats. It was definitely a good meal.  Service is spotty and when the waiter did come to take our order he was rude and very rushed. When I had my credit card ready for payment however, they were quick to serve. Food is great, just prepare yourself for the poor service.
author: Yelp O.

description: First time trying the 7-Course Beef...Yummmm! If you like meat, this is definitely worth it! For less than $20, you can't beat it! It's not a fancy joint but good food for a reasonable price!
author: Joy A.

description: I went there last weekend with 5 other friends... we ordered 3 orders worth of the 7 course beef, their sugar cane shimp, crab/shrimp ball claws and a grilled pork thing.  Everything we had was yummy.  I love this place because I am 8 months pregnant... and it helps lets me eat lots of veggies with a lil beef.  (And yes i made sure everything was well done- for me at least).  Neighborhood isn't that great..but its worth the trip for the food.
author: Sheenie L.

description: I love this place!  We always get the 7 course beef meal.  It's delicious!  We always order one order less than number of people in our party because there's a ton of food. I would make a reservation since it can get crowded.  I didn't give it 5 stars because the service isn't that great, especially when they are busy.
author: Stacey L.

description: everyone seems to raving the 7 course beef, but my favorite at Anh Hong is the sugar cane shrimp. The serving is generous--not the dried out whimpy shrimp that you get elsewhere--served with noodles and lots of fresh mints and lettuce. So roll up your sleeve and get ready to wrap you own rolls. Yum!
author: A L.

description: Did I miss something?  A friend and I had Anh Hong's popular 7 course beef and shrimp paste cane appetizer yesterday evening.  There were some that tasted good - shrimp appetizer and beef porridge.  However, overall, I had better Vietnamese food at many other places.
author: MJ K.

description: Average vietnamese, did not have a good selection of pho, and a bit expensive.
author: Eric W.

description: See my review of Anh Hong, San Jose.
author: Hao L.

description: This Vietnamese restaurant located in the outskirts of the 'Loin serves up a mean 7-course beef dinner. Yes, that's beef served up 7 different ways. Anh Hong is a good place to have a family-style dinner with group of friends or family over some ice cold "33's". Overall, Anh Hong is a good value and worth a try if you're into beef and it's delicious variations.
author: Be N.

description: I give it 5 stars not because it is the best restaurant I have been too, but because it was the best Vietnamese food I have ever had. It was fantastic and seemed to be very authentic, fresh and a totally unique dining experience. We had the shrimp fondue, and the beef grill thing, all were fabulous! If you are looking for something new and tasty to try, come here, you won't be disappointed.
author: Julia T.

description: Man, weird! It's kind of pornographic (at least as pornographic as beef can get).
author: christopher a.

description: My review is really a 3.5 but since there's no halves, I decided with 3 stars.  My group tried the 7 course beef meal.  It started off with the carpacio.  Man, that thing was delicious.  I was ready to greedily eat all of it for myself but I had to constrain myself.  Second beef item was a salad with small slices of beef which I thought was pretty good but not great.  I was wondering since we're only on the second item, the next 5 must be good.  Then, 3-6 came out simultaneously: 3 different types of sausages.  We were to use those hard Vietnamese tortillas, dip it in water, and then stuff them with beef and other things like carrots.  It was a disappointment since I expected many different types of dishes.   The last dish was watered down rice porridge with small pieces of been and lots of ginger.  I didn't like it because it was watered down and there were way too much ginger to even taste anything else.
author: Ronald L.

description: I went for Bo Bay Mon - seven courses of beef.  It was a lot of food, but the courses started to get very similar and it was just too much beef and not enough flavor.
author: nicole h.

description: The La Lot (beef sausages you wrap in rice paper and mint yourself) are great as are the fantastic korean BBQ ribs.
author: Issa K.

description: When the signature dish is printed on the outside cover of the menu, its safe to say that's what you should order. Such is the case here as the 7 course beef is definitely the way to go. Its not the best meal on earth, but is unique, fresh and tasty. If you are looking for an intimate spot for a romantic dinner, look elsewhere, as this place is filled mostly with large tables of families. The menu also has some typical (and not so typical) Vietnamese fare, if the idea of 7 courses of beef doesn't appeal to you...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Best Vietnamese place in San Francisco!

The location isn't the best but the food here makes it top notch.  I never come for the ambiance anyways.  

Like many other people say, you have to order the 7 course beef dinner.  You will be stuffed and extremely content.  Basically, you just get 7 huge dishes of beef pastes, sausages, skewers, etc... with different wraps and rice noodles.  Dip them all in the fish sauce.  There's also a really good soup that comes with it.  I could be wrong about what was exactly on the menu because we had a friend order for us.  I know we did the 7 courses though.  

I think the price is really good too.  It was about $20+ per person for dinner.  Great price considering how good the food was and how much we got.  If you can't speak vietnamese, ask the waiters to help you order.  

I've also come here for just 5 courses of the beef dinner and was pretty stuffed so you will have plenty of food.  I'm coming back next Wednesday for a birthday!  I crave beef!
author: Scott L.

description: I love this place.  I rarely get the 7 courses beef here because I don't really like the rice porridge at the end or the random meat loaf looking thing.  I just get a couple orders of sugarcane shrimp, Bo La Lot (beef wrapped in a leaf), and Bo Moi Chai (beef sausages).  They'll give you as many fresh veggies as you want just keep asking for more.  It's a great place to go with a large group.
author: Joann C.

description: I love the 7 course beef! Everything is uber tasty and the portions are very generous! Not cheap for the TL, but worth every buck!
author: S N.

description: I can't believe I never yelped this place. I love this place, it beats the one in SJ by a ton. Well, lets start from the top.. they dish you out the GOI which is salad. I hope I spelled it right. it's never wrapped just eat it like that! and then the beef in Vietnamese hot pot pans, and candle wax. When I went back to my homeland, thats what they did too! it was awesome. except the fact that instead of wrapping beef we wrapped puffer fish :[ then theres the meatloaf, wrapped beef in lot leaf, and beef wrapped over onions, and just beef. Sorry to say it doesn't make me full :[ I know its rice and all but me and AT we can eat this forever at home when we make it it takes like 15 rolls for AT to be full but he can keep on going. What I hate about this place is how little veggies they give you. Theres always toooo much or toooo little rice wrap so I bring my own! LOL. that's because I have a lot of home.  I'm asian like that! Then after all is done, you get the yummy porridge that i love, because i can't stand porridge at my house AT says it's like baby food. but this is good. i love every moment and every time i eat here, its like MMM. MMM in my tummy! :D oh and if it's just two people you should order one order and then order one order of bun cha gio, and you can wrap that, because thats how we do it at my house! :] it makes you full faster. My home away from home :[ Plus, there's tons of parking after 6 because that frees up all the yellow spaces. CrdtCrd and Csh obviously are excepted. They have good Cha Ba Mau.
author: Carolyn Y.

description: I guess when you first walk in, you don't expect much from this place. At least, that's what I was thinking when I first walked in. It looked a little dirty, small, simply like a regular Vietnamese joint with mediocore food. Then I had the 7 Course Beef. Let me tell you, it's pretty DAMN good! It definitely gets you full. The last two times I came here, I came in big groups where we had to reserve ahead of time. There wasn't a problem with the space and we always got straight to our tables as soon as we arrived. The service sucks pretty bad. They're mostly rude and very ignorant- definitely never follow American customs of "the customers are always first". I think the Mexican workers that clean up the tables are probably the nicest workers there! I love Vietnamese food, but I hate Vietnamese service! Anyways, I deducted one star for the service and the cleanliness of the place. Otherwise, 4 GOOD STARS for the GOOD food.
author: Sylvia N.

description: I love the idea of wrapping your own spring rolls so we ordered the 7 course beef along with some other dishes. The food was delicious.. i liked the meat sausages with the onion inside, and i liked the beef rice soup too. The people who work there were friendly and got us more of the wraps when we were out. I will definitely come back to try the 7 course beef again. Its worth it because you will be stuffed by the time you leave. And its not expensive either if you plan on sharing.
author: christy w.

description: This place is a must go!  My friend took me here last weekend and there was a line out of the door.  Super crowded, but fast and efficient.  So put your name down but don't go anywhere, cause even if you are 6th in line, you will probably be called in 10 minutes tops.  I felt like I was in Singapore at this place.  Loud, bustling, packed with families and the like.  7 course beef is delicious. Do not go for the ambience, you know this already.
author: Rikki D.

description: been coming here for over 20 years! my family loves it! my favorite is the beef porridge.. cant get it anywhere else. yum! and the cha gio is better than anywhere else...
author: L M.

description:
omg, i never knew beef could come in so many variations and incarnations, each one successively tastier.

i feel a little bad about eating so many cows but i heard that cows produce 20% of carbon emissions so i'm really doing my part to reduce my daily impact.
author: Joanne L.
